description:
This is probably my favorite chili house in the city! I came here Sunday at 1pm with reservation, it's actually not a long wait with reservation. We, party of two, waited for about ten minutes and got seated in a clean table. The environment of the house is in a very traditional Chinese feeling. We ordered 5 dishes and they are all very good that I would highly recommend to try!!

1. Beijing pot stickers 鍋貼
2. Tan Tan noodle 擔擔麵
3. Pebbly jellied meat 水晶魚凍
4. Pork with Szechuan pickled mustard broth 酸菜白肉
5. Peking duck 北京烤鴨

Food impressions
1. Very appetizing to eat before enjoying the real entree. This pot stick is a very traditional Beijing food that I couldn't believe I can try in SF (I have tried it once when I travelled back to china and they tasted almost the same!) The pork in the pot stick is very fresh and savory! Give it a try and you will love it!
2. The Tan Tan noodle is sooooo good! It smells so delicious and spicy, but actually it isn't that spicy. I would give this noodle a five star, because it tasted very good like traditional north Chinese's handmade noodle!
3. The pebbly jellied meat is very great and it looks so cute! It uses some yellow-bean to make the "jellied meat" in a fish-like shape, added with the special homemade sauce, and made it tasted so good as an appetizer before meal!
4. This is an entree that the cook highly recommended us to try, and it's in the "secret menu" that not much known of. It tasted so good and it has my favorite vermicelli in it!! It is very good to eat with white rice, because the meat has absorbed all the flavor of the broth and became very savory!
5. This is my favorite dish of the night! I always love the way how Chinese cooked the duck, and this is my favorite cooking method! We enjoyed the special taste of Beijing Roast Duck by covering the slices with special sauce jam and green-onion shreds on a soft flat bread. And after that, they cooked a soup with the rest of the duck (the part that couldn't be sliced down). They cooked a duck in two ways, so we can enjoy both the sliced duck and the soup! I love this so much!

Service impressions
Fast, competent, and efficient wait-staff. Very nice and patient to introduce you their famous foods!

Would definitely come back!!
author: Patricia L.

description:
This is a long over due review to Chili House. This place is a perfect place to go if you want to bring guests to entertain with the kungfu tea show, or just simply to enjoy their delicious food!

Parking is a street lot, which is expected in SF. 

What we ordered;
1. Kungfu Tea- actually this is the main reason why I went to this restaurant, I wanted to show my kids and my mother how cool the kungfu tea performance was. The price quite be steep but my kids and mom really enjoyed the performance. Something that you don't get to see in San Jose. 
2. Beef Wrap. Juicy beef meat wrapped with chinese tortilla skin. Inside you would see some veggies, some sauce that made it all so good. 
3. Noodle with Chilli Oil. The noodle is not soggy, chewy, chilli oil is not that hot. Definitely will re order this dish if we're planning to come back. 
4. Steamed Scallops and Steamed pork dumpling. These are also good as well. Juicy on the inside, and most importantly the dumpling's skin is not that thick. Some places sell their dumpling skin way too thick that you feel like just eating flour. Unlike this one, the portion of the meat was generous as well. 
5. Shiumai - nothing really extra ordinary. I prefer the ones that still have chunks of shrimp inside. But not bad for the taste itself. 
6. Fried Noodle - I ordered this dish specifically for my kids, and they totally loved it. 
7. Peking Duck. GET THIS DISH WHILE YOU'RE HERE!! Because this is what they are famous for! Duck was juicy, not too dry. They will slice is in front of you with the walking tray, and they will serve the duck bone as a soup with veggies that will be served after all the dish came out. You usually eat the sliced duck wrapped in thin flour skin along with sliced cucumbers and some hoisin sauce. So good!

Will come back for sure!
author: Maureen M.

description:
We were invited to a banquet dinner here recently, it was indeed a very substantial and impressive meal. Service was friendly but a little chaotic, lots of food both in varieties and portions but with some hits and misses. All the dishes were plated beautifully, kudos to the chefs;  tea serving with the super long neck kettle from a distance was fun and interesting to watch.     
The starters were all pretty good, chicken in spicy sauce, couple's delight,  pig skin jello in a fish mold and my favorite the bitter melon ribbon in honey sauce, which was pleasing to the eyes and taste buds.
Dim sum were done well, the fried egg rolls were crispy, Peking shao mai was tasty and juicy which I liked better then the Cantonese style, dan dan noodles had good texture but a little too spicy for my taste.
There were many large plates; the one dish we enjoyed the most was the seafood stew with prawns, clams and fish, all poached perfectly in a tasty spicy broth. The Peking duck carved table side was decent and stir fried pea shoots is always a crowd pleaser. A repeating theme in several of the dishes was over frying (and the reason for 3 instead 4 stars). The large prawns in mayo sauce was dry and tough; sweet and sour fish, same issue, even the baby meat balls although very tasty can be cooked a little less.  The platter of sweets was again interesting and fun to explore. 
Definitely a place worth coming back for and hopefully they can better control the frying time.
author: Julie W.

description:
I have literally been eating here since they first opened after taking over the burnt down shell left by the previous noodle(?) place. I'm not too sure if they've had a change in hands at some point over the years - possibly around the same time they started hard selling their Peking duck - but the spicy staples that I've once loved from them are loved no more.

While the Couple's Delight, Twice-cooked Pork, and Spicy Wontons (I order these three specifically, every time) are still good, they're just simply not what they used to be. Though I find their staple dishes a tad lacking, I do quite enjoy their Salted Egg Yolk Pumpkin but the Peking Duck in all honesty, is just "okay" in my opinion. I won't say that I've had better in The City - because I haven't - but the fact that they praise their designated chef's resume so often, at the least, I kind of wish it all lived up to its hype. Again, just my two cents.

I will always come back to this place but I still wish they hadn't changed whatever it was they changed in the quality/recipe/technique they once mastered for their more simpler dishes.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
I did not do my homework before coming here...I came to Chili House SF on a Sunday evening WITHOUT making reservations. Big mistake as the wait was over an hour. There were several parties ahead of us that had even left because they were tired of waiting. When we finally got a table, we were ignored for quite some time. We were seated before the table across from us, however, the other table was given tea, had their order taken, and even start receiving their dishes BEFORE we were even acknowledged...and it was only because we had to manually flag a waiter down before any service was given to our table. 

As for the food....the Shanghai Wine Chicken ($10.95) was tender and delicious. This was one of the best wine chicken I've tried and my favorite out of everything we ordered. 

The Cauliflower with Smoked Pork in Mini Flaming Pot ($15.95) was another good order. It is a little spicy, but the flavors were pretty good. 

Tan Tan Noodles ($7.95) - I did not like this dish as the sauce was too spicy and did not have the right flavor. I would not order this one again. 

Couple's Delight ($8.95) - Although I did enjoy the beef slices, tripe, and tendon pieces, the flavor was too spicy for me. Also, the spices were tiny and scattered throughout the dish, a little too messy. If you enjoy REALLY spicy flavor, you'll probably enjoy this dish. 

Overall, it was an okay experience, but the wait was too long, the wait for service was too long, and a few of the dishes were too spicy. Their Peking Duck looked pretty good, which I would be interested to try in the future. This restaurant does not provide complimentary tea, they charge $1.75 for a bowl of rice, 30 cents for each take out container you request, and 10 cents for a to-go bag. Just mentioning the small details. Also, another piece of homework I didn't do...Groupon offers 20% cash back through your credit card. Do yourself a favor and make a reservation through Yelp before coming here.
author: Jean S.

description:
I'm here to put all of these bad reviews to rest...

1) The peking duck wasn't the juiciest, but it was still amazing. What stood out to me was the amazing sauce that accompanied it. It was like a mixture of hoisin, oyster, and some some floral notes (I would recommend, drinking the hot Jasmine tea with this dish to bring out more the floral notes). And the pancakes that came with it were so incredibly thin, which is great so that you don't fill up on the carbs. This meal also came with green onions and cucumber. And they offer to make a soup of the carcass, stir fry it, or deep fry it. We had it deep fried with salt and pepper, which was good, but we would've preferred it in a soup. Still very delicious. 

2) The Szechwan Green beans were spectacular. The green beans are dusted in flower and fried for a light crispiness and then topped with fermented black beans (for saltiness), chopped nuts, and roasted Szechwan pepper (tasted like camp fire marshmallows and a mild spiciness). 

3) Spicy Wontons: The wontons were amazing. Most people forget to dip them in a little bit of soy sauce, which is why they think it's flavorless. it sits a pool of chili oil which looks intense, but they're actually beautifully balanced and not over powering at all. 

We would've loved to order more, but it was just two of us and we were already so full. We would love to come back again for dim sum.
author: Lizzy S.

description:
I just ate at their sister restaurant 2 weeks ago and have been craving Szechuan food ever since so why not try them out? 

This spot is closer to my apartment and not right on in Chinatown. 

But while they're pretty good, there's a reason their sister spot has the Michelin star and not them. They just aren't as good. 

We ordered almost the exact same dishes as we did as their sister spot. The fresh fish in spicy oil, salted egg yolk pumpkin, the tan tan mien noodles...

I actually like the tan tan mien noodles better here. They're spicier. 

Their fish in chili oil is pretty good too but somehow seems watered down in comparison to its sister.

Salted egg yolk pumpkin was okay as well too. Not as flavorful though but had decent texture... I just have to separate the two restaurants but it's hard not to compare them.

Overall it's a good spot and I enjoyed it, but if I'm craving Szechuan, I think I'll make the trek downtown.
author: Mandi W.

description:
YUM. I'm from LA SGV area so I am definitely a Chinese/Asian food snob. Bay Area/SF honestly lack amazing chinese food (yes, I don't like San Tung), but this Chili House and it's sister restauarant, Z&Y both do a great job on the food. I came here 3 times at least and enjoyed my food. The Szechuan food is on point here and I do think it is better than the dishes that were non-spicy. The peppers give the food a nice flavor without being TOO spicy (depends if you can tolerate spice or not). 

My favorite dishes here include:
- Peking duck (fresh and sliced in front of you)
- Explosive Chicken
- Chili Pot Boil Fish Fillet 
- Pot Stickers (Beijing style ones)

Other dishes I enjoyed:
- Green onion pancake
- Crispy Shrimp
- Tan Tan Noodles
- Orange chicken (WOW actually really great here) 

If you're coming here for Chinese food without the spices, they are just ok. Also you can make a reservation on Yelp!! This defintely my to go restaurant in SF for Chinese food.
author: Micaela I.

description:
Peking duck is authentic, especially liked the "tortilla" thing they're sooo good and yummy! The duck bone broth is super delicious an authentic. I went with someone actually from Beijing and he LOVED it!

I also recommend the poke dumplings and the fried dumplings, they are extremely good, and the fillings are so juicy and tender!

The spicy fish was also delicious, the fish was fresh, and tender, would recommend! 

The service here is really good! The waiter we had was really attentive and nice. We also ordered the Kungfu tea service, which was quite fun to watch because there was a tea artist performing right in front of us! 

Food was real good overall, the environment was nice and welcoming. Would definitely go back again!
author: Hermione L.

description: Nice way to combine traditional​Chinese​e tea culture into Chinese​ food, as a Chinese, this is the old-fashion way to present how we drink tea, but it also is ​good to let world-people know what Chinese tea really is.
author: Faye L.

description:
A picture is worth a thousand words. At least that's what Bread sang back in 1971, and OK, maybe Confucius said it a few centuries earlier. But it resonated when I walked by this popular eatery while strolling on Clement and saw a close-up photo of the Poached Chicken in Explosive Chili Peppers. I decided I needed to try it, so a few weeks later, I came back for lunch. In the meantime, I perused some of the online articles about this place and discovered it shares the same owner as Z&Y in Chinatown (review: http://bit.ly/2x4YGpm). They appear to be famous for their Peking Duck as well as spicy Sichuan-style dishes like the one that caught my eye.

I was by myself, so I couldn't find it in my conscience to order anything beyond the $15.95 poultry I saw. It came in a fairly large bowl and the intimidated my rather sensitive palate with the heavy oil and intense red of the peppers which completely overwhelmed the smallish chicken pieces and heavily boiled vegetables (photo: http://bit.ly/2LmbYkp). I have to say I was disappointed as there appeared to be more skin than meat in the dish (photo: http://bit.ly/2s0oyO3), and it required at least one bowl of the $1.75 Steamed White Rice (photo: http://bit.ly/2LmcWNz). I'm no Sichuan culinary expert, but I could barely eat a third of it. So much for the worth of a picture.

FOOD - 3 stars...spicy and oily concoction that disappointed me
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...spacious and not too crowded on a Thursday afternoon
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...not too friendly or forthcoming with insight on Sichuan cuisine
TOTAL - 3 stars...for Sichuan and Peking Duck aficionados only
author: Ed U.

description:
In A Nutshell:

-Did you know that Chili House SF is under the direction of Michelin Chef Li Jun Han?
-His other restaurant is Z&Y (that's the one in the Michelin guide).
-Came here b/c my wife & I were in the mood for some Peking Duck.
-After checking in, a nice 50% off coupon for XLB's was available, so we ordered those too.
-The XLB's were very good, not bad at all, so order those, especially at 50% off!
-The Peking Duck took some time to arrive, but that's expected.
-What wasn't expected was the skin, it wasn't crispy, but the duck was still very tasty.

Overall, we'll come back again to try some other delicious menu items we saw.  Check em out.
author: Romeo K.

description:
FIREEEEE! So hot. But in the best  way possible.  My friend and I went here on a whim, based on some foodie IG story. And we're glad we did. The meal was outstanding and I can't wait to go back!

Started with tan tan noodles. I didn't remember the last time I had anything that spicy. But I loved it.

Then and the kung pao shrimp (best flavor out of everything), the fire pepper chicken, and a side of string beans. The chicken wasn't amazing, but it was good. Definitely get the string beans.

We also had a pot of green tea which set the mood.

Loved this whole experience!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Made a reservation on Thursday night and I glad I did - the restaurant was full of people.

Peking duck: since the availability is limited, we called and reserved one duck. However it was a big disappointment. The duck was quite bitter, and the meat was just okay. Definitely not coming back for the duck.

XLB: surprisingly good! The meat is so juicy. I prefer this over ding tai fung's. Also you would get a 50% off by checking in at yelp.

Eggplant: taste good! So flavorful and not oily at all.

Kung fu tea: I'm giving it a 5 stars. By ordering a pot ($8), a master will perform some kung fung when filling hot water in the tea pot. Also the pot can be refilled. The tea tastes good too. 

Overall I will come back for the xlb and tea, but definitely not the duck.
author: Yuen Yung L.

description:
4/14/18

There are good Chinese restaurants, GREAT Chinese restaurants, and TRANSCENDENT Chinese restaurants, (among all the weeds.)  My gf's a treasure hunter, and food is her prize.  We heard among our friends, friends of friends, wanna be's on the net, fellow chefs-in-training, and even the birds singing into the sky, that there's this restaurant that would be TRANSCENDENT...

From the owner of Z&Y, (or is it Z&X... X&Y... hmmmmmm.)... well, THAT one that US Presidents like to visit when in SF, that person also opened this Chili House & Peking Duck.  The bar's high.  The heavens aren't much higher.  Was this Chili House a success?

..... first, before I begin, I just want to say that despite the heavy tailoring towards non-Chinese ethnicities, and despite the very mixed cultural makeup of the patrons, despite your initial assumptions and stereotypes, this would be a Full Fledged Yellow-Blooded True Chinese restaurant.  So...

...for those that aren't Chinese, you might have heard snippets here and there about Chinese table manners--don't point your chopsticks at people, don't stab your chopsticks into the rice, pour tea for everyone first even if they're too far to reach, elders first, etc.; BUT, I tell you, one thing that definitely will piss off all Chinese patrons would be ordering FRIED RICE, ORANGE CHICKEN, and CHOW MEIN.

We looked to our side and there was a table of 10, all non-Chinese.  All were happy and smiling--awesome.  Then we saw on their lazy-susan an array of fried rice, orange fried chicken and chow mein.  Basically Panda Express served fancy.  The selection was striking, being the largest table, and surround by dozens of tables topped with steaming clay pots, and big bowls topped with thick red oil.

Just don't okay?

Alright: dungeon level hardcore or not???...

1. Peking Duck $43.95 "served with roasted duck, pancakes, green onion, cucumber, and paste.  add $3 for extra green onion, cucumber and paste; add $5 for extra pancakes":  "Peking Duck" is actually part of the restaurant name.  So, better be beyond heavenly good right?  Well, sorry to say, you know what's coming--it SUCKED.  Like, not inedible terrible--ironically I only had that bad of Peking Duck once, and it was in Beijing (Mandarin spelling of the Cantonese word "Peking" if you didn't know).  But other than that one duck, this was the next worst.  The skin was at times hard, and other times just uninspiring (as opposed to the epic buttery crunch awesomeness of the best), and the flesh was actually pretty dry.

To make it even worse, they're REALLY stingy with those pancakes, giving you only about 8, which totally is not even close to enough, and have the balls to charge $5 if you want more.  I would say taste-wise this duck is 3/10. but the price and balls, and even being the restaurant name..... 2/10

2. Pickled Veg & Fish Clay Pot $18 "fish fillet boiled in our traditional Szechuan pickled mustard broth with tofu":  Ahhhh.... NOW we're talking.  DELICIOUS fish broth, topped with pickled goodness, and tender fillets of fish.  This you want.  10/10

3. Xinjiang Grilled Lamb Chops $16.95:  These are lamb ribs basically, missing much of the expensive steak meat.  Which is fine, as I like ribs.  The odd thing was out of the 5 pieces, each one was a different shape and size.  Flavoring to me was good, but my gf wasn't impressed though--but she grew up in Xinjiang, so who knows what she's thinking.  Pretty juicy and tender.  I should note, this was our friend's favorite of the night, a White girl with us.  7/10

4. Bean Jello in Red Chili Sauce:  Apparently a cousin to my gf's favorite dish of all time--Liang Pi.  Served the same way--thick and delicious red oil sauce, some cucumber, and other mystery tidbits.  The only difference being the noodles, which according to my gf is made from the starch of a different plant, which makes for a more "Jell-O" like consistency, instead of being chewy like Liang Pi.  It's a bit hard to eat with chopsticks though, since the noodles are brittle and break.  Glad I got to try this though since I've never seen it at another restaurant.  9/10

5. Chinese Cabbage with Chili Pepper $10.95:  Sigh... I write too much.  Out of space... so, it was great.  8/10

............. okay, I didn't talk about the other unique thing of this place: the entertainment.  Yes, there's entertainment!  Want a Kung-fu tea service with a long sword-like tea pot?  How 'bout a very traditional multi-face Chinese opera'ish dance to watch while you eat?  (Gf says it's actually a special trade in China--only passed through apprenticeship, after bowing to master's and showing your deep respect to those who might teach you.)  Personally all I could think was somehow Jaqen H'ghar, the Faceless Man, figured he needed some money and started working here in SF...

....alas... it was not transcendent.  Too much hype.  But definitely a unique and authentic Szechuan restaurant.

4/5

#szechuan #sichuan #star #sanfrancisco
author: Dean C.

description:
I liked their dishes made of flour. They tasted wonderful. I will come And to order them again.
The cucumber appetizer was a disappointment. The cucumber was not crunchy and not chilled. Another disappointment was the lamb chops. 70% of this dish were bones.
Waiters were very friendly and made you felt welcomed. And we went on the right night to see a special performance there. I do not get this kind of thing often.
They have several well known dishes advertised on media and requires 24 hours order in advance. Make sure you check their menu online first.
author: Marian K.

description: If you want bland, flavorless, and super oily dishes, then this is the spot for you. Everything here was super greasy and bland, did I mention... it's also on the pricier side. I wouldn't mind paying for it if it actually tasted good, but I left this restaurant with a heartburn. I would not come back until they decide to make their dishes less oily and actually taste better.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I stumbled upon this while walking around the Richmond area, what a great find! If you don't have reservations, it might be a 30-minute wait, but they take reservations for parties of any size. So make sure you get on the list through yelp or simply by calling.

Their Peking Duck here is quite authentic and they will either make a soup for you with the left over bone and meat or a stir fry. The portion for the duck is pretty large, so I would recommend ordering this for a 4-person group. I also enjoyed the other dishes they have: cauliflower + pork in a sizzling pot, spicy fish fillet, etc. Things are a bit pricy here, but the experience is up to par.

Also pro tip: they have special Chinese performances on Saturday night :)
author: Angel C.

description:
I give this place a two, mainly because it is disorganized in terms of service.  No one seems to know what they are doing.  They can't seem to turn around orders in any kind of reasonable fashion.  It's unfortunate because the food seemed tasty and would have been great if served on time and hot.  The presentation is also quite pleasing.    

I ate at this place when it first opened and it was excellent all around, but how quickly things change.  I predict that this place is not long for the world.  

This time the problems began right away.  It took ages just to place an order.  Once the order was in, the noodles arrived quickly and we polished them off just as quickly.  We waited another fifteen minutes for the dumplings before they arrived, and they were luke-warm (I assume because they had been sitting on the counter and no server thought fit to bring them). After sitting another fifteen minutes, we had to push the waitress, telling her we were pressed for time and that we were still waiting for our appetizer!  It arrived quickly, but was cold through and through. 

The flavors were good, but the prep/serve times etc were ridiculous.  Don't know who is to blame, but whoever is running the kitchen should be fired (drawn and quartered) and someone who knows their stuff hired.  Or else a new wait staff needs to be hired.  Bad management.  Will probably not give this place a second chance.  Your best bet, if you live in the SF area, would be to order take-out.  Don't bother stopping by unless you have a big group and can afford to sit around half the day drinking beer, or something else to kill the time.
author: Jaime C.

description:
Came here on a weekend and it was packed. It's best to make reservation beforehand. We pre ordered the Peking duck and had great expectations. To our surprise, it wasn't all that good. I expected to be juicy packed with flavors. It was pretty bland and they wanted you to complement with their sauce. I like the wrapper being thin and that's the authentic way.

So why give it a 4 stars? All the other side dishes/appetizers were surprisingly delicious. It was flavorful and reasonably priced. I find the beef roll to be my favorite because it was juicy and pan fried to its perfection. Yum yum
author: BT B.

description:
I usually come here for lunch it's good when you have people to share .


Schezuan cold noodles are great , I try not to mix it too well because then the spicy oil   over powers the whole dish 
Beijing pot stickers are good!
Dan dan mein ok
Peking duck good !
Pea sprouts are good !
Pig ears are excellent
Xlb are done right here
And the guy with the tea is awesome.

Servers are busy but are pretty good
author: DOM d.

description:
This is a combo Sichuan and Beijing restaurant in the Richmond district.  The Sichuan food was pretty tasty but pretty standard for the good Sichuan restaurants in San Francisco.  Get the usual - cummin lamb, mapo dofu, fish in chili soup.

This restaurant knows how to create theatrical experiences that play well with the non mainland crowd.  During the night, there was a masked Chinese dancer who did a fun routine to punchy Chinese music.  It was nice although food service stopped and it would have been nice to have to wait less.  They also have a server who provides the hot water for the tea in one of those long necked pots that looked nice but was pretty unnecessary.

I would have like this place better if I didn't have to wait in line 90 minutes
author: Mark C.

description: 3.5 stars. Boosted up for very good service. The Peking duck ( we reserved it incase they ran out) was gamey and plain. I'd pass on that dish. Service was 5 stars, especially for a Chinese restaurant. We had a pork belly dish which was just okay. There were a few dishes we all enjoyed. The tan tan noodles, Shanghai dumplings and the explosive chicken dish are highly recommended. The tan tan noodles are a little spicy, very flavorful. The Shanghai dumplings are soupy! The explosive chicken reminds me of waffles for some reason. Will be back for those dishes!
author: Dawn N.

description: Urgh! We went here based on reviews for my moms birthday dinner. Unfortunately the food including the Peking duck didn't taste good enough for the expectations :(
author: Alice C.

description:
One of our local favs. We usually get here right around 5:00 pm for dinner and avoid any wait. We like the menu here as it is not yet another Hong Kong regional selection. From good variety of northern Chinese style dumplings, green onion pancakes, etc which is less common and a nice change of pace from most Chinese restaurants in the area or any area really. If you're looking for typical Chinese fare, the chow mein and fried rice are good, but nothing stellar. The only disappointing dish we had so far was the Kung Pow Chicken, which was surprisingly under whelming.

We come here for the northernly regional Chinese style specialties. On that we give this place our 4 stars.
author: Patrick M.

description:
Just an honest review: The food is not the best compared to other szechuan style restaurants in San Francisco. We came on a Saturday night and at 8pm they have the mask changing show. It was really entertaining! Do you know what's not entertaining?

The MSG filled dishes and above average prices. $20ish for a $10 dish? For 2 person, you'll probably end up spending $60+. It's a good spot to take tourists or visiting families, however please skip if you are looking for some authentic Chinese food that is not drenched in MSG, salt, and oil.
author: Fei S.

description: Staff on point, very fast friendly service. I just pulled them up on Yelp and on October 9 they started they were rated POOR by the city  (bottom 5% ) we ordered the chilli crunchy chicken...spicy and good...eggplant yummy...twice cooked pork horrible bland night flavor. We eat Canton , Beijing, Shanghainese so we know our food. I was expecting more flavor. But overall it was good and I would go back.
author: Casandra R.

description:
This is my husband's ex-COO's favorite Chinese restaurant in SF. His ex-COO has left the company for over a year so yes, it took a long time for us to come here!

We came on Saturday night at 5:45pm and finished dinner at 7:00pm. We waited about 5 minutes to get seated. A long line started to form at 6:00pm so we just beat the rush. Overall a great experience and we will be back! I want to try the other dishes!

FOOD
Cucumber chili fish- lots of peppercorns and a slow burn which I like. Fish tasted a little fishy (in a good way!) and I feel my mouth salivating now as I'm reminiscing.
Bitter melon slices with honey- served over ice and very refreshing and the bitter melon was not unbearably bitter. Perfect amount of honey, not too sweet. 
Beijing potstickers- super juicy meat inside and delicious with a little chili oil. Looks like rectangular spring rolls, not the common Dumpling look a like. 
Chicken ginseng soup- small order was pretty large and we had to pack the rest to go. Good flavor

SERVICE
Great! The waitress came over to take out order shortly but we weren't even ready haha. Then a waiter came back. Both were friendly and spoke both English and Mandarin. Food came out at a good pace. Saw other tables who ordered duck had a waiter served the duck from the side of the table- table service!

DECOR/AMBIANCE
Decorated with Chinese calligraphy/words on walls and posters of mouthwatering dishes (terrible if you're waiting for a table and starving.. you will become hangry). Tables, chairs, plates and utensils appear clean. Noise level is of average Chinese restaurant.
author: Iris H.

description: Loved dining at this restaurant! The dan dan noodles were insanely good. We also ordered the crab (cooked in a spicy/chili sauce as opposed to the ginger scallion version), some pan-fried buns, mixed veggies, Chinese preserved meat + cauliflower, and beef and tripe in chili oil 夫妻肺片, as well as the Peking Duck which is served table side and comes with a soup made with the bones of the duck.
author: Weich Y.

description:
Love love LOVE! Everything from service to flavor. Nothing is actually "spicy" so no fret you non-pepper tolerant folks, you can eat here too. Their chili oil is like no other! Service is always pleasant, however I have been coming here for over 8years. Never disappoint. My favorites are;
Explosive chicken, basil eggplant (we order it fried), hot n' sour soup, beef pancake, scallion pancake, and those cold peanut noodles (I don't eat it, I'm allergic, but my friend orders it ALL the time). We get water, bottle of wine, AND tea. I'm a bit of a wine snob and their Riesling is great; not sweet like typical Riesling wines. Love this spot. Give it a go! Xièxiè
author: Robbin R.

description:
I know this place was well known for their peking duck as suggested by Facebook so I thought maybe I'd pop in there to try for a late lunch. Brought my sister along and I hyped her up about it too. It was a weekday afternoon around 2 pm when we went. Nope. Apparently I gotta call ahead to make a reservation for them to make it. It's at least a 24 hr process. 

Well ok. I wanna give it a chance anyway. We were sat down. There was 2 other tables being served with 2 waitstaff. They were talking loudly in mandarin and was being brought dishes and additional request by the staff. The staff ignored me and my sister. I figured we would get better service too if we spoke in mandarin. But all the times we call the waiter to come and get our order and even some tea or water was met with a dismissive hand wave. Until one table was done and they were removing the dirty plates did we finally get to put in our order. Holy cow. Why did this take that long? Was the waitstaff also the chef that they can't take our orders at the same time ???

As for the food we ordered a Szechuan tan tan noodle dish and their most famous princess chicken wing dish.  As per advert on Facebook we also checked in to get 50% off on xiaolongbao. 

We waited a long time before getting waited on and we waited even more before Food actually started coming. By then we were pissed and hungry. It was almost about an hour later when we started getting some food. Food also didn't come in the normal appetizer then main dish order. We were given the appetizers last. What in the world is the kitchen doing ?

The noodle dish was good but oily. There was so much oil that I could scoop with a spoon. It was way too salty. We finished this dish. And then we waited. And waited. And finally the appetizers came. 

Princess chicken wings was super sweet. It's like friend chicken with a thick sugar crust on it. It's like sticky candies chicken. 

And the xiaolongbao was tough and leaky. There were already holes in it. 

Overall the food and services here is bad. Don't believe everything they hype up on Facebook.
author: Rose Z.

description:
Pro-tip: ask for the Peking Duck bones in a plastic bag to make pho broth yourself when you go home instead of just getting the bones in a soup or something in the restaurant. The dick itself was okay and they could have cut it in more pieces for us but that's why we asked for the rest of the duck togo to make the most of our buck. (But srsly, the broth we made with the duck was so good) Come here on the weekends for dinner and get a dance show! Also if you order tea, you can watch them pour it just like a fancy restaurant in China haha, my brother got scared tbh though. 

GET THEIR SPICY WONTONS 10/10 would get again
author: Mora O.

description:
The food was fine - not the best Peking Duck I've had, but not the worst either. Likewise for most other dishes. E.g. mapo dofu was meh - I had better at yuppie Mission Chinese the previous night. I did like the scallion pancakes, and the fish in a big bowl of red chilis.

However, prices are on the high side. They charge you for the tea like many Chinese restaurants ($8/pot!), and on the back end they tack on their service charge like a white restaurant, while providing neither the typically free Chinese soupy dessert, not a fortune cookie. 

But by far the worst of all, and what makes this a "never return" destination for me, is the volume. Too loud to hear yourself (85 dB) all throughout dinner. And that's before the 10+ minute entertainment that exceeded 100 dB! (Yes, there's an app for that.) 

That's craziness. I go out to enjoy a meal in the company of friends - and to talk to said friends - not to permanently damage my hearing. 

I wouldn't return if this were the best food in the world. Which it is not.
author: Michael J.

description: Great food great place in SF. If you like authentic Peking duck this is the place to go! They even have a tea pouring snow!
author: Sebastian L.

description:
I came here for a birthday and apparently they are known for their peking duck. They carve the bird table-side and it is pretty good.

XLB was okay. a little mushy and overcooked and most of the dumplings were already popped for some reason.

Service could use a lot more work. It was a Saturday afternoon and not that packed to be honest but they took forever to take away finished dishes to make room for additional plates. not that they were quick to get dishes to the tabes to begin with...
author: Anh T.

description:
We came here to try the Peking duck. Honestly, it was whatever. Nothing special. The duck was really lacking in flavor and I guess you're suppose to dip it in the sauces. But I don't like the sauce and didn't dip. After they slice off the meat of the duck, they ask you how you want to prepare the bones. Fried or in soup. We asked for it to be fried. Oh boy, that was bad. Dried up bones with no flavor what so ever. 

For the price of $44 for the duck, you're better off going to any other place for Peking duck. The only thing special about it was that they "prepare" it in front of you. By preparing, it's just slicing the duck. I can care less. Just give me the meats when it's ready to be eaten please.

Besides the duck, we also ordered the tan tan noodles and the Xiao lung bao. The tan tan noodles were like mala noodles. I'm not a fan of mala so I didn't like that. The noodle texture was good though. The xiao lung bao was half off with Yelp check in and that was surprisingly pretty good. The skin was a little thick but it was still pretty good. 

Overall, if you're here for the duck, I'd say you're better off somewhere else that's cheaper.
author: Celia D.

description:
Come here for the duck, salt egg pumpkin, sour fish soup and magical surprise that only occur on Saturdays at 7pm.  Make reservations and don't be mad if they're busy because guess what....THEY'RE BUSY.  Love hearing people complain while they wait.  If you see a shit ton of people crowding by the door and even outside, don't expect to wait 30 min and be able to eat...have some common sense and be mad at yourself and not the restaurant for being busy.

Make reservations as early as you can and if you can't make a reservation wait until you can.

ps. No need to get the soup dumpling or Beijing fried dumpling - those 2 are just mediocre.
author: Vince L.

description:
I booked a table here for Chinese New Years because it looks like they have pretty good Peking duck. I was actually not impressed but the duck because it was a bit gamey and dry. They also didn't do the pancakes that wrap the duck, either. 

We also ordered the fish with dipping pancakes, which I didn't like. I was told it was sweet and sour but it wasn't what I expected. We got the egg yoke batter shrimp and the special crab with tons of fried garlic. Those two dishes were the standouts. The crab was around $50 so I was glad that it was worth it. The shrimp was so flavorful and the fried pieces of pumpkin were great. 

We also ordered the dan dan noodles, two orders of the soup dumplings, two orders of the shao mai, the beef pancakes, scallion pancakes and vegetable dumplings. These dishes all turned out tasty, especially the xlb, which was juicy and tender and thin skinned. 

We also ordered chicken chao mien, garlic peashoots and garlic sauce eggplants. They were also good. 

I was surprised that we didn't get any freebie desserts after ordering so much food but I guess they were super busy and wanted the turn the tables ASAP. It was a bit hectic, with people waiting crowding our table. The service was ok, they seemed a bit under staffed. 

All in all, the food was above average and considering how busy it was, they did a good job and my parents were happy with the meal.
author: Alice W.

description: Food was excellent, the duck was out of the world cool and an experience I've been wanting and the tea poring was a fun experience would definitely recommend it if you're coming here!
author: Allen B.

description:
Wonderful peeking duck. The food is great, prices are reasonable (and the 20% Amex discount you get via Groupon is nice too.) 

The only negative thing to say is that basically they ignore reservations.

At the host stand, they have a signup list. Having a reservation helps in your haggling with the hostess to get a table, but a 7:00 res definitely does not mean you're getting a 7PM table.

Otherwise pleasant experience.
author: Samuel S.

description:
THE BEST CHINESE RESTAURANT IN SAN FRAN!!! 
This place is my family's must-go everytime we stop by San Fran. We have invited friends from China to here as well. And it never lets us down!!

My recommend dishes are the red chili chicken(辣子鸡), roast Peking duck, and 椒麻肥牛
author: Yuxin F.

description:
Let me start by saying, what kind of name is "Chili House SF"?  It reminds me of a fast food Mexican restaurant.  Wasn't there a popular chain called Chili's before?  

My family and I came to this restaurant after my father saw a commercial advertising that this restaurant had a chef straight from Peking, China cook for you.  When we came, I asked.  The chef is from Peking, but most of the other chefs are from Szechuan.  So food should mostly be Szechuan.  Customers were a mix group of outsiders(nonAsian) or Asians that are willing to come here for just the presentation and not the food.

Each dish took at least 30 minutes to wait.

We ordered the Hot Sour Soup.  Tasted like soy sauce and just powdered pepper.  The soup was black and the tofu was hard.  It had no contrast of Hot and Sour and barely had any ingredients inside.  We complained to the waiter that it was nasty tasting.  He was reluctant to do anything. We asked to exchange it.  He did, but then came back and told us that we didn't know how to order food.  That we ordered too little and that we shouldn't eat here if we didn't know what food tasted like!!

I was so insulted.  By the way,  he wears glasses and is stocky build.  Avoid him at all cost if you can, he has an attitude.  But he will serve you well if you are nonAsian.
I would have left, but my dad assisted on staying for the rest of our meal.

We exchanged the Hot Sour Soup for Egg Flower Soup.  We waited and waited, finished our other food before the soup arrived.  It had absolutely no taste.  Too much meat.

Now I"m not picky at all for food.  I would eat just about any Asian food because I am Asian, but gosh did it not have any taste.  It was like drinking water and they just threw meat into the bowl!

Overall, the dishes were small and tasteless; expensively targeted for those who want to throw their money away and don't know what Asian food taste like.  They tailor to the tasteless.  You have to order a lot for them to give you a lot.  

The Peking Duck is $40.00 here.  There are better, cheaper places for Peking duck. Folks, just because the chef is from Peking doesn't mean you are getting the exquisite, authentic food directly from China.  You are being pulled for your money for food you think is Chinese.

We had ordered the Fried Rice, but they never placed the order and so we just asked for the check.

We noticed they charged for the Hot Sour Soup and were not only careless in removing this off the bill (or at least giving us half price off), but were going to charge us for 2 soups!
Very careless!

Bottom Line: This restaurant caters to those who have never ate Peking Duck before and charge you sky high prices.  They make most of their business off of this dish and this dish alone.
author: K G.

description:
1. Make a reservation or prepare to wait

2. Beijing duck was decent. Not the best because it was not as juicy and tender as the other ducks that I had, but decent compared to other places in SF that serve Beijing duck.

3. The Couple's Delight (spicy beef tendon) has more of the numbing taste and not as spicy as the authentic dish.

The eggplant with basil sauce was delicious; it had the right amount of sauce that didn't drown the eggplant.

Honey walnut fried prawns was good: crispy batter with tender prawn inside; the batter was a bit thick though.

Xiao Long Bao was okay. The stuffing could be tastier. It was a bit bland compared to their other dishes with big bold flavors.
author: Eileen H.

description:
Had to wait 45 mins in line for our party of 6, but the food was delicious and sommelier in a great mood (or felt bad that we waited so long), comped us a sautern and free 酒酿汤圆 dessert. Visited us frequently during the meal and talked to us at length about pairing European wines with Chinese food.


---- APPETISERS ----

夫妻片: 3 stars
Cold dishes are not really our thing so hard to judge.

蜂蜜涼瓜: 4 stars
Bitter melon with honey, refreshing with all the spicy dishes.

红油抄手: 5 stars
Perfect thick-wrapper dumplings in Sichuan peppercorn chili oil.

三鲜水角: 4 stars
Non-spicy version of above.

酸豇豆: 5 stars
Tangy vinegary super unique flavour. Minced pork

Dan Dan Noodles 担担面: 5 stars
Possibly the best dan dan mian I have had in the Bay area, after living here for 10 years.

Scallion Pancake 葱油饼: 2 stars
Don't bother.


---- MAINS ----

沸腾鱼: 4.5 stars
Super tender fish fillets

Cumin Beef: 5 stars

Peking Duck 北京鸭: 5 stars
Whole crispy duck wraps. Also came with a huge tureen of refreshing, comforting duck soup cooked from the carcass. All for about $35 total. Compared to the $60 half duck from Mister Jiu's that was overcooked... *shakes head*

Spicy Chicken Soup: 4 stars


---- DESSERTS ----

南瓜饼: 5 stars

酒酿汤圆: 4.5 stars
Black sesame filling Tāng yúan
author: Letitia L.

description: Was excited to try Xiao Long Bao (Soup dumplings) but it was okay, the bao was too thick, I've had better elsewhere. Peking duck was sliced in front of us. Some of the duck meat were used for soup. Xiu Mai was the worst I've ever had, it tastes nothing like it! ait was like a duplicate of Xiao Long Bao. Bittermelon when honey was pretty weird because it was cold for being served on ice and honey being spreaded on it. Disappointed.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Don't come here on a weekend night if you're hungry. On top of a long wait for a table, everything comes to a halt for a "magic mask" performance a la Peking Opera accompanied by blaring loud music that lasts for what seems like forever, especially when you just want a table and a meal. The least they could do is warn you that your wait will be doubled by this amateur hour show 

Got a comment from someone representing the place, but no way to reply. So I'll respond here. They said "It's a traditional performance" (duh) and many customers like it. (OK).  But SERIOUSLY when the line is out the door?  It's stupid to do it when they are so busy. And it's absurdly rude not to warn people who are getting on the waitlist that their wait is going to double or more because of it.
author: Timothy M.

description:
We love Peking Duck from Chili House.  Its beautifully carved and presented to your table.
The place is small so try not to go during the peak hours. 
I try a new dish with every visit. 
So far the favorite is Peking Duck which they are famous for.  Next is the spicy szechuan beef/ chicken. 
The sesame pancake is a delightful appetizer. Don't forget the xioa long bao. Finish with House Chow Mein...
I enjoy their floral teas as well.. i haven't had the chance to watch the tea pouring demo yet... 
I am trying the lamb dish next..
author: Nelle L.

description:
My wife and I love Pecking Duck and were looking to satisfy our craving this Memorial Day weekend. Parking was easy, there is plenty of street parking and there are a few public lots with available spots (even on Memorial Day).

We didn't have reservations and waited about 30 minutes for a 2-person table. I do recommend you make a reservation, the length of the line fluctuates a bit and a 1-hour wait time is very possible.

Sadly we found out the menu says a reservation is required for the Peking Duck (website doesn't mention!) but we were able to order it anyhow and needed to wait ~30 minutes for them to get it ready. We were happy to wait and less than 30 minutes later a chef came out and cut the duck in front of us!

The waiter will ask you how you want the duck's bones prepared: either in a soup or garlic fried. The duck comes with small pancakes, scallions, cucumber and prune sauce. 

A whole Pecking Duck is $39 and is enough to serve 2 people (if you don't order appetizers). Some reviewers say the duck isn't perfectly authentic and having had it in Beijing several times I have to agree however I did find it extremely good. Ive had Peking Duck hundreds of times across the US and this is the best Ive had so far.
author: Thomas L.

description: Big time service was Peking duck was awesome soup dumplings and spicy dumplings fresh and tasty when you get the Peking duck ask for the duck soup option very fun time all good
author: Joseph R.

description:
After transferring some chowmein to our dishes from serving plate, my dining companions commented that noodles were not hot.  I asked server to have the kitchen redo it but all he did was have them stir fry what was left on serving plate rather than redoing the dish.  Remainder of noodles came back super oily.  Waiter should have had kitchen redo the entire dish and serve it piping hot. 

After visiting the bathroom, I would never go back to this restaurant. No pride.
author: blaine s.

description:
Honestly, the Richmond district has got some of the best Sichuan restaurants in the city. Maybe even the bay. And this spot is definitely up there on that scale of my go-to Sichuan spots. 

Been coming here on and off over the years...not bc I don't like it, but bc their portions are so huge, it really becomes an event whenever I come in. 

It cracks me up every time I read other reviews about how shitty service is at Chinese restaurants. Everyone, let's just be real with one another, these Chinese restaurants really dgaf about service. So if you can get past that, the food here is pretty legit. 

My typical order here usually consists of: chives and flounder dumplings (so good), salty egg yolk pumpkin (GET THIS), fresh fish in boiling chili soup (not crazy spicy, unless you want it to be), and chives pancakes (favvv). IMO the chives pancake is better than the green onion pancake, but my fam always forgets and gets the wrong one. The green onion pancake here just isn't crispy enough...a little doughy looking! 

During my dinner today, the wait staff was much better than usual. I only had to wave them down once! Haha. The food is still as good as I remembered. The fish in the chili soup was really fresh. The salty egg yolk pumpkin situation...honestly A+! No lie. 

Parking is shitty, but that's all of Clement. Actually, all of Richmond district is. Sooo unless you're willing to commit to finding parking, possibly a little bit of a wait, and probably spotty service, then this probably isn't the right place for you. BUT if you're looking for some legit Sichuan food in the Richmond area, Chili House is a pretty damn good choice. 

4 stars!
author: Jennifer L.

description: There was some really good Xiao long bao. Very fresh and juicy. I liked it alot. The only thing I got to gripe is the wait. And attitude about my take out order.bi told the girl I order over phone. And she act like she didn't know there was an order of Xiao long bao and beef pancake. I told her when I got there
author: Selby C.

description:
I was recommended here, and the first time I was here it was absolutely fantastic the duck was one of the best I've ever had, Super Fresh super juicy nothing bad could ever be said of it.  They cut the duck right at the table and then hand folded into fantastic little envelopes to be eaten right in front of us
It was five star only because there was nothing higher

Unfortunately because it was so profound the good I had decided to bring my family.  Weirdly this practically a different restaurant at at this point.

The food was dry it lacked seasoning even the wait staff irritated

It went from a place I couldn't wait to go back to, to a place where all we did was botch about

I was profoundly disappointed

I don't know if I'll return an experiment again
author: John L.

description:
This place has a great show, and that show is called their Peking Duck, which reminded me of when I was in China and saw the same show.

But this is definitely, cheaper than the plane fare it takes to travel across the country.

Absolutely loved their seafood pot and the service from Norman who was quite frankly the best waiter I've ever had around that area, hence the 30% tip.

The Peking Duck needed an hour in advance to prepare, and I think they run out quickly since most people come for that and they said by 8pm they run out some times.

So come quickly to get your duck, sliced right at your table, with some flare.

I love their xiao long baos, which had great flavor to them and the fresh ginger gave it that nice kick.

And back to that rocking seafood pot, filled with fresh shrimp (heads on), fresh clams, a great soup broth, and fresh fish. I was loving this seafood bowl, and hogged it all until the duck came.

The duck comes with your choice of duck soup, which comes from the leftover bones, and I think is a must have with the cabbage they add. It was refreshingly good, and the 4 of us couldn't get enough of that soup.

I have to admit if I ever had a birthday party where I wanted to show off some Peking Duck, or just wanted to throw a party just for the fun of being alive and blessed to be living in San Francisco, I would book my party here.
author: Jack R.

description:
My aunt took me here because apparently the chef has cooked for 2 Chinese presidents and we wanted to give the Peking duck a try. Make sure to reserve that ahead of time for the duck as well as for their dessert platter (which we missed out on). Also, if you get their tea, they serve it in traditional Beijing style and it's quite the show! Most definitely a nice touch that we weren't expecting. 

- Peking Duck
Phenomenal. The skin was crispy, the meat was juicy, the skin was thin, and the sauce alongside the green onion and cucumber were the perfect complement. It was also great to see them carve the whole duck next to us. 

- Beijing Bean Sauced Noodle
I've had better. We all agreed that we could've used more sauce and it leaned more on the slightly bland side. However, the noodles were nice and chewy and we were informed it was made in house.

- Green Onion Pancakes
Wonderful. If you add a bit of chili oil to it, it added a nice touch to the pancake. 

- Stir Fried Crab
The crab was deep fried and prepared spectacularly. The meat was still tender and moist. However, I wouldn't say it was a special or memorable dish.

- Pork Intestine with Blood and Tofu
AMAZING. Our favorite dish of the night by far. This is a hard dish to find in the US and even harder to find a place that prepares it well. The flavors were superb, spicy enough to have that numbing feeling but not too spicy that we couldn't taste the other flavors. Would recommend that anyone who visits this restaurant get this dish!

Overall, we had great service and great food. Lovely experience and would definitely come back again.
author: Veronica S.

description: 3.5 star. Love coming here for their Peking duck but this time around it was dry with no flavor. I guess hit or miss on the duck. I still enjoy the chef cutting it in front of you. I usually come here only for their Peking duck and their other dishes was just ok. Today I tried two new dishes. Their beef roll and tan tan noodles. The tan tan flavor is actually really good but they need to work on their noodle. The beef roll is ok nothing wow same with XLB. Oh their service was really good. The young kid waiter was awesome. Overall 3.5 star. If they can be more consistent on their Peking duck flavor and work on more chewy noodles in the tan tan sauce than I can move into their restaurant lol. Hopefully next visit will be better.
author: Christy V.

description:
We came here on a Thursday night at 730pm and the place was packed. The wait was about 30 minutes and I was pretty confused as to how to snag a table here. There was a wait list to write your name down, but then also you could make reservations on Yelp for a table. Some people that walked in after us were seated before us. I highly recommend making reservations before coming here.

We already knew what we wanted to order so immediately after being seated we placed our order. The food was brought out so quickly (within 5-10 minutes). I was definitely impressed. The food was on point as well. My favorite was the poached beef. Wow. So tender and had some good heat to it. The green beans were also delicious. We appreciated the nice discount the restaurant offers on the steamed dumplings with Yelp check in.

We also tried the tan tan noodles. I didn't think they were such a big deal though. They lacked flavor and there was very little meat.

My parents thought the food was overly spicy and salty but the rest of us thought the food was  perfect for szechuan cuisine. I was definitely thirsty after leaving the restaurant though.

Overall I'd definitely come back here again, especially for the poached beef.
author: Janet E.

description: We came here on Mother's Day lunch time. Food quality over all its great. Beijing Duck was only ok and not too impressive. Fish Udon noodle, pork jelly and Beijing snack are really special here. Paper chicken it's also really yummy as well.
author: Jenny C.

description:
GLASS IN FOOD! ..and they don't care.

I picked up takeout and discovered a half inch piece of glass in the string beans when I got home. I immediately called them. They told me there was no manager that could talk to me right then but that they would give me a refund but I had to come back in. I asked if they could just do it over the phone, but they insisted that I come in. I told him what time I would come by the next day and he said he wouldn't be there, so he gave me the name of the manager and said to ask for her and he would tell her about it. 

I came in the next day at the stated time and the manager was not there. The waitress called her and she spoke with me, and said that she knew about the situation and she would issue a refund and to give the phone back to the waitress. The waitress spoke to her for a moment and then hung up and asked me for my credit card information. She took down my card number, name, and CSV code... Which I didn't really want to leave with her. She insisted that she couldn't process the return while I was standing there and that the manager would have to do it when she got back. I asked why I couldn't have given this information over the phone... I was told that I had specifically needed to come in even though I live 30 min away. But she said all she could do was take the credit card information and that the manager would definitely issue the return later in the day. 

No return was ever issued. The manager never apologized. They seemed completely unconcerned that I could've swallowed glass. Terrible and Terrible service besides!
author: CityPixie Q.

description: This place is the absolute best and I go every week. I always get the spicy cold noodles!
author: Lisa Q.

description: Update: gave this place raving reviews and recommend it to all friends and family for multiple years. Have been coming here as a neighbor since they open their doors. This was the first time where I'm hosting family from out of town and the front of the house made us wait 45min than crossed us off and gave our spot to someone else despite my continuous check-in every 5-10min. Very unfortunate experience and nearly ruined our night, but completely unnecessary and avoidable. Hostess completely avoided communicating with me in English, but couldn't stop chatting with other guests in Mandarin. Definitely made me feel like this situation done on purpose. I guess they have no place for their neighbors anymore.
author: Eduardo S.

description: Is this in some tourist guidebook somewhere?? It's crazy busy, even at 2pm for lunch so be prepared to wait. You have to flag people down and remind them at least twice for what you need. Loved the flaming oil, skip the dry tea leave duck and I've definitely had better "explosive chicken" elsewhere. Drink plenty of water! Bottom line, I'd still rather go to China North on Noriega.
author: Cathrin P C.

description:
Amazing food here and the service was great too. Ate the Peking Duck which was very well done. Then we ordered the tan tan noodles which again was great so was the chicken with explosive pepper. We also did eggplant in spicy garlic sauce and egg fried rice. I would highly recommend this place to anyone that likes spicy food. 

5 stars for food
5 stars for the service as all the servers are extremely nice and friendly. 

We will return often.
author: Rohan D.

description: This is wonderful restaurant, tea . Duck omg it's so yummy. The service is five stars. . I like it .
author: Fiona H.

description:
Good Food,  portions a tad shy, but good lunch specials.
Me and my partner each had a special and split and order of soup dumplings.   
I may just go back for the dumplings alone.
author: John W.

description:
The vibe of this place is p cool. There's a face swapping performance around 7 pm and kung fu tea ($8) where this guy walks around w a tea pot w a long ass spout and pours your tea for you lol so that was cool and unique and all -- 5/5 for that 

The restaurant was clean and you get the option of sharing tables w people, which is something that rarely happens here. It's nice cause either you meet new people or basically get seated faster (2 small parties sharing a larger table)

In terms of food tho, it was average. My throat hurt that day so didn't eat the spicy foods that my parents ate but they said it wasn't as spicy as other restaurants we normally eat at (so that can go both ways up to you to decide) and I ate pea sprouts and this lotus dish. They were good, but nothing super special about it. 

Tea as I mentioned above is only kung fu tea which is $8 so if you want the tea but not the show... too bad. We got water. (Honestly I was kinda scared of his pouring cause he wasn't SUPER good and ... imagine hot water shooting out at you eep!)

But yea, verdict: probs will take my out of town friends here but won't go back for the food specifically
author: Eva L.

description: The customer service at Chili House is wonderful.  People of all colors of all walks of life come here.  I do like their sour preserved veggie broth and their Xiao Long Bao.  It's too bad that their menu has the option for Pork wrapped in quesadilla style, but they really only serve beef.
author: Janet T.

description: Chilli House is one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the city. Be prepared to wait a while to be seated on weekends and some evenings, but it's well worth the wait. The atmosphere is loud, informal, and a great place to eat if you are dining with a big group.
author: Edith G.

description:
Got the peking duck, frog, xiao long bao, pork dumplings, fish fillet soup, and some vegetables. All the dishes were good to great, and service was well paced. The duck soup they made at the end with the duck bones was light and hearty, which contrasted well with the heavier dishes from earlier. 

Come here if you're looking for a high end Chinese restaurant that does it well.
author: Hans H.

description: I normally dont write a review but at the request of my mom am sharing that she would not recommend this place. SERVICE WAS HORRIBLE..I asked for ice water several times and never got it. Kept having to ask for teapot refills.  Peking duck was dry and not anything special. They charged for tea, for every take out container and bag without disclosing, which, for 15 almost 90 year old ladies, was not the right thing to do.
author: Loreen J.

description: Had lunch of peking duck, duck soup and chow mein.  The duck soup was good.  The chow mein and the peking duck were both okay.  We didn't find anything so special that would cause us to drive back to SF to eat here again. Just okay.
author: C B.

description: The Peking duck tastes just like we have it in China. The crispy duck skin is soooo my favorite, that in the end there are as expect some meat without skins leftover. Also the Tamtam noodle is tasty!
author: Lin Z.

description:
It was salty, over-priced and misrepresented.

We had a group of 10. They did not bring ala carte menus and insisted that we order from the banquet menus, which were much more expensive. We thought we would go for the feast. We were very disappointed. Every dish had so much salt that it was impossible to taste the other flavors. There was supposed to be a fresh fish, but they said they were out of fresh fish and were going to substitute a second Peking Duck. What? No, we didn't want a second duck. After more haggling, we got them to bring a catfish. Everyone got a tiny sample of the catfish. We also only got small samples of the Peking Pigeon, er, duck.

We paid three times what we would have paid had we ordered ala carte, and there was no single dish that stood out as particularly tasty - it was just boiled meat/chicken or ground mystery meat covered with sale, hot chili pepper, salt and more salt.

Perhaps I will return for individual dishes but not a banquet meal.
author: John B.

description: I love how you order the duck and it becomes an exhibition to being total care.  First they come up to the table and slice the duck in front of you.  You can ask them to take the duck carcass home or have it made into a soup or pepper and salt it in another dish.  Then the service person come and wrap your slice of duck into a pocket with such a thin skin crepe.  How do they make such a thin crepe.  The mysteries of culinary.   You wrap the rest of crepe yourself now that you know how to do it with a few pieces of green onion, a few sticks of cucumber,  and a smear of housemade hoisin sauce.  Voila,  deliciousness of duck crepe pocket.
author: Helen L.

description: $40 for a whole roast duck and duck soup!!! As a Chinese that has had Beijing Duck in China for so many times. This is a great place to have Peking Duck in Bay Area, good price, decent quality, nice customer service. Remember to make reservations for the duck.
author: Vega C.

description:
Ok I had to update my review and remove this bookmark. 

Since our last visit, their Dept of Health score has diminished worrisomely to 68/100. According to the Yelp WARNING, this now means that Chili House is at the BOTTOM 5% of all eating establishments in the City and County of San Francisco. 

Thanks. But no thanks. At least not til you improve your sanitary conditions. 

Absolutely not worth any health risks for myself nor my family. 

Meanwhile I'll be going literally right next door to Good Luck Dim Sum for my yum cha where they have a health score of 81/100.
author: Geminyna J.

description: Best Chinese on that stretch of Clement and it means a lot. Expect a line on the end of the week nights.  Dry string berms are especially delightful. Xioa long bao is excellent.
author: Vadim N.

description:
Service was fast even with super crowded area. Order Chicken Hot  was deliciously cooked but, extremely salty, had vinegar taste was different from other Chinese Foods but if it had less salt would had been better. Also tried their spicy eggplant vinegar like taste well cooked with extreme salt. Had green beans also very salty but well cooked. Sweet and Sour Soup vinegar type of taste but not bad at all. Th
Is is a good Restaurant if he leeses his salt I will give him a five star otherwise, he only gets 2 1/2 Star.
author: Konstantinos M.

description: Excellent Xiao Long Bao and Beijing DaLu noodles for lunch today.  I ate alone but couldn't help ordering 2 dishes and glad I did.  Good portions and reasonable prices.  Will definitely be back to try other dishes.  Other diners' beef rolls and Peking duck looked awesome too.
author: Karen C.

description: Great food here!!!! Service was nice and food was delicious. We got the beef in chili oil and chicken with explosive chili peppers with tan tan noodles. It's a little pricey since there isn't that much food with each order but it keeps you super full for the rest of the day, so I won't complain. I would definitely come back.
author: Emma H.

description:
We went to the Chili House for the Peking Duck because we had "heard" so much about it.  The duck is ceremoniously brought to your table, hot & gorgeous.  Right before your eyes, a "specialist" makes precise thin cross-cut breast pieces and lays them beautifully on a platter.  (They offer to make a soup of the bones for you.)

The presentation was great!  It's served with a sauce, shredded green onions, and julienned cucumbers, and thin pancakes with which to make a "duck burrito".  The duck, however, was disappointing.  It was mostly devoid of the fat (usually a good thing), and the duck meat was tender (good), but it was a bit dry and practically tasteless.  What more can I say?

As for all that chili in most of their their dishes, I love spicy food, but I can't understand SO MUCH chili!
author: Vera P.

description:
Love the Peking Duck meal with the soup and the pancakes.  The meat is tender and juicy and crafted beautifully.  The paper thin house made pan cakes go really well with the dish too! 

The sautéed pea sprouts dish is surprising good; csn smell the aroma from feet away!!  

Can't wAit to try the noodles and the tradition sweets!  

Be there early for dinner; can get busy by 5:45pm on a Friday!
author: Anita C.

description:
How does this place only have 3 1/2 stars?! I absolutely love this place. One of my favorite dishes is the pan fried pork pancake. It's super juicy inside, and the dough on the outside it super thin. A lot of time stuff like this is super doughy but this is not. I also love the explosive chicken. It is Sichuan goodness. Super flavorful! For those that don't love super spicy stuff it's not super spicy. Everything else
I have tried at this restaurant is also delicious. 
Try to get there early on the weekend as they get super busy.  

The servers are always friendly and the food comes out promptly.  I will be back.
author: Krystal R.

description:
Unbelievable! When I walked into the restaurant, there are 3 ladies standing around the cashier counter and chatting to each other's. I was telling them I have party of 2, and one of them ask me to take a seat. Due to this point, everything is all fine. After I was seated for 2 minutes, my husband came in. And both of us continue to seat for another 3 minutes, none of the ladies have show up, all of them stay at the back. We can hear them still talking to each other, but none of them have come out to check with their customers. Note: there are two tables across from us, one of them has party of two, the other one is 2+1 baby, and both tables are at least half way of their meals. 

So, the restaurant, on today, which 3/23/17, at 3:00PM, 3 tables, including us, NOT busy at all, the waitress continuing in their conversation, Not even come to bring a menu or ask for drinks for 5 minutes. All I can say is the management system has a big problem and their boss should notice this. Your employees are ruining your business!  Not Returning!!!
author: allan l.

description:
The food was really good. 

Awesome:
-peking duck
-little chickens
-tan tan noodles
-xlbs

Good:
-dry fried green beans
-dumplings in spicy oil


If you speak Taiwanese you will have an advantage. There was initially some difficulty pre-ordering/making reservations over the phone, but I messaged the business via yelp and they got right back to me/took care of everything. When we got there we had to wait a bit ( 20 minutes) but once seated everything was great. They even let us bring in a birthday cake ( Schubert's is across the street)! 

Thanks Chili House for a really enjoyable
evening with great food!
author: El B.

description: Skip the dumplings and go right for the hot pot. Took my brother on his birthday: the hot pot was savory and tingling with spice.
author: Nicholas Y.

description:
Been here twice already and I would definitely prefer the canton style rather than the Beijing.  The duck itself is fine but nothing spectacular but I would say their house made pancake wrappers is legit.  It's far better than the baos that most places tend to use. We had soup dumplings( fair) but not enough soup.  We tried their stir fried egg plant (not great). The beef rolls( pretty good, not as greasy).  Service was fair but not the friendliest. 

Overall, 3.5 stars is appropriate.
author: Patrick C.

description:
I was craving for their peking duck and everytime I wanted to order it they're closed. 

2 weeks ago I was lucky enough to be able to order it to go during lunch time. 

The peking duck itself was perfect and crispy and not too oily but then instead of  buns, I got the tortillas. I was so disappointed since it's not perfect without the buns. Why would you do that? Peking ducks are eaten with buns not tortilla. I have never seen any restaurants in my entire life and while living in Asia, that serves this with a tortilla.

Sorry about my tortilla rant but was just so disappointed after reading all the awesome reviews. Was I the only one that got tortilla?
author: Bebe P.

description:
Craving Chinese food, walked by, chose this place, and so happy about it. 

Wonton soup was yummy. 
Pork buns were alright, the dough was flavorless but nice and squishy. Filling was good, tasted like the wonton filling. 
Kung pao chicken was so great! Spicy but not enough to make you sniffle. Covered in amazing onions, peppers, peanuts. Really good. 
The chow mein was the star.  I am a noodle fiend and those were some of the best noodles I've had, and the flavor was on point. I am definitely gonna be craving this place. 

We actually ordered 2 more dishes than we received. The duck and potstickers never made it to us, which would normally be annoying but we were so happy because we were totally stuffed anyways.
author: Jessica F.

description:
I travel through China every year and this was by far the worst Chinese food I have ever had. I took my friends from China here and they agreed. 

The food was very poorly prepared and the ingredients were of very low quality. 

I do not recommend this place. There are better Chinese restaurants in the Bay Area. Do not get fooled by the reviews.
author: Lars E.

description: We came here mainly for the Peiking duck because we wanted to see how's compared to our favorite one at Great China in Berkeley. I personally liked it a little better than the one at Great China. The duck meat is juicier and I got to watch it being filleted right in front of me - like a mini show. The duck bones are offered to be further prepared in soup or salt and pepper. We opted for salted and peppered duck bones which we fell in love with more than the duck meat lol. Other dishes were also not bad. We got the xiao long bao deal and that was the least favorite among our orders. The skin was dry and easy to break.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Like it hot and spicy?  Chili House has a world famous chef and so you know the food is terrific.  Service is also superlative and you must watch the server carve the Peking Duck even if you don't order it!

Rounding out this find is a set of gender specific bathrooms that are cleaner than most Chinese restaurants' and no urine smell or homeless near the front door.  Bring your appetite and wine--their list is limited but corkage is an amazingly refreshing $12!!
author: david f.

description: Reservations mean nothing here. We walked in right on time for a 6:15 reservation with two hungry kids (who were super excited for some xiao long bao) and were told to wait outside... fine. 20 minutes later, they were seating families off the walk-in list before us. When I asked about it, first they acted like it was a huge imposition and then I was ignored completely. It was clear they'd rather we leave... which we did after almost 30 minutes of waiting. Who knows why, but we all left feeling like we were treated rudely for no apparent reason.
author: Shiwani S.

description:
Not bad, but not the nest Sichuan food either.
They also have some Beijing dishes. 
The flavor is light compare with the traditional Sichuan food. Not recommend if you are a traveler who want to have a great experience. 

Their service is quick and good.
author: Wen W.

description:
I received an email stating they would like to give me a free lunch, but I am not the kind of person that is looking for a free meal.....

I brought some friends to try this place again, hoping it would be better....

This place is the worst customer service ever.....they don't smile, walk by as if they didn't hear your request, always say wait a minute without returning, just terrible....management needs some serious training.....

The duck of course was great as usual, 3 stars for the food.....

I didn't know the big tables have an automatic 15% tip charge, which I normally tip 20 for decent service....but to pay 15% on the taxes added, I don't think so......
author: Leslie Y.

description: Blue bottle sake very smooth. Peking duck cut in front of your table, uses crepe style wrap.
author: Ju D.

description: The Peking duck is delicious, juicy, and crispy skin. The wraps are thin and chewy and a perfect combo with the duck. They also cut it right in front of you and either make a soup or fry it with seasoning after. The soup was delicious and flavorful. Overall a good experience despite the place being extremely packed and full. The dan dan noodle was not what I expected and tasted more like sambal chili paste than the nutty numbing noodles I am used to. But the cold spicy noodle was delicious and spicy.
author: Ellen G.

description: Owned by the same owners of Z&Y if you like spicy dishes you will love this place! We got the spicy wontons and boy was that spice your socks off delicious. They have all the z&y favorites and this location is also known for its peking duck which must be ordered ahead of time. $39 for the duck and it also comes with the bones either in a soup or salt and peppered (we selected the soup option). Green beans were delicious but the sizzling clay pot was more of a soup than your typical sizzling clay pot which has more of a sauce. Service was surprisingly attentive. Would want to come back to try their other dishes.
author: Betty C.

description: We had the banquet for 8 people ~$50/pp and added a few dishes and drinks. While the presentation was different or attempted to be special, the food was not impressive. In some cases, they may have tried a little too hard on presentation and sacrificed the quality of the food (for example, one dish was suppose to be served in a nest, but the nest is usually deep fried and crispy, but this one was sitting out somewhere and arrived soggy). The best thing we had was the scallop soup served inside a fresh young coconut. While the desserts were cute and pretty they were nothing special. I was really looking forward to the Peking duck based on what I've heard/read. The duck was ok- not especially better than any I have had at other Chinese restaurants.
