I walked away full but disappointed.
author: Musetta S.

description:
Came early on a Sunday.  It's totally expensive for dim sum, and even though the food is so good, I don't think some of the prices are justified, like, how to justify $8 for a pot of Oolong tea.  I mean the tea is good, but I'm going to knock of a star.  :] 

BUT!  The food is so good.  I've never had Szechuan Chinese food before, but there are some delicious Szechuan options on top of whatever province my dim sum favorites are from.  

We got the cold noodle, the beef pancakes, the pork and shrimp shu mai and spicy wontons.  I think normally, this is way too much food for two people, but we had just finished a race, and I thought I was going to die.  I believe the cold noodle and the spicy wonton were our Szechuan picks, and I might be assuming because I know Szechuan food is suppose to have a spicy kick to it, but these were so good.  They were my absolute favorite.  The sauce had a nice spicy kick to it, but not too much as to overcome the great tasting flavor!  Shu mai was nice and juicy and beautifully presented.  The beef pancakes were good, but not my favorite, we were in between the beef and green onion pancakes, and I think I would have preferred the green onion pancakes.  Oh well, next time, Chili House SF.  ;]
author: Cristina C.

description: I love the food here, but the customer service is horrible. We ordered eight dishes last time, and the waitress forgot three of them, she acted really impatient when I asked her about rest of our order, and they were even NOT that busy!  In the last they charged us 15% of tip, I would only give 1 % according to the whole bad experience.
author: Jessica L.

description:
NOT the best peaking duck save your money and go somewhere else. For $43.00 one would expect a superior duck it lacked flavor and the meat was dry. The duck was served with rice paper wrappers , sliced green onions , cucumbers and uneventful bean / hoisin sauce.  
Secondly I would rate the service was 2 out of 5. 
If your ABC expect to be treated not as well.
author: Julia L.

description:
First thought when I entered the restaurant: There's alot of people eating here. After waiting for a table with my family I realized that there are not alot of people eating here, but the fact that the customers here were just like me-first timers trying the new wave out. 

-Apparently, the peking duck cut in front of your table is a delicacy/their speciality. They don't give you the whole duck, which makes me wonder what they do after they're finished cutting slices for customers? Probably use it as scraps for their other dishes.

The majority of the dishes are spicy, filled with peppers, so if the sight or taste makes you bead sweat, then you're better off eating another type of Chinese food.
author: Erica K.

description:
Had to wait for one hour even with a reservation, with a senior and a baby. Tables were given to three parties coming after us. The waitress who arranges the tables apparently did not want to arrange the tables for us at all. Making her the first person the customers see is obviously a bad decision.

The food is good. The manager is polite and considerate. It's a shame that we cannot enjoy the food and service fully because of the wait and unpleasant opening experience. Recommend changing the waitress to someone who would not easily get offended by questions from customers.
author: Hua Y.

description:
Waited 2 hours to be seated, they told us the wait was going to be 30 minutes. We would've eaten somewhere else if we knew wait was going to be 2 hours...after being seated, waitress was rude and rolled her eyes at our questions about the food...then the table seated after us got all their food before we got ours, and we found out they lost their paper with our orders, so, we waited even longer...I understand mistakes here and there but so much time wasted when we came from out of town and the rude rude rude waitress bleh. so disappointed. 

Food: The duck was fatless. Beef roll was dry. Vegetables salty. Tofu was good. Salted egg and pumpkin shrimp a bit bland but the shrimp was big and fresh. 

Would've been 3 stars for food but service negative 2 stars. (Bathrooms are gross btw)
author: Fiona C.

description: Not the best looking chinese restaurent ambience wise, but the food was really good and price on the higher side. Didnt get to taste the duck as i have heard thats one of the best. But this will be surely my goto restaurent for sichuan cuisine in the Richmond Area.
author: Sharmistha S.

description:
Damn, should've checked this place out on Yelp before coming. No flavor, highly disappointed. Restaurant packed, but misleading. Siu mai was awful, twice cook pork was overly oily with no flavor.
Huge thumbs down.
author: K C.

description:
For a special occasion, our family of 7 reserved the Beijing Banquet of 14 courses, and $418 later, I was completely underwhelmed. The service is spotty, which might have been forgivable if the cuisine was stellar. The restaurant is trying to pass this off as a high-end Emperor's tasting menu, but the dishes were lackluster and not fresh (except for the duck). They also charge 19% gratuity (not stated anywhere when making reservations). When you arrive, there is no menu describing each dish. I requested one, and was given the a la carte menu. I asked again for the menu for our banquet, and I was given a 8.5"x11" sheet of paper with a handwritten menu in Sharpie marker, with item names only and no description of each item. Service was typical Chinese restaurant service. I wouldn't complain elsewhere, but for the price, it should be better. 

Let's start: 
1) The sweets were at the table before we arrived. They were stale, chalky tasting, overly sweet, and obviously a day or three old.

2) The cold appetizer dish: this came after the sweets, when it should have been first. This was probably one of the better dishes. The poached chicken was soft and moist. The rest was forgettable. 

3) Strips of bitter melon: all presentation and no substance. It was covered in a syrupy glaze that tasted so artificial and was presented on a bed of ice on a dish that was wrapped in cling wrap (why?). We barely touched it. See photo of the dish AFTER eating. 

4) Soup of winter squash and seafood in a young coconut shell: it was an odd bright yellow color and thickened with some sort of agent. It was sickeningly sweet, like they added sugar to it. They probably did. Seafood was fishy. 

5) Braised baby spareribs with mint: I'm assuming since it doesn't say it's cold appetizer that it shouldn't have been cold, but it was cold. However, if it was supposed to be cold, they should have said so. It was fried and dry, almost like jerky and tasted old - like it was fried a day or two ago and then re-fried before serving us, but why it was cold, I have no idea. 

6) Peking duck: this was the best of all the dishes. The meat was moist, and not too fatty and the skin was thin and crispy. Flavor was pretty good but not as good as Great Wall of China in Berkeley if you want good duck. 

7) Crab-avocado pastries and large prawns, glazed with horseradish mayonnaise. The prawns were coated in gobs of horseradish mayo and there were SPRINKLES on it. The kind you get on your ice cream at Baskin Robbins 20 years ago. 

8) Four-happiness dumplings. Bland. The wrapper was mushy.

9) Beijing-style pot stickers: too much wrapper to filling ratio. The filling was ok tasting. 

10) Braised and fried lamb rib coated in cumin and chiles. There was nothing braised about this dish. My husband was only able to cut off 3 pieces that were 1"long x1/4" thick that was stringy dried fried meat. The rest was fried to a crisp.

11) Beijing-style shao mai: these were ok, nothing special. 

12) Baby meatballs with baby spinach. Served lukewarm, tasted like they were fried and frozen and then re-fried upon serving. The spinach was very salty and overly seasoned. 

13) Catfish (or a fish like catfish - how would I know since the menu said "whole fish") in a peppercorn and chili oil broth. Fish was fishy and coated in oil, lots of skin. 

14) Pastry chicks filled with red bean paste. The pastry shell was hard and not flaky and tasted like hardened lard. 

I'm not sure how they got a good review in the SF Chronicle, but people save your money and go to Old Mandarin Islamic Chinese or Beijing Restaurant.
author: Patricia L.

description:
I found Chili House on an article that included SF's top Chinese restaurants. I wanted to try a new place and really taste authentic Chinese food. I was getting tired of the same restaurants and food. My family and I came around 7 pm on a Friday night. We parked on a meter and since it was after 6 pm you don't have to pay.  We were a bit nervous thinking there would be a long wait since this place was number 1 on the article. Luckily, there was a table and we were seated within 5 minutes. 

Now, I was unsure of what to order and I didn't want to go with the typical orange chicken, fried rice, panda express type of order. I wanted to see if the waiter had any recommendations but he just seemed really eager to take our order. I ended up choosing the dan dan noodles and they were extremely bland. I asked to confirm if this was the right order and the order said, "Yeah, numb," to my dismay. We also ordered soup dumplings since they were half off if you check in on Yelp. Those were pretty good. My mom got the mushu pork and liked it. We also ordered the onion cakes which were average and bland tasting. As an entreé, I got the salt and pepper chicken which was good, but I felt like there was more flour than meat. My dad ordered half a duck and he liked it. This place seems to be known for their Peking duck. 

Overall, we had an average experience in terms of service. I think we would've had a better taste experience had we ordered more popular dishes and dishes we were familiar with.
author: Dan G.

description:
Went in on a fri evening and waited over an hour for party of two. 
Food looked good but tasted average at best 

The beef roll was fairly tasteless
The cumin lamb was okay. Not bad but not great
The soup dumplings had no soup. But otherwise tasted good. 
The fish cooked in peppercorn oil had fish that was so unfresh I could not even eat the fish. I truly believe this fish was about to go bad. Every bite made me feel like I was going to get sick or feel sick.  (Didn't end up getting sick but I sure felt sick.)

I'm sure not all of their fish is on the verge of rotting but I wanted to just let them know. Of course the response I get is "that's how it's supposed to taste. Catfish is naturally a little fishy". Huh wuh? As if I've never eaten catfish before?  I don't think my cat who eats everything would even want to eat it.
They offered to throw in a random dish to go which was promptly brought out to us. Pretty sure it was some returned or extra order.  Really doesn't make up for these shitty 'that's just how catfish tastes' remark.  Would have been fine if they had just said sorry.

Edit: while I did not get sick sick, I certainly am feeling all sorts of feelings in my tummy the day after.
author: Erica Y.

description: We were looking for dimsum restaurant and we found this place on yelp. The food was good but we don't like their customer services. This is the first time we came here, so we ordered some food they didn't have. That's ok until the waitress back inside and told with her co-worker about us. My husband can listen Chinese language. Oh my god, we cannot believe it. Then we requested the check, they offer if check in will get 50% off for xiao long bao, that lady stared us and sighed. So disappointed. Although the food was good, we don't want to come back.
author: Eva V.

description: Probably the best Sichuan food so far. Schezwan noodles are must try. Just the right amount of heat to numb the tongue. Eggplant was also very good. We ordered the Peking duck and it was roasted to perfection. You eat it with hoisin sauce and green onions like a egg roll. Chicken with explosive chilli's was amazing. Not crazy spicy as other places. Will go back to try more dishes
author: Pramod G.

description: Great Peking duck! Mapo tofu was a little too floral/ aromatic for us. Def would come back for the duck.
author: sungheui u.

description:
Excellent. This place satisfies every single corner of my Chinese pallet. First, the customers are maily Chinese (good sign of credibility for good Chinese food). Secondly, the presentation of the dishes are well put together. And thirdly, the combinations of spices is very acxurate to the region of China where it is from.

The first time i went there i was with non Chinese people so i had to Americanize our order to satisfy their non-sophisticated pallet. So i ordered Americanized items like orange chicken, egg rolls and chow mein. It was horrendous but i was a team player and like Jay-z says, "I had to dumb it down for my fans." Indeed i did.

2 weeks later i told muself i had to come back a do it for real and redeem myself to myself. This time i came with the love of my life who has a food pallet that i have never seen anyone reach in my life. We walked in and immediately the owner noticed me. I told him that his place had potential and that my last experience was mediocre because of the people i was with. He told me "give me your menus and i will prepare you a dinner myself that's not for white people. You will love it."  So I put the fate of my pallet into his hands. What happened next was a blissful trip to North China in the niddle of Upper Sunset SF. 

First item was a pepper ground lamb dun dun noodles served in a bowl with basil leaves. It was the most exotic comfort food i ever had. Dripping with wet chilli oil with a minty taste and meaty finish. I was sold

The next thing was a the pepercorn and chilli tea smoked duck. It was savory, spicy and the skin on the duck was smokey and crispy. It was as satisfying as a cigar but with food.

Then came the siew loong bao (a Northern china staple). These steamed pork dumplings came in a bamboo basket with a side of vineager ginger dipping sauce. One bite into this gelatinous ball and all the juices came shooting out in an orgasmic fashion. It was juicy, savory and most of all, delicious

Lastly we had a melin fish soup. It had chunks of fatty fish  and fish fat floating on top of the melons. It was stable, even in flavor and really brought the meal full circle.

This meal was so good that I felt like that nerdy pimple faced kid who scored with the hottest girl on prom night. I highly reccommend this place but please bring a Chinese person who speaks Cantonese/ Mandarin. Your experience will be better and the food will be top notch.
author: Kswiss L.

description: Peking duck is amazing! That's why we came here on our trip to SF! If you don't mind, you should checked shared table while you sign on the waiting list. That will save you a lot of time.
author: Hanying H.

description: Came here with my family for my dad's birthday. There was a long wait and we had a reservation but still had to wait because they couldn't fit us at a table with a baby. My dad wanted to come here because he saw it on Facebook and heard it was good. Food was okay but hardly memorable.
author: Samantha D.

description:
I will preface this with saying the food is good, but not clean at all. 
We arrive at the restaurant and I go to the bathroom, someone from the kitchen walks out... with gloves still on. She used the bathroom, with her gloves on. I excuse this, just assuming she cleans the dishes and not to worry. 
Out food arrives, and after we get to the last mu shu roll, I find a hair. I ask the waiter if I can get a new thing of papers, since there is a hair in my food. He calm suggests I just eat around it. 
At my request, he finally brings some more and tells me not to worry, I will not be charged for them. 
Very sub par for the price.
author: Amy T.

description:
Wow - this is a popular place for a good reason. We had a very helpful waiter who helped us order a delicious new vegetable dish,"Chinese watercress".
We liked the spicey Eggplant, loved the Tan Tan noodles and also had walnut prawns. The food is HOT!
author: Helen M.

description:
So good will be back soon!

Duck is amazing for some chinese food
author: Eli S.

description: Serious restaurant! Amazing duck dishes. Spicy wontons are to die for. Very attentive servers. Explosive chicken is absolutely delicious. I am yet to eat something here I don't like. Extremely well managed family owned place. Highly recommended.
author: bora o.

description: Love The Chile House.  The staff and service is always friendly and the food is tongue numbingly good.  We've had whole fried fish,  and our favorite poached spicy beef  always great.  We have been only during the day so not tried the Peking Duck but really want to   its my favorite S. F.  Chinese
author: Miller's E.

description:
Food: 4.0/5.0
Service: 2.5/5.0
Value: 3.5/5.0
Decor: 3.0/5.0
Overall: 3.5/5.0 

Did not get to try the Peking duck but did get a sampling of the szechuanese stuff.  The food is authentic and very good.  Prices are a little high for the neighborhood but not high in the context of SF, and certainly not high compared to the sister restaurant Z&Y in FiDi Chinatown.
author: Damian W.

description: First time and it was amazing! Highly recommend making reservations, line was out the door the entire time cause it's so delicious. Had the Peking duck, chicken with explosive chili, green onion pancake and pork dumplings. Jake is a fabulous waiter!
author: Kerri A.

description: High quality spicy Sichuan Chinese food.  Best Tan-Tan noodles in town, great tea selection.
author: Rosco T.

description: Very authentic Chinese food! We ordered Beijing duck, 夫妻肺片, shumai, everything is very delicious! I like the shumai in particular, it is very authentic northern Chinese style, quite different from the cantonese dim sum style. This type of shumai is very popular in my hometown, very excited to find such a great restaurant in the US!
author: Zhizhitravel T.

description: Omg, the food is so good. I was about to order the intestine with chili (which is dry), but I gave wrong instructions and put chinese cabbage with it, but it still turn good. I wish the rice balls dessert can taste more to sweet, but I still like it anyway.
author: Merry H.

description: Solid place. 3.5 to 4 stars.  Their specialty is the Beijing duck, which you need to pre-order before you arrive and reserve your duck.  It's quite good, no question.  The duck has no salt, which is odd, because I think if they added salt to it, it would be really delicious.  The place specializes in Szechuan (Sichuan) Chinese food, which means that it is spicy. Overall, the food is solid and very tasty.  There are lots of sauces, so be mindful of that if you are looking for a place that does not have lots of heavy sauces.
author: Gunnar F.

description: Yum.  Even using delivery that food arrived and was excellent.
author: Leslie D.

description:
The golden feiteng fish is the best! 
Spicy crabs are delicious and with some veggies!
Best restaurant in SF!
Lovely girl waitress!
author: Yueru L.

description: I gave it 4 stars for great service and foods.  If you like spicy foods this is a place for you.  Ingredients were fresh and tasty.  Portions were huge.  Reasonable price and long wait so try to be there early.
author: Holly K.

description:
Basil chicken 1 star
Shanghai dumplings 2 star
Suck soup 1 star - taste like water
Service 1 star - the waitress took our duck soup away after we already started eating and only to realize that she made a mistake
author: Cindy W.

description: Sweet mercy. This place is fabulous. Their soup dumplings are the best I've had since leaving China. The Dan Dan Mian is super legit. None of that gross peanut sauce crap. Just pure ma la numbing spicy flavor. The pork and shrimp shaomai were plump and richly flavorful. I will absolutely be coming back because I need to try everything on the menu.
author: Mike N.

description: Very good food and outstanding value for the quality. Our favorite is the Cumin Lamb but there are many good dishes to choose from.
author: Matt T.

description:
Stopped in yesterday before my flight back to LA.  I cannot recommend Chilli House enough!  We pre-ordered the Peking Duck and it was incredible.  Also, the Tan Tan Noodles were fantastic.  They had Spicy quality to them that I cannot really place anywhere else.  
Our waiter was very good as well.  I have no doubt I'll be back!!
author: Jeff F.

description: Warning do not eat here.  I ordered a delivery of pork sui mai ( dim sum ).  When I bit into it the center was still raw.  I had a mouth full of raw pork in my mouth.  It was disgusting!!!!!   Never will order again.
author: Victor S.

description:
Me and my boyfriend got food poisoning after eat in chili house. We ordered peaking duck, Szechuan style chicken and garlic fried bean sprout last night. We both felt sick after we got home yesterday and this morning we both felt even worse. the symptoms are include, vomit, diarrhea and headache. Because of food poisoning, both of us not only can't go to work, but also we gotta go to the doctors.

We need to get an apologize from your restaurant. And Your restaurant really needs to improve your food quality and the level of food freshness, otherwise I'll report it to the mayors office since your restaurant has already got several POOR FOOD SAFTY SCORE!!!!!!!!
author: Shuting W.

description:
On a Wednesday afternoon treated out the wifey to some supposedly best peking duck / dim sum.

Just a note everything they served tasted super fresh, the meats and the vegetables were excellent.

Here is what we sampled

steamed dumplings (xia long bao) - dumplings with pork and inside the dumpling is juice - as long as the dumpling does not break when you are handling them the taste is explosive, slight crunch with whatever veggie they threw in there and that juice was piping hot, worth burning your tongue over and over again, must try when here

shu mai bejing style - appearance wise it did stand a little taller then the regular shu mai you would order at any other dim sum place but when biting down there is also a slight crunch from whatever was minced on this dish, definitely would order again

steamed bach choy (probably spelled it wrong)- standard dish with the wifey, no frills, garlic minces and steamed on a white plate

seasoned or dry green beans - helpful serving of veggies almost like salt and pepper anything but with green beans

minced pork with green and red bell peppers, dried red thai chilli's, red onions, cooked in a light sauce that you can taste through every bite - I would other this again if I could recall the name

The Peking Duck - this is there signature dish $39.95 for a whole duck, when it comes out, the duck is whole, the chef personally comes to your table cuts the meat into thin slices and sets them on a total of two plate one for each side of the duck, the third plate is for the rib cage and left over meat on the duck which is deep fried and seasoned with salt and pepper, the sauce, veggies and wraps are served on the side for this dish, the duck is not seasoned, not oily, super tender, skin is super crunchy, meant to be put on a steamed wrap, add some veggies, add some sauce then bite down on all this deliciousness. This dish takes close to 35 minutes to prep they tell you when you order it, glad to have tried this dish, I do recommend you have more people with you not just two people hahaha

For dim sum this place does have some star dishes, again I do recommend coming with more then just 2 people so you can have more dishes to try

food **** fresh produce and meat you can taste it on every bite
price $$ average cost per dish $9 peking duck was $39.95(35 min wait)
service **** as long as you know what you want or an idea of what you want they can assist you through the menu
ambiance *** no super frills just another restaurant on Clement in the city
author: Clarence A.

description:
This restaurant gave me my food with bugs in the bag and when I told them about they refused to do anything about it. I guess it was my fault, I was warned when I found them on Yelp that they had a poor food safety score. I now see why! 

I was so hungry too. [insert crying face]
author: Farryn L.

description: Not a bad place to dine and the food is reasonably priced. The only thing is if you come for dinner, you might wanna make a reservation first as this place gets very crowded around dinner time.
author: Shijia W.

description: The one thing Chinese restaurants are famous for is there customer service, or more like a lack of it. We where delighted by how great the entire staff was, they were very knowledgeable, made us feel welcomed, they checked on us often, recommended some great dishes, and even played with our 2 boys (9 months & 3yr) during busy hours. We didn't rsvp our Peking Duck in advance, but our waiter said to give him 20 minutes and he'll get us one. It was worth the wait, they brought out the duck, cut it in front of you, and the bones was deep fried in salt and pepper. The duck was juicy, the sauce was perfect, and the pancake wrap was a great compliment to the dish. The basil clams was fresh and flavorful, the green beans with black bean sauce had enough spices, but not overpowering, the smoked ham fried rice is thumbs up. Everything was good and we would definitely return. Having eaten almost all the Chinese restaurants on the street, Chili House stands out above all of them with great customer service and food.
author: Hieu L.

description: near the golden gate park. traditional sichuan dishes are quite strong spice which are very delicious.
author: Shan G.

description:
Attracted by their ad on the Chinese TV station saying that you must be something wrong if you don't go to this supposedly great restaurant, then finally decided to give it a try. Well, first of all, the service people, including a manager like person, were super racist - when they saw non-Chinese customers, they smiled and they welcomed them wholeheartedly. During the meal, they would talk to these non-Chinese customers and asked them opinions about the meal. However, to Chinese looking customers, they simply tried their best to ignore them. The difference in services was as wide as the Pacific Ocean although we Chinese know what to order and actually ordered more expensive food.
In terms of the food quality, this place is trying to do it all but failed. Peking duck is Pekingese cuisine and has nothing to do with Szechuan cuisine. To have some Peking food mixed with Szechuan food and label itself "Chili House"will not work for people who really know Chinese food well. As some other reviews indicated, their Duck is just so so and the duck cutting performance is just average. The soup dumpling is Shanghainese food and also has nothing to do with any of their specialty. Because they wanted to fit every possible taste of Chinese cuisines, none of them excelled. The Northern dishes we ordered did not do it right . Some of the things they advertised that their service person didn't even know what they were. I believe that the guy who is busy doing duck cutting performance is a real chef from Northern part of China. However, at least teach your staff how to greet your Chinese customers and teach them that "Wandou Huang" and "Lvdagun" are not Cantonese or Szechuanese Dim Sum. 
The restaurant is also a very tiny one trying to pretend to be a bigger one. Ding Tai Feng started in a very tiny place but evolved into a huge company by only making two dumplings famous. Please check your food quality and train your staff before going out to perform and welcome the non-Chinese customers, your restaurant will have a bright future.
author: Ah L.

description:
Our first visit here was a huge hit for all five in our party.
* Super friendly and knowledgeable wait staff.
* highlights:
  -- Xiao Long Bao were out of this world:  flavorful, full of broth, al dente wrapped perfection.
   -- dry string beans, perfectly cooked and seasoned
   -- lamb was tasty as all get out BUT TOO SALTY.  Too Salty = common theme.  Wish the onions had been slightly more cooked too
  -- Szechuan pepper corns in a fish dish had us all Atingle.  Literally.  Our tongues, then whole mouths tingled in some pretty interesting and intense ways.  I liked the fish but others found it slimy.  Excellent use of cumin And cucumbers in this dish.
  -- Hot and Sour soup was just right hot and sour, but, you guessed it, too darn salty.
   
Can't wait to come by for the tea smoked spicy duck -- will be sure to get xiao long bao and green Beene again ... maybe hot and sour soup too.  Will definitely ask for LOW SALT VERSIONS of these and all the new dishes we try too.
author: Scott C.

description:
Heard chili house for a while and wanted to try! We check their hours before we go to Chili house to make sure we were not there too late! Yelp saying they closed at 11:00pm. We were there at 8:15 and we wait for 45 mins for our table! (The table was ready but the sever didn't seat us) We wait for about 25-30 mins for all our food come out. I admit that their food are good but their service are very bad. Except Two of the server! After all the food come out, the waitress gave us our check immediately and saying they are closing soon! We were so shot! We were trying to finish our dinner as soon! However, one of the waiter who had never serve us attitude were very bad saying that we are eating very slow and ba ba ba...from the other side of the restaurant. I understand that you want to go home but I spent my time to wait to for my table and food too.

Peking duck was good! Also xiao long bao was good!

Two stars for the food and two nice servers!
author: Patricia T.

description: Food tasted okay  i had better else where the soup dumpling was okay 2/5 not the best
author: haze y.

description:
Welcome to the Szechuan world! Chili House is all about bold and robust flavors of Szechuan cuisine, a cuisine known for the generous usage of garlic and chili peppers. Learn about how the unique Szechuan peppercorns separate CH from other Americanized Szechuan restaurants. When it comes to ethnic foods, I am all for authenticity and the virtually 100% Chinese crowd bears testimony to this. Don't get intimidated by the fiery red chili oil and the gazillion chili peppers in the sauce as CH's job didn't just end here. CH also juggles to balance heat with the numbing effects of Mala sauce to produce a symphony of flavors. Being the novice that I am, I have to admit that not all dishes in CH were pleasing to my palate.  This might just be me. 

My first visit to CH was indeed a learning experience. Staying with the true and tried, I ordered Tan Tan Noodles ($6.95) to share. It was the sauce that made the noodles absolutely wonderful. The chili oil was plentiful although happily blended with vinegar and sesame oil to enhance the taste and dilute the heat. A subtle sourness in the sauce was the key. Noodles were al dente and topped with chopped peanuts and minced pork that acted more like garnish than intended protein. The heat was surprisingly mild, mild enough that any spice wimp can handle!
 
I have often seen Shanghai Style Wine Chicken ($7.95) in Szechuan restaurants, a Shanghainese dish that I truly enjoy.  My guess the whole chicken was marinated in Shaoxing wine (a Chinese rice wine) and steamed perfectly so that the skin remained intact and the meat was firm, not tough or dried out. CH's rendition was flawless except for one big transgression IMO. The chicken was almost too salty to be eaten without rice.

McDonald's has Chicken McNuggets. The Japanese has chicken karaage. CH has their very own Chicken with Explosive Chili Pepper ($10.95), a name that couldn't have been more graphic and intimidating. There was this pile of red chili peppers where the chicken nuggets were buried.  As to why the nuggets were not more 'explosive' remained a mystery even up to now! Kudos to the chef as the meat was moist. The flavorful 5-spice marinade differentiated Szechuan style from the Japanese and of course McDonald's in a good way. This was where my love for this dish ended.  CH added an inordinate amount of Szechuan peppercorns that overwhelmed everything else. I am still new to this weird fragrance so while others savored it, I find that a total overkill. 

The House Special Fresh Fish Filet Boiled in House Spicy Sauce ($15.95) was like their signature dish but failed me for two reasons.  CH carried only one kind of fish and that was catfish. This is my least favorite fish regardless how it is prepared except maybe deep fried Southern style. Then there was again the ubiquitous Szechuan pepper sauce blended in a pool of chili oil. It was my mistake not to pre-check the kind of fish used before ordering. Nonetheless, the fish had a soft texture and the elaborate spicing concealed the inherent muddy taste. They were generous with the fish portions and the Napa cabbage did help break the monotony. This was the spiciest dish of all and I could have enjoyed this dish more if the peppercorns were toned down to a more subtle level.

In spite of me not savoring the food as much as I should like the rest of the diners, I can still honestly say the food here is legit. I definitely need to first acquire and appreciate the new taste and fragrance of Szechuan peppercorns in the numbing Mala sauce and give CH another shot when I am ready.
author: Geoff G.

description:
Had a great lunch here around noon on a Friday & it wasn't super crowded. We ordered a bunch of amazingly delicious entrees and left more than happy.

I'm sad to see that between eating here and the time that this review is posted there is a Consumer Alert in effect for: Poor Food Safety Score from Yelp due to a recent inspection, where this facility received a food safety rating that is in the bottom 5% locally, and is categorized by inspectors as "poor."

It kind of makes this review a moot point. However my iron stomach and I will proceed.

-Spicy Dumplings ($7.95 at time of review)- Really good. Really, really good. The presentation was super cute and the food was flavorful and filling.

-Beef Pancake (price varies due to market)- HANDS DOWN MY FAVORITE. I was surprised at how much I loved this dish. I am one of those genetically mutated individuals whose taste buds think that cilantro taste like soap. This dish however, was the first time I genuinely appreciated cilantro. 

-Peking Duck- AMAZING! The best bet is to call ahead a few days and special order this so you're not disappointed when they run out. The chef will come out and carve the duck for you. Then once the meat is served they take the rest of the duck in the back and deep fry the bones & leftovers and bring it back out for you. I'm not a huge fan of the fried bones but I know there are some people out there that love it. 

-Ma Po Tofu ($4. 95 at time of review)- This was good. However due to the other food ordered this dish didn't stick out as much as it would have if I wasn't with a group and ordered it alone.  

I'm sure that we had two other dishes but to be honest I think that I can't remember what they're called because they didn't stick out to me as much. This is a fun place for a group to come to. There were 5 of us and our bill came out to about $35 a person.  

Once yelp removes the Consumer Alert I'm sure I'll be back. Until then I'll be checking to see when it goes away!
author: Tam T.

description: It was ok but expensive for what you get the food was just average. We picked up a lunch menu on recommendation of a local patron but the waitress would not let us order off it. I clearly said at the top "lunch menus"   The waitress got mad at the patron and told her off. Very unfriendly place.
author: Daniel P.

description:
Orderd different dishes. The chicken with chili was very good. My favorite remains the frog with chili in a pot. I can't list al dishes I tried so far, but none of them were bad, tasteless, over cooked or poorly designed.
We have a winner.

However, this place is very busy. Service can be slow. The wait can be long. A lot of people did the same by ordering mutiple dishes. I'm pretty confident that all dishes will help you to forget the wait.
author: Jean-Yves F.

description: We came here hoping for dim sum. Well, it wasn't really a dim sum place, but it was great for lunch. I got the salted egg yolk pumpkin dish -- a Chinese speciality rarely on menus in the US -- and my friends got dumplings. All was delicious!
author: Elyssa R.

description: Very legit, tasty hot and sour soup. It starts off spicy and gets more sour as you work your way through it. Also had some respectable steamed dumplings. Pretty basic but high quality and home made Chinese food.
author: Scott B.

description:
I'd like to start by saying that if you are going to bring your costumers individual bowls of rice and they have not asked for it, do NOT charge them for it. We were well into our meal when a server gave us each a bowl of white rice, as is common at Chinese restaurants. What is also common is that rice is included with the meal, and since we didn't even ask for it in the first place, we were put off by the fact that we were charged $1.85 a bowl for it. If we had asked for it and been subsequently charged for it, that would have been one thing. But we did not request it and then got charged for it, which is not OK.

But on to the decent. We went for a late lunch on Christmas (knowing that they would be opened) after a long day of walking. The place was packed and there was a waiting list, but they did a very good job of accommodating as many customers as possible. We waited maybe twenty minutes before they offered to sit us at a large table with another family, which we were more than happy to do. We ordered up some soup which we had asked to be out first (it ended up coming out last), followed by some dumplings, green beans, duck, and a couple rounds of beers. It was solid food, and we were simply happy to be able to sit and eat indoors after walking around the city for the past four hours.

When the check came, I noticed that they had charged us for an extra beer that we did not order. They happily corrected the (I'm assuming honest) mistake, but when the check came back a second time is when we noticed that we had been charged for rice that we had been given, but had not asked for. Since it wasn't a significant amount of money and the servers were still running around, we decided to let it slide so that we could get going. Even if it's only a few bucks, that's not a good way of doing business and it's disrespectful to your clientele.
author: Reid C.

description:
Ordered takeouts via Yelp Eat. By the time I got there on foot, the order was ready, quite efficient. After getting home and opened the boxes, I noticed the tea smoked duck tasted just like Cantonese duck you can get in a lot of restaurants in town, no tea, no smoke, just a lot of grease. The other fish "happy family" tasted greasy as well. 
It used to be a good restaurant...
author: shan t.

description: Our go to place for quality Sichuan food.  The Peking duck is great but we order this only on special occasions.  Food is very high quality and there are many dishes to choose from.  We appreciate the pictures on the menu to help us decide what to order.  One suggestion though, we think the fancy tea where a person uses a long tea pot to serve your tea is a bit overpriced.  Limited parking and the long wait can be a pain but the food and service is worth the pain.
author: Gary L.

description: Best kung Pao chicken I've ever had! Can't say much about anything else because that's all I had.
author: Jessica W.

description: This is a good restaurant for authentic Sichuan food.  I also like their Beijing duck.
author: Rancho Cordova R.

description: Very good, especially the fish, my family loves it!! And Xiao Xia is very nice to us, too. Definitely will come again!!! Highly recommend!!!
author: Alison L.

description:
First off, they take reservations. Do not ask me why there are twenty people waiting in the tiny area by the door with their name scribbled on a clipboard. And please do not give me the evil eye when I am seated ahead of the walk-ins because I made a reservation. People, it's easy, you can do it here on Yelp.

We went for lunch on a rainy Sunday and it was packed, which is a good sign. The prices are reasonable, but higher than your average Clement St dive. We ordered chili dumplings (tasty), Seafood Claypot (meh), and Tea Smoked Duck (delicious, best thing we ate). Service was good and other than the giant TV silently displaying real estate listings, I liked the ambiance.

I'll be back for more of the duck, and to hopefully discover some new faves too.
author: Samantha J.

description: After a wait-20 minutes, even with reservations, we sat down and proceeded to order.  Right off the bat they were out of pig ears and Peking dumplings/6:30 on a Sunday. Everything we order tasted bland.  The Peking was beautiful and hot but had no flavor.  So we said, ok been there done that.
author: Jeanne L.

description: I went here for a friend's birthday dinner looking forward to try the Peking duck that's specially advertise. We placed the order with a reservations and took advantage of the yelp discount on shanghai dumplings if checked in. After a full filled meal, we ask for the check and thinking it was correct, I paid the bill with my card.  After the bill came back for signature, i happened to noticed that the shanghai dumplings was not discounted.  I informed the waitress, but she told me why didn't i inform them prior to paying.  I guess i was under the impression that it will be applied since we ordered and check-in advance.  And because i was speaking to them in Chinese, i was informed with an unfriendly tone that it was my responsibility.  really??? I end up with no discount and no revised bill to reflect the charges and told to use it next time.  *sigh* will there be a next time with this rude customer service?
author: M W.

description:
Tip: If you go for their famous peking duck, make sure you call to reserve your duck a day before!

I have been trying to find a restaurant who servers real authentic peking duck for years, not the ones served in Cantonese style restaurant, those ARE NOT real period! So one night while channel surfing I saw their ad playing on KTSF and decided to give a try. I have been to Chili house before and didn't really like their food compared to the other location in Chinatown. We came on Chinese new year's eve, place is packed but since we had a reservation we were sat down pretty quickly. Ordered bunch food and all of them taste pretty good. Peking duck is prepared at the table, the duck chef pushes the cart to your table, show you the whole duck, then he will carve it in front of you. Very authentic! just like the one you get in Beijing. Duck is very juicy and the flour pancake is home made, this is what you should eat the duck with, NOT with buns. You can choose what you want to do with the leftover, either have the chef make salt and pepper duck or soup. I would go with the soup but salt and pepper is good too.

I am not sure if they really hired a new chef or the chef really listened to the suggestions and improved but the food does taste better now compare to the last time I came. We will be back again more often now to try other beijing style dim sum.

One suggestion to the restaurant if you are reading the review, please do not add sesame oil (香油）into the sweet bean sauce （甜面酱） for the peking duck.
author: William C.

description: Xiao Long Bao. Peking Duck. Fish with chili oil. Amazing. It's an experience the whole way around. Yum yum yum
author: Anthony G.

description: Make sure you reserved before going there as line can be long.   Peking duck was lean and tasted great.  No fat at all.   Service was attentive for Sunday lunch time.   Price was good too.   7 dishes + 2 appetizers ($205 including tip for 6 ppl).  Will definitely go there again,
author: Stanley L.

description:
We were initially drawn to Chili House's promising looking XiaoLongBao. It turns out that they are a complete disappointment. While they look nice from the outside, there is no juice on the inside. We almost got 2 orders of it and we could barely finish 1.

We also decided to try the Peking Duck. Although we did not order in advance, they were able to bring out the duck after just half an hour. The chef who sliced the duck table side was very chatty with me.

The duck was served with authentic pancakes (not those silly buns) and scallions, cucumber, and sauce. We needed more people to eat a duck as the richness got to me by the end. Overall, it was a solid rendition, particularly for the Bay Area.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Wow. Leave the "traditional" Chinatown and head to Chili House. We tried an appetizer of Spicy Dumplings and were fighting over the last one. Three different main dishes to share and had trouble pushing our plates away even though we were stuffed!
Make a reservation - the word has gotten around.
author: Ann M.

description: Lots of chili. Thats for sure. If you luv heat,chili is your game. I'm more.into dimsum for lunch.
author: Ronn M.

description: The menu here says that they share the same chef as Michelin-rated Z&Y, but that's a stretch. We have eaten in Z&Y, and it was miles ahead of Chili house. The first time we went there there was a wait of about 30 mins, and food was OK. The second time, the wait was more than an hour, and the shoddy way the queue was managed made things worse. There were quite a few people who were not in the queue, and they were let in before us. When the people in teh queue raised objections, we were told that these patrons had reservations - this seems strange, because the restaurant did not take reservations! Once we got a table, the food was considerably lower than average. Everything was very greasy, and lacked finesse. Overall, not a good experience, and we are going to give this place a pass.
author: Dipankar M.

description: We actually came here during New Years so it was insanely busy. They were able to sort of keep up with the crowd. Service is great! However, the food is just all right.
author: Candy L.

description:
I've been coming here since they first opened, mostly for their lunch specials.  At first my experiences have been good...large portions and relatively affordable.  But the past 2 years or so things changed.   Their menu changed and the service changed.  A few of my favorites were no longer served.  But the worse was their service.  I think maybe a change in the ownership as the waitresses before were always better.  Now with the current waiter and waitress I have to constantly remind them that soup is included in the lunch specials.  You would think that they would know their menu by now.   

I've just about given up on them and will take my business elsewhere.  The food is ok but I think it was better when they first opened.
author: Acura Nsx T.

description:
The food is ok. Not the greatest but there are a few stand out dishes like the Peking Duck, Basil Clams and the Seafood Stew. I'd skip the Xiao Long Bao, Pork & Chive Dumpling and I didn't find the Mung Bean dessert worthwhile.

The servers, while nice, are very inexperienced. Upon arriving, they said they were going to combine 2 tables for me after I told them several times how many was in my party and that I already had a reservation. Yet, they still wait and ask me several more times. Took us forever to order. After dropping off our soup, we had to ask for bowls and spoons separately. Not sure how they expected us to drink it. Our table had mismatching utensils - some of us had takeout chopsticks while others had regular. 

They stated over the phone that there would be free duck buns w/ the purchase of the duck. What we realized after is that they meant that the duck skin to wrap the duck into little burritos was the free item. So exactly how were we supposed to eat the duck w/ the scallion and cucumber if they didn't give us the "free" skins? Just as is w/ no rice and such?
author: Julie L.

description: We waited for about an hour before being seated, however their food & customer service makes up for the wait. It explains why they have so much people. Their Peking duck is a must try! Our server was David and he was great! He made sure we were always good to go. I suggest making your reservation through open table or calling ahead so your wait time isn't as long.
author: Treena Mariel S.

description: An amazing restaurant we found accidentally. Love its Peking Roast Duck with nice serve.
author: Zhirui Z.

description: You wouldn't think it but their Beijing duck is the best we've found in the area.  Perfectly crispy skin with juicy meat and barely any fat (not oily at all), and the accompanying thin pancakes are so good!  Plus the rest of their typical Szechuan fare is yummy as well.  The wait and service can be slow, but that's typical of Chinese restaurants!
author: Jen W.

description: One star for finding long black hair wrapped snugly inside my honey walnut prawn. The interior is nice, and it looked clean but I guess looks can be deceiving. It is a shame because the food did look good/ample serving size. We showed the hair in our food to the person in charge, and she looked at us like "Meh". No apology whatsoever.
author: Eva J.

description:
So much food at such a little price. I'm talking dinner for 7 with rounds of beer and tea, happily munching away for a total of $123. What a rhym - ha! 

If you have a large party, Chili House is a great location to gather around. 
The tables have those spinning platers that make family style ordering a synch. 

Our menu consisted of:
Appetizers:
- Scallion Pancake - wasn't my favorite. It was more like a potato cake.
- Steamed Pork Dumplings - excellent.
- Wonton with Spicy Peanut Sauce - equally excellent. I am not a fan of peanut 
   flavored sauces, so you will have to sample on your own.

Entrees:
- Whole Fish with Bean Chili and Hand-Pulled Noodles - there's a head on there! 
  The fish is tender and soft, but with any muddy-water fish there is that lingering
  bayou taste. I think catfish is better fried.
- Lamb in Flaming Chili Oil -  The sautéed onions complement the lamb 
  perfectly with a tender crunch that explodes with spice. The lamb itself was cut  
  into small bite size strips.
- Stir-Fried Chicken with Pickled Chili Pepper - so many peppers, not enough
  chicken. The small bit that I did get was a semi-battered mini-bite.                   
- Stir-Fried Chinese Cabbage with Chili Pepper -  loved that the cabbage was 
  not overcooked. It was sautéed and served in a nice sauce.
- Steamed Rice

The service was okay. It wasn't the friendliest, but certainly not the worst I have had. They were attentive and were there when we called. Oh and that carpet! They need to pull that bad boy up and either good wood or replace. It was mangey! Otherwise, bring some friends and have some delicious szechuan cuisine. P.s. It wasn't all that spicy!
author: Jaylena P.

description:
You want authentic szechuan food? Look no further

Even before you walk inside, you can tell from the outside that this place is legit. The menu is full of authentic szechuan items, and when you order them and the food actually arrives, there is no mistaking it--full blown pure szechuan numbing spiciness heaven. The spicy beef tripe was Crazy good, with Enormous slices of pure beef meat. The water-cooked-fish was large, and filled with ingredients and large slices of fish fillet. The veggie fried rice was pretty good as well.

Will definitely come back whenever I am craving szechuan spiciness.
author: Henry L.

description: Their fish fillet and tofu dish is made just the way we like it and the mongolian beef was good too. Looking forward to trying the peking duck next time.
author: Helen L.

description:
Ok, so I got a little huffy when I saw reviews about this place being sub-par when it comes to cleanliness, I swear they are lies, because I'm the back neighbor to this restaurant and can see their kitchen through my window, it's literally 3 feet away. Their kitchen is always clean, and they have a professional cleaning crew come in often as well (lol not to be creepy but I can hear them cleaning). It's a real professional kitchen. Because of this I always order food to go from here, and recommend it to tourists that walk around the neighborhood. 

I think I've met the elder owner guy too, he doesn't speak that much English but he's the sweetest man ever. 

Their portions are huge and the foods always awesome. I hope this place is part of the neighborhood for a long time.
author: Faye H.

description:
While browsing through chinese places on yelp, I almost skipped over this one when I noticed something that caught my eye. In one of the pictures, there was a noodle dish in a red broth with ground meat on top. The caption read tan tan noodles. How could this be, I thought. Tan tan is a ramen style (my favorite)... this is not ramen, heck its not even japanese. So I decided to give it a go.

I ordered the aforementioned tan tan noodles and a few other dishes as well. This place seemed to specialize in spicy dishes, which I like. Unfortunately all of the other dishes I ordered were not very good and I did not eat much of them. 

The tan tan noodles were actually pretty satisfying. It had a good spiciness to it and decent flavor. The ground meat was close enough to remind me of my favorite soup, although I wish there was more of it.

Despite that, this place was average at best and I will likely not be coming back. It was worth a shot though and I always enjoy trying new things.
author: Mark O.

description: I've eaten at this restaurant twice now, and I've left full and happy on both occasions. The Tan-Tan Noodles are exceptional, as are the beef pancakes. This is my new go-to Chinese spot in the Richmond District.
author: Andrew A.

description:
Got take out from them yesterday. Placed an order through Eat24 around 5:30p and the order was ready around 6p.

Fish filet with flaming chili oil ($18): A huge order! There were a lot of fish filets! I ordered this hot in regards to spice level but it wasn't really spicy at all. Got some of the numbing effect afterwards but I wanted some of that spicy flavor. Also this was packed horribly. It was in a take out container wrapped in tin foil. Thank god they put the container in a box since the oil completely spilled out of the container on the way home.

Steamed pork dumplings ($5.95): An order came with 6. The wrappers were the perfect thickness and texture. The dumplings also held up in the to go container and didn't break. All the soupy goodness stayed inside. Yum!

House special chow mein with Beef ($8.95): This dish had a good amount of beef. Noodles also had a nice chew.

Dry sauteed string beans ($8.95): I love string beans! Especially when they are dry fried. These may had suffered from being in a take out box since they were mushy when we got home.

Scallion pancake ($5.95): My least favorite dish. Not much scallions and the pancake was super oily and doughy.

Spicy dumpling ($5.95): Spicy and savory. I wasn't expecting the dish to have peanuts, but they weren't that prevalent so I still enjoyed the dumplings.

Other than the fish, the rest of the dishes were packed nicely. The lady helping me out was super nice. I'd love to try one of their spicy hot pots one day!
author: Elena N.

description: This place was amazing and iv had an amazing, authentic experience. The server David basically took our menu and picked out the dishes for us and they were all absolutely amazing. From Appetizer to desert to even wine it was delicious and not your average American Asian food. The best part, we didn't even break the bank! It came out to $25 / person with tip for 9 hungry hungry people. Would definitely recommend it!
author: Anoop M.

description: This place is like Woa!! Love it. We ordered 5 dishes, and finished almost everything . My favorite dishes are "cold noodles" and "couples delight"! Woa very good , must try! I get hungry again by talking about it . I'm actually planning to eat it again for dinner. Z&Y has better "couples delight" , but this place is also good. Eggplants good too. :P
author: Leilani M.

description:
First time here. My friend and I was there on Sunday around 2pm - a full house.  They had a very good business apparently.  Was the food good as well?  Let's check it out.

We didn't want to have a big meal, so just ordered the following and that's what we thought:

Vegetables (warm):  Dry Braised String Beans..................way tooooo salty!
Meat (Cold side dish) : Couple's Delight.............................way tooooo oily!
Appetizers (warm): Beef Roll Pancakes.............................not bad but not fantastic either.
Steam Buns (Shanghai Xiao Long Bao).............................An Ok for me but my friend said not good.  He is way more experienced on food than I do.
Drink (Cold to room temperature): Soy Milk.......................they advertised as self made but we saw it was poured out from a plastic bottle that we can find in the oriental grocery stores.

The first two dishes put us off guard and almost damaged our appetize.  They were way too salty for our tastes.  But, my friend said when he was invited by friends from mainland China to their house or to the restaurants they picked, the dishes were always very salty and oily.  Hey we eat salty food in other part of China region as well but NOT THAT SALTY and OILY!  So, maybe it was normal for them in mainland China but definitely not healthy.  "Couple's Delight" was supposed to have more oil than most of the dishes, but, the restaurant poured way too much oil for this style of dish.

Might not go back.
author: TG B.

description: I tried to get a table by signing in on paper sign in sheet. I noticed 15 minutes later that they combined 2 tables to seat 8 people. Then, I realized there weren't 8 people on the sign in sheet. There was a group before me too, and they seemed to wonder. So, I asked the hostess for help. She brushed me off. Then, lots of people came. I realized the paper sign up was a phony.
author: J J.

description:
Well before coming here i did some reading on yelp, let me say the most helpful tip was that they take reservations. When i walked in they were busy, and some people were waiting to get seated. One of the tables were reserved but the other table was occupied. So we had to wait til they were done and then we got the table in time. While i waiting for the group to arrive, i looked at the menu and prices were very reasonable. We did a group of 18 people, for a go away party for a friend. For the seating situation they had a round table that fits 10 and another round table that fits 8 people. We couldn't put the tables together for some reason anyways we split the group up into 2 round tables. Then we order separate orders for the 2 tables. In my table i was sitting with the foodies so we had ordered their popular dishes and the more authentic dishes too. 

PICKLED SALTY CABBAGE 
This dish is complimentary for each table. Its like a starter to munch on while your deciding what to order. It was salty and wasn't even sour. It had a weird taste to it too. It did look good but when i took a bite of it, i left it alone lol. and had to wash it down with water lol. 

DRUNKEN CHICKEN 
We started with the Drunken chicken. It was strong with an alcohol flavor. The chicken was tender and juicy. The presentation looked great too. We had a table of 8 in our table. We all had a pc or 2 and was enough.

SPICY CHILI COLD BEEF TENDON 
This dish was served chilled. The warm hot oil on the meat did made the meat luke warm. The meat was soaked up in the red orange chili oil which was mild. it was over a bed of chives which made the presentation of the dish look good. 

GINSENG SOUP 
The soup was served in a clay soup pot. The pot was traditional made out of ceramic. When the herb soup is serve in that tastes the best because it keeps warm and gives it extra temperature for the herb to come out into the soup. There were lots of herbs, ginseng, and chicken, and gogi berries floating on top. Everyone loved the soup, but didn't like eating the ginseng because it looked funny. To me this soup reminds me of my childhood memories growing up to all kinds of traditional herbal soup from the asian culture. 

SALTED EGG YOLK PRAWNS AND CORN 
This dish was definitely tasty! so they batter up the corn and prawns with some egg yolk and batter and then deep fry it. it was crisp all around and in every bite. Them kernel corns were so scrumptious! i did enjoy it a lot with my steam rice. 

STIR FRY PORK BELLY WITH CHIVES
This one was one of my favorites to pair with my steam rice. it was more on the salty side and it was flavorful. the pork belly did have lots of fat on it with the lean meat too. this dish did make me want to run an extra 5k to burn it off. The chives were also soaked into the sauce. I only had 2 pcs since i didn't want to get a bigger tummy lol. i do recommend this dish if you want to spoil that body. lol 

HOT POT CHILI OIL FILET FISH 
I am not sure what kind of fish it is. It did taste buttery so we were guessing its cat fish. The fish was inside a pot of chili oil. Also there were lots of dried chili peppers on top which they did help remove it once it got to the table. The fish was very tender and non spicy and bland. don't let the look of the dried chili pepper fool you on being it hot spicy. Also the fish was boneless so that was a plus. 

SWEET AND SOUR FISH WITH FRIED TOFU (AKA SECRET MENU)
Ok this dish was from previous experience. The fish was fried then soaked in chili oil to make it well done. The fish was crisp on the outer but inside it was mooshy. The presentation overall was a 10! it was served in a big white plate with fried tofu around the fish and then sweet and sour sauce drenched in the plate. The sweet and sour sauce was good. The fried tofu was crisp on the outside and inside of the tofu was soft and hot! overall this dish was so so to me. 

HONEY BITTERMELON 
This dish was thinly cut bitter melon and served chilled with a light honey sweet taste to it. The bitter melon was served over a bed of ice to keep it chilled and lightly topped with finely chopped red bell pepper. This dish was interesting and definitely the bitter melon was bitter! it was different and interesting and definitely good for ig, fb, or for social media pic. 

Overall they don't have large table to host a big parties. they only have 3 max table to host large parties. plenty of small tables which is a plus for smaller parties. The tables were wobbly. It was hot inside, Then they open the door to let the fresh bay breeze in and cool us down at the end. The food was oily overall, it felt like i was getting a heart attack with all the oil intake lol. Half of the dishes were ordered were kind of bland, but looks really tasty in pictures and it isn't. They did have good service on refilling water 3 times when it was getting low. Also they did include a 15% gratuity to the bill so we didn't have to tip since its included.
author: Alex T.

description:
Well, I still drive from east bay to here for Peking Duck. Last time I had it was a bit too hard (maybe because Chef Zhao left?? ), but until I found a better one, this is the one. Anyway, I have been to this restaurant maybe 50 times over the course of 4 years or so. The quality diminishes over the year. This is true to their sister store in Chinatown. Like it or not, I think they got spoiled by the customer. If you crave for something more authentic, I highly recommended spot. It use to be my first recommendation, but it slowly losing it. SAD!

If this is your first time, feel free to try different things. Food safety and cleanness seems to become a concern lately. Hope the owner can take this serious and spend more time on tidiness rather then how much money they make.
author: James M.

description: We ducked (ha) into Chili House & Peking Duck for weekend lunch not wanting to wait in line at some of the other dim sum places. They do have some nice dim sum on their menu and they offer many other dishes as well. They seated our family of five immediately and were super friendly and helpful. But the best part was that the food was just all so, so good! Their dry friend string beans and siu mai were the best I've ever had. Pot stickers were long and skinny which was different, and delicious. Soup dumplings were wonderful too. I would go back here in a second to dine, thank you!
author: j r.

description: Best Peking duck in SF for sure!  Also the selection & the various dishes are flavorful too!  Prices are what you pay for & you can get carried away with ordering but everything we had was so good.  Parking isn't great but you can get lucky.  The service was really good, staff was nice, & food was given quickly right after we ordered.  A nice place to go for occasions but make sure to reserve because this place gets packed.
author: Oliver Q.

description:
Awesome spot, had high expectations walking into this place, and they were met.
Had the poached beef, perfect spice level exactly 5/10 with a ton of awesome flavors to match. You don't really drink the broth because its hella spicy but the beef is perfect. They make rice pancakes here that are a lot like crepes but rubbery, liquid proof little guys that turn anything into finger food.
Had orange chicken, perfectly cooked chicken that was moist with a crispy shell. Flavors were bright and not too sweet. Service here was what you would expect, that being said Chinese culture is flagging down your server, they won't really ever come check on you. Just give them a wave and they come right over. It's a hard thing for me to do coming from fine dinning lol. Don't continue this activity in non Chinese restaurants tho lol.
Chili house is definitely doing it right and can't wait to come back to navigate this lengthy menu!
author: Nathan B.

description: Reviews here steered me wrong. The food is meh and the service is worse. I don't get it.
author: Michael A.

description: The waitress in charge of arranging tables had horrendous service. We made a reservation in advance. There were empty tables when we arrived, but she would not seat us because she insisted on putting two tables together horizontally instead of vertically. When we pointed out either way would provide enough room for the waiters to move through, she got offended and gave us a lot of attitude. She refused to explain and kept us waiting for much longer than necessary. She was either extremely inconsiderate or simply thoughtless. Either way, would have ruined our evening if not for the good food.
author: Jing Wei P.

description:
Everything I'm in San Francisco I always end up here because my sister loves their fish soup.  

We ordered the mustard greens spicy fish hot pot as per my sisters craving. It came with over 30 red and green chilies floating in a flavorful fish broth with lots of fish,  tofu, mushrooms,  bean sprouts and mustard greens. 

But other than this soup and the beef pancakes there isn't much else I can say was really good. Their hot and sour soup was neither as I remember. 

The soup dumplings were a dis service to shanghai food... flash frozen and then steamed over high heat so when we got it the outside was dry and the I side was still cold. 

Half the servers ignored us even when we flagged down. One server with glasses was great and consistent. Asked everyone for chili or hot sauce and never got it.  

Overall there's definitely better places to get Sichuan food in sf but I'd come back if my sister wants to.
author: Jannies L.

description:
4.5 stars really, but they get a 5 from me since I'm drooling just thinking about the dishes we ordered.

Chili House serves Szechuan food. I was quite scared since I couldn't feel my mouth the last time I tried Szechuan cuisine. However, Chili House's spiciness is not full-on flaming, it is also quite flavorful. We went for an early dinner around 5:30pm so it was quite empty when we arrived. However, I did notice the restaurant got quite full around 6-6:30, so it may be wise to make reservations beforehand as suggested by other reviewers.

We ordered the hot and sour soup, mapo tofu with pork, mushrooms with seasonal vegetables, tan tan noodles, fish filet, and the grilled lambchops with garlic. I definitely recommend the mapo tofu with pork, tan tan noodles, and the lambchops. All the dishes were good, but these three were absolutely delicious! The mapo tofu was flavorful and I loved the aftertaste burn. Same for the tan tan noodles, except it was also a bit sour. Don't let the color of the tan tan noodles scare you, you'll regret not trying it! The lambchops were extremely tender and so flavorful from the garlic and chili peppers.

There is street parking, but it may be challenging depending on when you go. Service was just average, like any other Chinese restaurant. We went in with a party of 6 and our bill came out to $72+. Pretty decent since we ordered 6 dishes too. If you're looking for good Szechuan food, this is the place to go! Can't wait to go back and try more dishes!
author: Kristi T.

description: Just saw today that they have a very bad health inspection report in the lower 5% as reported by Yelp. Yikes! Run!
author: Spoon G.

description:
Just ate here tonight with a good friend.  We were both so impressed with both the food and the service.  We asked the maitre'd/manager to choose the dishes for us since it was our first time there.  Had the xiao long bao (yum!),  this bun with beef and broth inside (also yum!), ma pop tofu and these other beef stir fry-like dish (yum and yum!).  I can't wait to come back and try other dishes and perhaps for dim sum, too.  

Excellent dinner!!
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Make reservations before going here!  It can get crowded and busy during peak dining hours - especially when the fog creeps into San Francisco!  

Chili House serves up Sichuan Chinese food that gradually makes your mouth feel the spiciness overtime!  

Bring a group instead of a plus one!  With so many dishes to choose from, it was too hard to resist just a few plates from the menu! 

Their (Dan Dan Mein) Egg Noodles in a bowl reminded me a lot like Z&Y's style on how they make theirs.  I feel like this place is somewhat affiliated with Z&Y (located in Chinatown, San Francisco) because of their decor and the food presentation.

I really liked their cold cucumber appetizer dish and Couple's Delight, which is a cold spicy beef starter!  Try to save some cold sliced up cucumbers for the main courses that are hot, hot, hot because it helps with calming down the spiciness.  The light vinegar taste to the cold cucumbers, helps to thin out the rich, spiciness of the other dishes!  The cold spicy beef platter is good, in general, throughout the meal!

I didn't care for their Mixed hot pot dish nor their Stir-Fried Rice Cakes.  Their mixed ingredients in the hot pot, didn't compliment well with each other and their rice cakes were soggy - not chewy textured at all.  I've had better so skip and order up other entrees.

Servers were hustling and bustling - our waiter came out with the wrong order as well as forgetting to bring me my vinegar when I asked for it.  Thumb down.  He even charged us for both orders so 2 thumbs down!

Other than that, we had plenty of spicy leftovers that can last us for a couple of meals.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
made it to my bookmarks - regular here...
loves - pork dumplings, chili chicken, duck, mapo tofu, etc
author: Richard C.

description: Came here for a Mother's Day dinner and the line was out the door. Luckily we had reservation and spent the next 2+ hours chowing down on the delicious food. The Peking Duck and tan tan noodles are highly recommended. We shall be back to try other dishes (with a reservation of course)
author: Rossi K.

description:
Another regular, here for dim sum. Tried the beef pancake from the menu. It tasted great. As usual ordered Xiao Long Bao and the Beijing Style Siu Mai is a must TRY. So tasty and juicy. I love the Chef here. Always impressed me with nice tasty food. 

11/14/2015: here yo try the Beijing duck. I gotta say is the best duck I ever have in San Francisco. Worth for waiting in line and for those interested pls call and book for the duck. Sold out Everyday. Very tasty and satisfying sauce on it. Yum!!! Thanks to Chef Zhao. I have wonderful lunch earlier.
author: Unyo N.

description:
We love this place!! 

We order from this restaurant at least twice a month. Our favorite menu items are the cold noodle, mapo tofu, and explosive chicken. I highly recommend this restaurant, especially of enjoy spicy food!
author: Wendy D.

description:
Make a reservation online saves tons of time for you! Make sure you call the restaurant after reservation and let them know earlier if you want roasted duck. 
Mapo (spicy) tofu was really good, out of all five dishes we tried. Rice is a little expensive than most place.
author: Hannah C.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

0/1 Star: street parking wasn't too hard to find, but I might have gotten lucky. 15 minute wait for a group of 7. 

_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

1/1 Star: service was normal. Clean. Nice Asian Ambiance.

_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

2/3 Stars: food was good but spicy. 

_____

Overall Experience

3/5 Stars 

_____

Last Words
Hot hot hot
author: Elliott N.

description: I ordered the tea smoked duck. The skin was crispy and the flavor was great. I eat a lot and for less than 20 usd I've got a nice dinner with left overs.
author: Dona M.

description: Horrible experience at this restaurant. Good food but can't compensate for the worst, demeaning and somewhat racist service of my life. When my family and I walked in, my mother wanted to sit at a table in the front because it's dark and dim in the back. The hostess rolled her eyes and sighed three separate times when my mother requested another table because it troubled her to take an extra minute to explain that she needed the two front tables for larger parties later on. Funny thing is she sat two people at each of those two front tables later on and not any larger parties. After being seated by the rude hostess, our waiter came by and started yelling at my American boyfriend because my boyfriend accidentally poured the tea before it was fully infused and ready. He then rudely assumed and spoke out, "You must be Dutch." to my boyfriend, basing off of his blonde hair and skin color, as to insult my boyfriend for not knowing Asian customs or how to correctly pour tea because he's Caucasian. The waiter and hostess were both so eager to make everything go faster that they didn't care about what the customers wanted. And if that isn't bad enough, the waiter tried to repeatedly defend his racist comment and his poor, rushed and inconsiderate service. They will not be getting our business again and if they don't correct their service, they will be losing more business in the future, too.
author: Sylvia Y.

description: At chili house we only got chopsticks and when I asked for some forks they said they had no forks!! Also our table was all wet and weird. The fried rice had no soy sauce so no flavor. But excluding all that the food was great.
author: Arin K.

description:
Excellent hidden gem! We went here for lunch this past weekend and absolutely loved it. Food is excellent and service is quick. Must try the 1000 chili chicken which will blow your mind with the aftertaste. The boiled pork was delish as well.

I'm forgetting our server's name but he was just too good. Took control and gave us excellent recommendations during the entire meal. He was also quick to act when a friend dropped some soup on her shirt by getting us hot water and a towel.

Must try!
author: Kabir S.

description: Did not try pekking duck yet. Order house special fried rice and beef wrap which are delicious. But porkbelly takes too long to cook and tastes just ok. But what bothers me the most is service and attitude.
author: Sanguan L.

description:
I have this one friend that loves spicy food so much. She has a hard time finding a good place that just for her liking.  This place has spiced up her life and I think it will spicy up yours as well.   This looks like your typical Chinese restaurant but their menu is truly a szechuan place.   

This place does get crowded but if you get here early enough you can get a table.  I've ordered a few items here before so allow me to break it down for you

Beef Pancake- i guess i didn't like this dish because i didn't like the way the beef was prepared.  The beef is sliced up and rolled up into the dough.  I was hoping the beef was going to be minced.  

String Beans- there is no way anyone can mess up this dish and they didn't.  It came with chili peppers and it made it super tasty

Spicy wontons- I didn't quite like this dish, i didn't like the ingredients that was inside.  This however, was a very spicy dish, so if you want that extra kick you should order this dish.  

Couple's Delight - this was a cold dish, i believe it was spicy tendon,  It's pretty good and it's best to eat this with rice

Fish Filet with Flaming Chili Oil- This is a dish there the fish filet is in a soup of chili oil, so start fishing! This dish may look very spicy, but it wasn't extreme.  You can tell them to make it mild if you want.  Again another good dish to be served with white rice. 

Prawns with Salty Egg Yolk- this was by far my most favorite dish,  The prawns are in this light battered and this dish comes with fried corn kernels.  Yes each kernel was covered with batter, it was so good.  I doubt you can get this just by itself, but the next time i go i will try to just order that.  

The service here is also pretty good and parking is usually never a  problem after 6.   I tried to place an order on my phone but I think their site is not mobile friendly, so i made my order over the phone.  Overall, this is turning out to be one of my favorite places in SF.
author: Belinda C.

description:
A very solid, inexpensive option for good Chinese in the Inner Richmond area.  I stopped by for lunch coming from Marin County on my way to SFO and was not disappointed.  I was served hot & sour soup, a pseudo-kimchee type of side, and hot tea as soon as I sat down.  The lunch menu prices are extremely reasonable ($7 includes the entree, rice, and the soup, pseudo-kimchee, and tea).  I was able to try two options - the mapo tofu and the eggplant with garlic sauce.  

The mapo tofu was very good, but not any better than what I make at home or any decent Chinese place.  It was flavored well, the sauce was the right thickness and not too salty.  The tofu quality was average and tasted like it was from Safeway.  But overall the dish was everything you can ask for.  

The eggplant with garlic sauce caught me off-guard as I was expecting eggplant stir-fried with sauce, not eggplant cutlets that were fully battered and deep fried.  It tasted great and the garlic sauce with sliced carrots and bamboo shoots was also very tasty.  But I wasn't really in the mood for the deep fried eggplant and the abundance of oil that I tasted in each bite.
