I will definitely come back here again to try some other dishes.  The restaurant was clean and service was friendly.
author: Amoli P.

description: Food is good but it took 20 min to get our first dish and another 10 min later our Shiao Long Bao. It's worth the wait if you don't have wiggly kids and some place to go.
author: Elizabeth F.

description: Great food and good service.My recommendation is the Szechuan Tan Tan Noodle and Poached Fish.
author: Teresa C.

description: This was one of the greatest dining experiences I have had in the SF Bay Area. Our humorous waiter David ordered for our group of 15 and every item brought out was better than the last. Buns, dumplings, spicy chicken, eggplant, and wow, wow, wow the whole duck. I love this place.
author: Dave J.

description:
After we were done ordering, I noticed everyone around us ordered the at-the-table carved whole duck. The thing looked delicious. It was steamy and so fresh looking, like me after a hot shower. Everything we ordered I'd say was a little bit above average for chinese/taiwanese food. The server was attentive and courteous. 
Only thing is, as we were exiting, my mom saw pre packed pastries on top of the flower shelf and wanted to buy a box or two for breakfast. When she asked how much they were, the waitress said "$3". The waiter came and put two boxes in a bag, he asks my mom for $14. We had an enjoyable dinner, so my mom let it go and paid the man $14 instead of $6. Oh well.
author: Kev L.

description:
I with my friends ordered Peking duck for lunch at restaurant today. We waited more than an hour for that due to special order. I expect this order will be very good. However, very disappointed of that, when serving , the DUCK was COLD ! ! !  We waited for one hour to eat that COLD DUCK and without any services too. 
I also want to remind this restaurant, some of dishes have lipgloss on there still for customers to used ! 
Anyway, never try again.
author: C C.

description: Another Delicious night at Chili House, the eggplant and basil, so good, cold noodle salad cools down the spicy, explosive chicken!!  We eat here often, always good.
author: Carole W.

description: Easily one of the best Chinese meals I have had in a long time! The restaurant is in Richmond, but don't expect too much by way of atmosphere on the inside - this is all about the food! I'm not much for spicy food, which some may think makes this place a waste to visit, but I ordered a mild satay beef which was perfect! Worth the visit!
author: David P.

description:
A pleasant "Sit anywhere you like" as I got to this joint for the first time. I was excited as I love discovering Sichuan places which I found through some quick yelp research. 

I order my two favorite dishes spicy chongqing chicken and "water-boiled" fish. Mouth numbing Sichuan peppers check, mounds of red chili peppers check, but the taste?  The only way I can describe it is it had a very home-cooked feeling and taste.  Like a friend's mom might make. Although the taste was alright. The chicken flavor lacked depth, maybe because they seemed to use a lot of white meat and this time on the verge of being under cooked. Not the darker color and richer flavors of somewhere like Z&Y restaurant. The fish dish was also not on point.  It had a slight fishy after taste that made me doubt it's freshness. 

But all that said it still fulfilled my Sichuan craving. Come here for a solid and homey meal. But if you want a little more refinement and richness of flavor try others like Taste of Formosa, Z&Y, China Village in the east bay, or even Mama Ji's in the Castro. 

Happy eating!
author: Kenji H.

description: Sichuan food is really good. However, Beijing duck is just so so. The hairs are not removed well. Highly recommend the spicy dishes.
author: Jing L.

description:
Service was outstanding. We arrived 1/2 hour early and our 2 tables were ready for us. One table had more children than the other so we ordered more age appropriate dishes for each table. The skin on the Peking Duck was perfect... the meat was a little on the dry side and needed a little more seasoning. My favorite was the steam sea bass and the Szechuan fish with flaming chili oil. The basil clam was another good seafood dish.

My best comment is the service was 5 star for my party of 15 for mother's day dinner.
author: Kmaintl L.

description:
I came for the Peking duck as every one was commenting about it, I think they pass, but the wrapping needs improvement. Great China in Berkeley still has the best wrapping, the hoi sin sauces is a little on the salty side, I don't know what they add in it, the color is darker from the
one I bought from the store.
author: Helena Y.

description: You will never miss for having spicy food.  I went there for lunch. The spicy chicken wing is tasty and crispy. I enjoyed the tofu fish. I did not have enough time for the Peking duck but I saw everyone ordered one. Service was good. Will come back if I have a chance. 4 stars at this moment.
author: Katherine L.

description:
Had high hopes for this Szechuan spot in "new Chinatown," came with my half-Szechuanese mom and brother.

Got the whole catfish and noodles, which was supposedly fresh/alive when we ordered but this is suspect. Sweet instead of spicy really, but the fish was still pretty good and at least the noodles weren't overcooked. 

The beef pancake roll was flavorful with some fresh cucumbers and sweet sauce but damn it was doughy and kinda raw :(

Service was insincere and food took a really long time. The kitchen forgot one of our dishes, but we didn't wanna stay anyway.
author: Vivian H.

description: Bad attitude cashier lady. She willing get mad with the customer even the waiter get wrong order. Then she told me that next time I should be careful when I order. Next time????? Yes lady it won't happen again. I'm promised because I'll never come back again. This's not my first times here but I know this's my last times. Very very bad attitude lady!!!!
author: Lynn T.

description: The duck, chili fish, tofu, and veggies are soooo good! The manager was so nice and kept coming to us to ask if everything was good. Though the service can be rushed at times, it's understandable because they have to serve such a large volume. When I come back to SF, I'll for sure come back to try other items :)
author: Christine L.

description:
Came here for the Beijing Duck and man, it really hit the spot. 

The menu is quite extensive but like the basic Chinese family, we ordered all the staples: Mapo Tofu, Shanghai Dumplings (XLB), and Beijing Duck...and everything was super delicious. The duck comes with the wraps, sauce, and cucumbers, etc for you to eat to your hearts content! Also they cut the duck right in front of you which was kind of fun haha. 

The only reason I docked a star was the service was pretty slow/bad as it is at a lot of Chinese restaurants. We were seated in a little corner and it took so long to flag down a waiter every time we needed something. But the food was sooooo good would definitely come again.
author: Jingxi Z.

description:
Came in here at around 12:20pm, not a lot of people which is good. A waitress seated us and offered the menu right away.
We ordered there items.
First one is beef stew noodles, my wife picked it and she didn't like it at all. The broth tastes awful.
I ordered "spicy boiled pork" which is good, but the "beef pancake" is a bit too salty and firm to bite.
Talking about the service, the waitress is nice and professional, but another guy server is kind of rude.
Maybe there are certain dishes that are really good here, but probably won't come back since there tons of choices in SF.
author: Wei Z.

description: The food is great, awesome actually, uniquely authentic. But the cooking time is kind of long and they are short on waiters. We were waiting there for 10+ minutes before we could just get someone to get our bill .be prepared for a long wait if you're hungry, but the wait is worth it!
author: Olivia Z.

description:
Chili House is an interesting place. It's a different style of Szechuan food than you typically find though my lack of culture only vaguely understands the differences. 

It's spacious, and we've thrown larger parties here before with set courses and a lot of bourbon. 

Bad: The beef rolls. These are one of my favorite, comfort dishes and they flat out suck here. Go to Dong Bei Mama for them. 

Decent: Minced pork wraps, sliced pork and garlic, spicy wontons. 

Absolutely must get: Dan dan mien. The main reason I keep coming back here is for this dish. It's hands down the best version of these noodles I've ever had and something I've introduced many friends to. 
Another favorite is the pumpkin soup served in a coconut shell. It was hot and savory and comforting and we absolutely did not pour some bourbon in there. 


Overall I would have given Chili house 3 stars as a standard place to eat if you're in the area, but their Dan Dan Mien really is that good and I crave it every rainy now and then.
author: Jonathan Y.

description: Three of us came here for dinner on a Monday night for a 615 reservation (yes, they're on open table!) and it was fairly busy at the time and filled up within 30 minutes or so. There were large families at three round tables, mostly two tops and some singles. I was very excited to try this place because Peking Duck is one of my fave dishes and I've had take out at their sister restaurant, Z&Y many times and love their food. We ordered the Hot & Sour Soup, Szechuan Cold Noodles, Silky Tofu with Fish in Chili Oil and Peking Duck. We did not call ahead for the duck but we lucked out and they were able to make it for us. We gladly waited the 45 minutes and it did not disappoint. The duck was juicy and delicately carved tableside like we had experienced in Beijing. Since it is a northern tradition to eat it without the bun, they served it with pancakes, cucumbers and green onions. I couldn't believe how thin and soft the pancakes were and they peeled easily and didn't get punctured. They have some master making them in the kitchen. The pancakes held up well even after being filled with hoisin sauce, duck and the garnishments. It was definitely tasty Peking Duck. Based on the inflection of our server's tone when she asked if we wanted a small or medium sized soup, we went with the medium and it turned out to be huge. We did finish the whole thing by the end of the night. The Hot & Sour Soup had good flavors melded together and the right consistency, not too thick or thin with the eggs scrambled correctly and the perfect brown color, all factors that one should judge it on. Steve and I love spicy food and my friend likes it a little but it can make him sick. I could sense his anticipation as the red goodness reached the table. As he took a few bites of the Fish & Tofu, he commented that it was good, with a numbing effect and didn't burn his stomach so we had a winning dish! The Cold Noodles were delish, just like at Z&Y. The menu here has more to offer than their sister restaurant. We'll be back with a bigger crowd because a whole duck to ourselves was overwhelming and I want to try now things. On this first visit, we did order the right amount of food choices. We polished it off except for all the duck and bones. I should mention you can have the duck bones cooked in soup or fried. We went with fried and they sprinkled the special salt & pepper seasoning on it. It was very good as well. Oh and the service is good. They were friendly and attentive. They refilled water and actually checked on us which is hard to come by at most Chinese restaurants.
author: Jen L.

description:
after a walk at Lands End, Mom and I went there for a quick lunch.  almost 1:30pm, few customers, we ordered Dong Po Pork, Shanghai Pork dumpling, Beijing sauced noodles.  
fast service, dishes looked very fancy and they did taste really fabulous!!!  end up, we ordered more dishes to go, pack fast and nice.  will be back soon for the No. 1 Peking duck!!!
author: Yumi H.

description: Enjoyed Dim Sum (Shumai, rolled beef pancake and basil clams) then Peking Duck.  Carved table side, lovely presentation, and delicious!
author: Christine W.

description: Our dinner was delicious.   The soup dumplings were so good and I loved the crispy prawns.  The had some crab dish that was very flavorful, but hard to eat and messy.  We shared a few spicy dishes that were very good, just a little spicy former.  If we lived here, we would go back.
author: Emily W.

description: Thought the food and service were both very good ! Maybe could use a little more garlic and more numbing spice but no complaints! Had the tan tan noodles, explosive chicken, dry fried green beans and the half off yelp dumplings. Waitstaff was super courteous too!
author: Gregg C.

description:
This place makes the BEST spicy wontons but it's a bad idea if you plan to go out after dinner if you know what I mean.... Worth it still if you do plan to ;). Everything I have tried here did not disappoint:

Mapo tofu
Xiao long bao
Sauteed green beans 

I usually don't deviate much from these items (because they are soooo good) but the last time I came here I saw a lot tables ordering the peking duck! Must be new because I came here many times and never saw it on the menu. The chef comes out to cut the duck in front of everyone so that was interesting to watch. Since there were only two of us, there was no way we were going to finish a whole duck! Maybe next time. Be prepared to wait on a Saturday night- it was about a 40 minute wait for two people!
author: Karmen T.

description:
One of the best Sichuan restaurants in the city. On the "nicer" side for Chinese restaurants.

Personal Favorites:
1. Grilled Fish Fillet - A giant solid piece of fried fish fillet. Perfectly fried: light, soft, juicy, and dry rubbed with Sichuan numbing peppery goodness.
2. Mapo Tofu - A Sichuan staple. Full of flavor and it's actually spicy, which is rare. Tons of that numbing spice.

Other than my top two, all Sichuan staples are solid: cold beef cuts, dandan noodles, spicy wonton, stir fry veggies.
author: Nop J.

description: New player in town. Quality, flavorful Sichuan food. The utensils/plates might not be the cleanest, but my mouth isn't that clean either.
author: Michael L.

description:
This place is the bomb. 

Great service, good value, never a long wait if one at all, and most importantly tasty as hell. 

I've been here probably 10 times now, and it's been great everytime. Here are some quick recommendations: 

- The cold chicken (delicious)
- Salty egg shrimp (hold crap.. so good)
- Whole fish with spicy noodles (so much food, so little money)

Things to stay away from

- Shanghai dumplings (these were pretty meh, not terrible, but if you're at a place named chilli house, order something spicy for goodness sake). 

Bottom line: Food here is bomb, pretty cheap (not hole in the wall cheap, but affordable for sure), and the service is as good as you could hope for with a Chinese restaurant. If you order any of the dishes that are spicy, you will not be disappointed.
author: Kevin W.

description: Excellent Peking duck, sliced by your table so everyone can see. Only thing I wish they served with the duck were buns instead of thin wrappers.  This place is good and you wouldn't know it by looking at it from the street. Staff were super nice to our young kids, even made makeshift kiddie chopsticks for them so they could try and eat like the adults.  All around good experience.
author: a c.

description: So good! Very authentic. Service is out of this world compared to other Chinese restaurants. Highly recommend and will come back for sure!
author: Lucille H.

description:
Hands down, since the Empress of China restaurant in Chinatown closed, Chili House is THE BEST CHINESE FOOD IN SAN FRANCISCO!!!  

My husband and I both love going here.  I've used their food for workshops, family gatherings, etc. and you can TASTE THE LOVE that Chef Han puts into his food.  Open until 10p.m. this place is amazing!

If you go with two or more people, try the price fixe menu that starts with the won ton soup, basil chicken, beef chow mein, lightly breaded prawns, steamed dumplings!  THE BEST!
author: Alacrity I.

description:
The food was generally good, some of them could be very salty.
The service was horrible. There's no hand soup, no toilet cover and no tissues. The waiters were always busy and impatient with no smile on their faces. We didn't get ice water and rice until we almost finished. 
Don't think I will come again for we got so many other options.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
Basically had a TERRIBLE first experience here. The waiter semi made up for it with great service, but what happened before I sat down left a really bitter taste. Never have I ever been more appalled at the severe lack of professionalism at a restaurant. I also completely understand that Chinese restaurants are not known for their service, but this level of disregard and disrespect has never happened to me.

As I stepped in, there were about 2 parties ahead of us. We wrote our name down. I looked around, and there were a bounty of empty tables with the restaurant (think a half empty restaurant). I definitely do not mind waiting for a table, but the fact that my bf and I sat there for ~30 minutes with no one coming to explain that either 1) the tables were reserved and the parties are coming soon or 2) ???. I don't even know what a second scenario would be. Fine. I decided to give them the benefit of the doubt that there was a huge party occupying half the restaurant soon. Then, a group of 4 Caucasian people came in and wrote their names down. Very soon after, a waiter goes over and asks how many people they have. After around another 10 minutes, they sit the 4 people down when there were clearly 2 parties of 2 (us and another couple) who came here WELL before they did. When I asked why they seated the 4 people ahead of us and showed him our names on the paper, he completely ignored me and didn't even look me in the eye and apologize! I really really dislike playing race cards but what made him magically IGNORE the sign-up board in front of him and just seat them ahead of us? Instead, he walked away hastily pretending nothing happened. I'm not sure why this man decided to seat 4 people over us when we were waiting for a good 40 minutes in a half empty restaurant (remember that I gave them a huge benefit of the doubt that there was a banquet coming in which is why they didn't want to occupy that half of the restaurant). 

Thankfully, a more sensible worker saw what happened, (who eventually was my waiter) apologized and asked if we wanted to be seated. He offered us free drinks and honored the Yelp Check-In deal. The actual food we ordered was good. The chili was on point, but there was a lack of flavor depth. I would've probably given 3 stars for solely the food.

I still must give this place a 1 star because it was easily in one of the worst experiences I've had in a restaurant. If you totally oversaw us for 40 minutes, fine. But the worker who decided to completely ignore us was completely unprofessional and unapologetic. If any managers of Chili House are reading this, I suggest you create a better system / process for those waiting for a table.
author: Claudia C.

description: With a name like explosive chicken, you get a little scared and want to check their food safety score.  But it is one of the prettiest presentations i've ever seen, and the taste matched it!!  The dry green beens with fermented black been was excellent, the fried pork pancakes where unbelievable!  Light flaky and dripping with flavor, like a shanghai soup dumpling!
author: Vinh N.

description: Service was polite, but the Peking duck was not crispy at all, I would prefer Cantonese style roast duck. Will be back to try other dishes but not Peking duck again.
author: Shan S.

description: THIS PLACE IS NASTY!! We were here yesterday with my friends and we found HAIRS not on one BUT on TWO of the dishes!!! The waiter didn't even apologize! He just walked away with our food to bring it back to the kitchen. BAD SERVICE, the food is bland and not handled well hence the HAIRS on our food! Don't eat here unless you want a hairball in your throat at the end of your meal!
author: Vanessa A.

description: Great Peking Duck.  We were lucky that they were able to give it to us since you have to reserve it in advance.  Shumai were also excellent.  The soup dumplings were so-so.  Thick skin and not a lot of soup.  We also ordered the spicy dumplings, but this was not my choice.  They had a strong ginger taste and were drenched in hot oil, but this is probably how they are supposed to be.
author: Pasha G.

description: Food was amazing!! I ordered the spicy dumplings which was 50% off when you check into yelp. Another great dish I would recommend Beef cumin. Perfectly cooked (two thumbs up)! As far as cold apps go, couples delight (thins slices of pork belly in hot oil) is the way to go! Service was on par.
author: Jenn L.

description: The dim sums were to die for, service is awful, authentic Chinese food- will definitely go back again.
author: Sheena B.

description:
Decent food. Unfriendly, scattered service.  cute, painted waitress...no eye contact, no smiles, no greeting.  ordered a large soup and house chowmein ...large bowl delivered with ladle; no spoon, no smaller bowl, no utensils. five minus later, I waved down a different server  and asked for bowl and spoon. five minus later, both servers put bowls and spoons on table without a word.   A friendly "host"? Owner? rushed by smiling and asked "have you been served yet??"  (food was on the table).  Wor wonton was a little watery/bland...broth not much flavor...chowmein was excellent.

The place seems popular. there is a lot of compete ion in the area.  The owner or manager needs to rethink the service.  There are many trained servers looking for work. Unfriendly doesn't cut it. Cute is not enough. People need to feel welcome.
author: William S.

description:
Cabbage pork dumplings very bland
Fried rice very good. Not too oily
Fried pancake ok
Large tables ordered hold back in cars that table apparently that's really good but there was only two of us so no duck, and they were out of the duck buns which we were looking forward to trying
author: Amie B.

description:
Everything I've tried here is good. But the spicy dumplings and the tan tan noodles are TO DIE FOR. I crave it and will trek from the peninsula to get my fix. So good! 

It's busy all the time. I strongly recommend making a reservation. Especially if you want the duck. Service is a bit slow but by then I'm in a food coma and I don't care. Getting the check is always a task.
author: bree m.

description: Came here on Christmas Day because Chinese r always open including Christmas haha... Since it's chili house we were afraid it's gonna be too spicy because we can't eat spicy food too much... When we ordered, i told them to give us the Smallest amount of spice possible! I was still expecting it spicy because usually when you go to Chinese spicy restaurant it will be HOT even if u don't want any spicy. To my surprise it was the perfect amount of spiciness !!!  Everything was pretty good, but they charge u for rice, which I guess is the thing to do in north cal ... I think they charge 1.75 per rice bowl~ So if you got 4 people, you might as well order a fried rice !!
author: C L.

description: The hubby and I went here for the peking duck and I've got to say I don't think I'll go back for the duck.  SO - IF you are going to go for the PEKING DUCK ... YOU MUST CALL AHEAD AND RESERVE IT AHEAD otherwise you MAY HAVE TO WAIT 45 minutes for your duck!  The 2 stars for the duck is simply for the fact that I had to do absolutely NO work prepping it ... it's all cut up and ready to eat!  I liked that they skinny slice their green onions and I absolutely LOVED their super fresh "pancake" wraps...the duck itself was MEH ... the skin was NOT crispy at all!!! Isn't peking duck suppose to have crispy skin??!??!?!!?!?  and although they give you a choice of salt and pepper stir fry or soup with the duck bones ~ it was not that good.  We also got the Yelp check-in half off XLB - which wasn't that tasty, we didn't finish it.  Perhaps we ordered the wrong items ???? The noodle dish the table over had looked really good  ~~ as did the green veggies ~~ perhaps we'll go back and try those dishes ... but I don't think I'll go back for the duck or the XLB again!!!
author: Bravo J.

description:
I've been here before and i'm not sure what has changed since 2-3 months ago but things definitely are different.  Craving for some spicy noodle and the closest restaurant that still in business is this place so we went.

First service from the waiter/waitress is pretty bad. And we came here just for lunch(because within the 2-3 blocks basically a lot of other chinese restaurants went out of business).  They didn't give us the usual lunch menu but only more expensive dish menu.   The spicy duck wings appetitizer are no longer given.  we order 2 noodle bowls and a xiaolongbao.
Xiaolongbao taste just okay, but 3/6 are broken, all the soup inside spill out.  For the yunnan traditional noodle , they didn't even ask you for spiciness(which i forgot to tell them also, but the waiter should have ask)

I would give them a 4 before, but more like a high 2 to 3 for now
author: Eric C.

description:
Let's cut right to the chase- Order the Peking Duck. Everything about it was great - the wrap was thin, but chewy, duck was juicy, and the best part is that they take the duck bones and make it into a delicious soup afterwards! You can honestly just order that and have a great meal. 

We also ordered the fish fillet boiled in chili oil, and that was a great dish as well. It comes in a big pot and the staff will scoop out the chili peppers upon serving the dish. Fish was tender and it was perfectly spicy!

The only dish that didn't wow me was the fried string beans. 

For a party of 3 people, the three dishes was more than enough. We were incredibly full afterwards, and feel like we would be satisfied with just the duck and the fish fillet. 

The place does get packed (like all the good places in SF), so expect a bit of a wait even if you made a reservation. The restaurant was brightly lite and looks clean.
author: Sherry C.

description:
Wow! This place...I'll definitely be back! 

Let me start with the most important part: this place has the best noodles I've ever had. Period. Their tan tan noodles are made of magic and chili oil and raw concentrated tastiness. 

Chili house is a great place for big groups; you can do the family style dining and try a bunch of different things. 

I ate here alone. Plates are humongous. It's still a good deal to do that - just plan to leave with leftovers :). 

Their tan tan noodles, man. Their noodles. 

I also got the chicken with explosive peppers. Too funny of a name to pass up. I later noticed all of the Chinese families (the entire rest of the restaurants patrons - a good sign!!) also had an order of this. It's tasty, no doubt...but I also don't really know what to do with it. Can anyone really eat this many peppers? It seems like a hilarious joke, like they just kept dumping peppers onto a plate and then tossed some chicken in for giggles. Fortunately the peppers aren't insanely hot (I think they may've used some of the numbing peppers too). 

And man. The tan tan noodles. So good.
author: Chris S.

description:
I honestly never write negative reviews, but I feel like at some point the owner needs to know because they're the ones investing money into this business. My coworker and I walked in Friday night around 745pm. We live in presidio, and frequent the clement area and had never seen this place, so we walked in. There was some sort of engagement party going on so 2 big round tables were full, but they were starting to leave 10 mins after we arrived. 15 mins later there are a 3 tables( 4 seaters) that were empty, but yet the waiters were not seating us, or the 3 other people waiting behind us. 3 younger waiters literally walked around just chit- chatting, and one older waiter was talking to a large table for the most part we were there. Finally after 55 minutes, we were seated along with the other 3 waiting people. We were happy, finally we could order, actually we had already looked at the menu, so we knew what we wanted. So now we're waiting, trying to flag wait staff and they just say hold on. Well the 3 waiters are just talking, laughing and standing around, not even a simple glass of water. Now after patiently waiting for 25 minutes, nothing. Even the other people who walked in were still waiting to even get a glass of water. At that point we had walked out and the older waiter stopped us and said why you leaving, we explained, and he just shrugs his shoulders, and we leave. 
     I hope management sees this review, and hires restaurant undercover or put in some cameras so they can see for themselves what goes on in this place.
author: renee m.

description:
Had high expectations for Chili House. But I have to say Dong Bei Mama on Geary is much better! 

Ordered:
Beef pancake wrap/roll
Spicy beef tendon
Bitter melon w/ honey
Spicy wontons
Cumin lamb
Garlic pea sprouts
Total: $64 (add 3x rice, 1x sprite, to-go containers/bag, tax)

Quality was ok on everything. But portions were disproportionate. Beef wraps were tiny. Tendons were huge. Lamb was moderate. Seems the cold appetizers were in bigger plates than the entrees. 

Although customer service was nice and friendly, food service was very slow. Entrees came out before appetizer dishes and cold dishes. Ate the meal a little backwards.
author: Stephen Y.

description: So ono! The chicken with explosive chili peppers is fiyah! Had a nice Christmas lunch with my love!
author: K S.

description: Food off the hook, HOT, HOT!!! Will return for the BURN!! SPICY princess chicken wings (house special), spicy Tofu, and spicy garlic crab.. One love!!! Island love to the cook..
author: Anthony M.

description:
Hm... I am really torn about what to say for this review since it was very good, but I was also somewhat filled with regret afterwards. I was ravenous after getting a haircut in a salon nearby, and happened upon this spot since it was the only one open. I'd consider myself a smaller Asian girl, but I ordered 2 different dishes just for myself because everything on the menu looked good, and reading the reviews here on Yelp was making it hard to trim down my options.

Anyway, I ended up with the chili dumplings and the tan tan mian (noodles). Each bite was delicious and chili-oily and filling, until about halfway through the meal where I realized both things I ordered were pretty much the same flavor, and I probably should have ordered some veggies to make it a bit healthier and more balanced. I felt like after devouring all that, I could have cried tears of oil. All in all, food was great and I'd order again, but my only regret was eating too much too quickly, and not having enough veggies in my selection of dishes. Also, if you eat here, try not to wear anything white or that you'd be upset ruining, as the risk of staining your clothes with the chili oil is very high!
author: Nancy W.

description: Super delicious good, i would love to go again when i come back to San Jose
author: Anderson L.

description:
The service was bad. We waited a long time to be seated. There were empty tables but there just weren't enough workers to clean the tables and get people seated quickly. After being seated and was ready to order, it was hard getting their attention to take our order.. & We asked for water and rice over 3 times but they kept forgetting to..

The portions were good and the food all tasted good. but after, I felt really gross and oily. I was really thirsty the whole night, then realized they probably put a lot of MSG in their food..
author: Tina S.

description: Looks like the only thing that is pretty good is the Pecking duck, everything else is average or below average, you can find better Szechuan restaurant easily in the city. (for example, Spices on 6th Ave.)
author: Jerry Y.

description: Ordered take-out from here. Got the dry green beans and asked for them to be spicy and added fried tofu. Lots of garlic and red chilies. Also got a side of rice. Really liked it, however 15.99 for string beans with tofu is a bit steep. This place is a block from me so it's extremely convenient. Given that it was good I will be back to try the beef pancake, and the spicy noodles which looked great. I'm a huge fan of spicy food so that is a huge draw for me.
author: Thielson D.

description:
So you go to CHILI house, and it really is CHILI house.

My mouth was on fire for a while. 

We ordered 4 dishes and that made our mouths burn like no other.

The waiter helped us order some mild menu items and sure enough it tasted like someone put chili's on our tongues and just left them there.

He told us the chefs turned it down a bit, so I would be surprised to see what hot really was. 

We ordered a beef cake which was delicious. (tasted like a pho wrap)
Cold udon noodle like things that were spicy.
Drunken chicken...maybe best for the very asian minded person.
And a beef soup that tasted like great balls of fire.

Try something different and head to this place, there are many unique dishes that you are bound to fall in love. 

I left my credit card there so now I have to drive up to San Fran to pick it up, but they are nice enough to hold it for me.
author: Vince N.

description: This place was a real mixed bag. The spicy wontons were great, maybe the best I've had in SF. The XLB were so-so. The mapo tofu was disappointing - I've heard that it was supposed to be good here, but it was all heat and Sichuan peppercorn and very little other flavor. Bummer.
author: Jo B.

description: suan cai yu and xiang la zhu ti are good! The dishes come in a large portion!
author: Yunzhu C.

description:
Dare I say this place is actually better than Z&Y? I feel like they are affiliated because of similar decor but either way still delicious!

Definitely get the cold noodles with cucumber and peanut sauce. That was a lot better than the tan tan mein, which was poorly seasoned compared to all the other dishes. 

I'm also a huge fan of the fried chicken bits buried in red chili, the fried eggplant, the green beans, the poached white fish that comes out in a hotpot. 

Ma po tofu was solid but because everything else was so good, it wasn't as notable.  Go with groups so you can try new things!!
author: Anna T.

description:
First, long wait, and hectic service.

Second, advertised combo meals were "not available during holidays".  We were there for lunch on Xmas Eve.

Third, we explicitly asked for "no hot spice" for our pork sandwiches, and they came in with chopped green chilies in them, which completely ruined our appetite.  

Not going back.
author: Jane C.

description: Don't bother with reservations. They ignore them. We found that out after waiting for 30 minutes after our reserved time with no seating and no eta. Terrible service. Food smelled good but disrespect of customers isn't worth it.
author: Shannon V.

description: I ate a bunch of spicy dishes here, cause how you gonna go to a place named Chili House and not? Wasn't too spicy on the departure the next day, so I'm going to put this place at intermediate level in terms of spice.
author: John B.

description:
Chili House. You're supposed to be spicy but instead you left me mild. Props to the tan tan noodle but everything else was..meh?

Ma Pao Tofu - you really can't mess up on that. 
Pork with Garlic and Spicy Sauce - not sure if the pork was cooked 
Spicy Dumplings - you were A OK.

I thought the prices were a bit steep for chinese food esp in SF where it's fairly competitive.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Chili House deserves more than a "A-OK", but not a "Yay! I'm a fan" -- something along the lines of surely a place one can eat at, but not be gung ho about.

Seating is prompt, water is served as you're still settling into the chair, the menu is set in front of you and they give you a minute or two before they return.

Tables are clean, serving ware, eating utensils, and sauce bottles etc are clean as well. The hostesses smile.

The food is good, pretty good. We ordered:

1. Scallion Pancakes - the BEST I've had since moving from the East Coast!!!! Really good.

2. Tan Tan Noodles - umm, spicy and good. Could do with some vegetables, esp for vegetarians!

3. Tea Tree Mushroom Firepot - good, a bit chewy.

4. Side of Rice

After all this, we got served some complimentary Red Bean sweet soup/dessert - it was good. 

The prices are ok, a lil more than the "affordable," the bill won't kill. Not a place I'll keep going back to, but give it another try or two.
author: Me Iz S.

description: Food was tasteless, service was just OK, dirty dishes left on the table piling up for over an hour. The waiter was controlling and arrogant. A waste of time.
author: Lawrence T.

description: It is one of the most popular Chinese restaurants. There are lots of Sichuan dishes. We ordered Orange chicken, Spicy beef tendon, Frog in mini flaming pot, Pickled fish clay pot, Mushroom with season vegetables, Shredded potato with chili pepper. They are all delicious and not that spicy like China. You should go there and have a taste.
author: Nancy S.

description:
my second time to be here last night.  first time was just so so. second time and last time, horrible experience with service . my friend and I got there around 9:30 last night. the restaurant seemed busy, but we noticed there were about 3 big tables that were being kept closed for some reason. after waiting 20 min to be seated, it took another 15 or 20 min for one of the waiters to come to us to take our order. 
we ordered: 
xiao longbao 
explosive fried crispy chicken
battered prawns with garlic
pumpkin in egg yolk batter 
Westlake minced beef soup
and steam rice to eat with the entrees  

first we got the soup, I thought it was too watery of a consistency and lacked flavor. the minced pork they used was of poor grade. poor grade pork is more fatty, and would have bits of tendons and sometimes bones of ur lucky . I had to spit some of the pieces of mince pork in a tissue because it had hard "stuff". 
 
then the explosive fried chicken came. it was not spicy enough for me to be called explosive. my friend and I both agreed that they didn't give u much chicken, it was mostly covered with dried red chilies. and when u ate the chicken, it wasn't crispy like it should. and some of the chicken were so fatty. I had to spit that out. 

pumpkin and battered prawns came next. I thought these were toooooo pricey . you get about 6 or7 prawns with one order and I believe they were 15 bucks or more. they did not use fresh garlic to season the so called "battered prawns with garlic" instead they used cheap fried garlic in a jar from the Asian market and put lots of that on top of the prawns. it was too salty. 

at least 30 min later my friend and I were still waiting for the steam rice. the food was too salty that we needed steam rice to be able to at least enjoy it better. 

did I say, that it was really difficult to get a waiter's attention here? they were pretty well packed with waiters id say 5 or 6, however they never came to our table to ask if we needed anything or asked if things were ok. we asked for water in the beginning and it wasn't delivered.

after finally trying to catch a waiters attention for 20 min, we asked about our steam rice. the lady waiter said she will check on it. 

10 min later a different waiter, male, came to our table to tel us that there is no steam rice ready. and that it will take a long time. and he suggested to cancel our steam rice order. 

in total shock and disbelief I didn't know what to say or ask. lots of things run in my mind. how could a Chinese restaurant run out of rice? steam rice???? oh come on this is a must and is a staple for Asian food!!! how the hell do you run out of steam rice!!!!! 

my friend and I were pretty upset. they could have told us this in the very beginning that they ran out of steam rice and it will take a while to cook. obviously nobody was paying attention in the back if they had enough rice or not. also, as soon as they found out they should have told us, but NO!! we had to find out ourselves!!! so how the hell are we supposed to eat all these salty spicy foods without rice???! are you kidding me? 

my friend and I quickly packed out foods to go, and left that restaurant. and this is the first time I never gave tip in my entire life. I was so upset and my dinner got ruined thanks to these inattentive, uncaring staff and such a "poor service" as I have written on the receipt.
author: Steve S.

description: We had chicken chilli explosion and it was great. Place was full of local families. Wish we had reserved the Peking Duck it was served to quite a few tables around us and it looked amazing.
author: Joel N.

description:
Doing cardio as I write this review because of my ginormous calorie intake at Chili House. It was so worth it!

Food = 4.0: I had high expectations and Chili House met almost all of them. I loved the spicy wontons and the dan dan mein. Both were delicious, floating in copious amounts of chili oil!  The beef pancake was just ok. I've definitely had better versions with crispier pancakes and tastier fillings. The hui guo rou was nice and fatty but very salty and did not show off other elements of spice, numbing heat and sweet. (Lord, I hope that wasn't bacon I just ate!) I really liked the mapo dofu with its silky, wobbly texture. Overall, the food was spicy from the chilies but I didn't get enough numbing heat from the hua jiao. (Translation:  I was sweating and my nose was running but I still had feeling in my lips and tongue!)

Service = 4.0: Very timely and courteous service! The staff was very friendly and professional. Definitely a rarity for Chinese restaurants. 

Atmosphere = 4.5:  This place is super clean and well decorated. Chinky but not too chinky!
author: Eddie L.

description:
Was here a couple weeks ago and this place rocked my socks off. We just wandered in for an early dinner (maybe 6pm?) and it ended up being SO good. We got like 10 different things among the 6 of us, and everything was delicious. Good enough selection for vegetarians. It seemed like they brought stuff out as it was ready, which makes sense for the family-style dining thing they had going on. We got a big round table with a lazy susan, I am a fan.

By the time we left, I heard a server tell a woman that it would be an hour and a half wait. Soooo I guess go early :-)

Service was good, prices were reasonable. If I lived here, I would go all the time.
author: Kelly R.

description:
We came in on a Friday night about 6:30 with no reservations and the place was full.  I was with a friend and put my name on the waiting list for two.  There was one name ahead of me for two.  We only had to wait about 10 minutes before we were called.  The two young ladies watching the line were not very friendly but it may be a language problem, they being Chinese from China and we being two old white men from SF.  I have to say they were busy clearing tables when not working the waiting line.   We both grew up on China Town Cantonese food and are use to the apparent rudeness towards quoi low but we know this is typical of busy Chinese restaurants everywhere and they are just as rude to other Chinese customers..  I have eaten in Chinese restaurants all around the world for 63 years and a pretty good judge of food and service
The food we had was good but not the best although they did their best to serve us and the service was very good considering a full house.  Our Xiao lum bao was as good as Shanghai, dry fried string beans good, yao choi with garlic was good.  The main courses so so.  we had spicy pork with dumplings was good but not spicy.  It was Shanghai braised pork shoulder that was sliced and piled in the center of the plate with the brown skin piled on top of the meat and a ring of dumplings and broccoli florets laid around the meat.  It looked very good but was not spicy at all.  I asked for Szechuan prawns but not on the menu so my waiter told me she would have the chef make me something similar.  It was spicy and good kinda like kung pao chicken. Last but not least the hot sour soup.  One of my favorites.  The soup was very typical but not enough white pepper or vinegar. I did tell the waiter to tell the chef although I hate to tell the chef how to cook less he come after me with a meat clever. I took the leftovers home and spiced it up.  And talk about leftovers, the portions they serve you are large and you do get your money's worth. 
All in all we did pretty good and will come back again with a few more people so we can enjoy the duck.  It did look very good.

Bill Palmer
author: Bill P.

description: The waiting list is deceiving! They have a separate waiting list for people who called ahead and they'll seat 5 tables who called ahead before they will even seat one walk in. Last time we came to this place, we waited 2.5 hours even though we were 6th on the waiting list.
author: josephine w.

description:
Visited last month with friends that live close. We ordered a ton of stuff to split between the 6 of us and everything was delicious. My favorite dish was the soup dumplings and they were exactly as I remember my first time having them in NYC. 

Highly recommend this place, especially with a large group so you can try many different items.
author: Megan R.

description: This place is ridiculously good!  Get there early because there is often a wait.  I recommend pretty much any of their chicken dishes.  Always fresh food!
author: D J.

description:
Chili House is said to be an offshoot of Z & Y. decor is very bright, clean, and cheerful. so are the associates here. they quickly acknowledge your prescene.

eats: dan dan mein(6.95)
-mushy and firm medium sized  noodles with ma la sauce (very hot at times)
-no ground meat tasted
-some green leaf veggie also. (spinach).
-expected some ground meat
-3ish stars

leftovers:
-comrades from the motherland can pick up  a copy of  "people's daily" (in chinese) at  the front door..
-eatery a 4 for ambience, service, decor
-not sure if all spicing is all ma la or is there a variety of hotness.
-hot spice addicts will love this place.
-not so hot about hot spicy foods.
-dumplings available too.
author: Victor G.

description: Zero stars for being racist against white people. The hostess said they closed at 9:30 when clearly they close at 10 on Yelp. Only Asians being served tonight.
author: Kimi U.

description:
Chili House definitely earns rights to its name, because I definitely had to stop a couple times during dinner to let my taste buds recover from the spicy goodness. 

The food and service were on point- was especially impressed with the awesome consistency of their noodles, and all meals are served with dessert! This is a nice place for a group of friends to get together or a family to share a meal.

Recs on what to order:

-Fish hotpot (so good and sooooo spicy)
-String beans (cooked just right with black beans and chili- get your veggies in!)
-House noodles (thumbs up)
-Tan tan noodle (SO GOOD)

Dishes to skip:
-Noodle cube appetizer (this was alright)
-Chili chicken (this looked better than it tasted)
-Mapo Tofu (pretty standard, but with the sichuan-style chili)
-Twice-cooked pork (pork tasted old/sour)

Definitely come here with an appetite and a big group, so you can try everything. The first time we came, we over-ordered (as usual), got 4 dishes for 2 people and hardly made a dent. Also, call in for a reservation especially if you're coming on a Friday/Sat/Sunday night!
author: Margaret T.

description:
We have been to Chili House twice and definitely would go back again to continue to explore the large menu.

-The steamed chicken soup with Chinese herbs is an excellent start to the meal.  The smaller size is plenty for at least four people.

-Especially liked the fish in a bowl smothered in bright red chiles and Szechuan peppers.  You scoop out from the bowl a piece of the generous serving of fish to your plate or own bowl.  The fish is tender and moist and the peppers leave a tangy feeling in your mouth without pain.

-Bitter melon with honey is a dish like none I have ever seen or tasted.  Bright green and served cold, the bitter melon is cut into long thin slices.  (Don't get this one unless you know you like bitter melon.)

-Prawns with hot spicy sauce were delicious.

-The Tan Tan noodles are an excellent carb if you still need more to eat.

This is a "real" Szechuan kitchen, not a Cantonese cook serving Szechuan dishes.  Looking forward trying more of the menu.
author: Rich S.

description: This is the worst Chinese restaurant I have ever met! Their food are not fresh at all and taste so bad! Recently I went to their restaurant once, their tofu tastes like has gone bad. But they do not admitted it. I was so upset about their food and service. Never go to that restaurant again!!!
author: Xinyi Z.

description:
I recently came to this place with my mother and sister, and I have to say, it was extraordinarily chilly! (I was assuming the "chili" was referring to the food, not the restaurant)

Anyways, the food itself was not bad, as the portion size for the price was quite reasonable. The entrees they provided were not bad, but we decided to order a plate of steamed veggies. This was shockingly expensive, so we were rather disappointed about that.

Overall, the food was not bad but the service itself was rather lacking, especially considering the lack of attention despite being the only table inside, and the freezing temperature within the restaurant.
author: Michael L.

description:
I don't know why I was so surprised that my mouth ended up numb here and that I downed several glasses of water. This place is called Chili House and it's pretty clear that it's a Sichuan style restaurant- thus spicy is to be expected. I'm going to put out a warning to those who get invited here by friends with abnormally high tolerance for spiciness- this place is spicy!

That being said, it's also quite delicious. I know this because despite the fact that my tongue was dying (early on, it was actually numb by the end), I kept going at it. I distinctly remember a frog dish and a beef in spicy oil dish- the others have disappeared as my mind was caught up in the heat of the moment. Just know that everything is delicious... but likely to be quite spicy as well. 

I was somewhat dismayed at the speed with which they brought me water. I was in need of water and they took a little longer than I was comfortable with. I suppose you can blame it on how busy they are, but when you run a Sichuan restaurant I think you should be a bit more conscious of how fast you bring water to your customers. In fact, next time just leave me with a pitcher of ice cold water with ice cold ice cubes :)
author: Philip W.

description:
Hot Hot Hot! Love spicy hot Chinese food? Be sure to checkout Chili House. This place recently opened and their food is delicious. When I think of spicy food I think of Spices but you can actually taste the food here. The restaurant atmosphere is ok, but it was a bit awkward seeing small heaters on the floor.

Food Ordered:

-- #1 Tan Tan Noodle "Dan Dan Mein" [$6.95]
-- #3 Wonton w/ Spicy Peanut Sauce [$5.95]
-- #5 Pan Fried Leek Turn Over [$5.95]

My wife and I ordered our dishes with medium heat and they came out with the perfect amount of hotness. All of the food came out piping hot and we were ready to eat! The Tan Tan Noodles were really good, and the flavor was just right. However the amount of meat was lacking and barely apparent. The Wonton with Spicy Peanut Sauce was great and the skin wasn't too thick. The Pan Fried Leek Turn Over was fragrant and had a nice crispy taste.

Quick Tips:

-- Bring a jacket on a cold night!

The Good: 

Delicious hot spicy tasty food.

The Bad: 

Lack of meat in the Tan Tan Noodles. Freezing Atmosphere.
author: Matthew M.

description:
I'm not usually a fan of hot spicy Szechuan food, but this place was pretty good.
Chicken herbal soup: delicious with a strong herbal taste.
Beef pancake: thin wrappings with an abundance of beef.
Mu shu pork: comes with really thin sheets but still strong enough to hold everything in.  I was a bit disappointed there wasn't a lot of eggs with the pork.
Dan dan noodles: great noodles but so spicy.  You can really see the chili oil in it.
Shanghai dumplings: nice meat, but skin was really dry.
We didn't order a lot of spicy dishes, but truthfully, looking at the other tables, it's a bit intimidating.  A chicken dish covered with chili peppers is not something I'm sure I want to try.
author: Karen L.

description:
Great gem that we randomly stumbled upon while staying in the inner Richmond district! We walked in, saw a couple eating a whole catfish in what looked like a decadent sauce with noodles so we knew we were ordering that instantly.

The place was clean and after looking over the extensive menu, my boyfriend and I could tell the food was diverse and authentic! As a graphic designer, I was impressed by the beautifully designed menu and clear, high quality photos.

We ended up ordering the egg flower soup and pork dumplings which both hit the spot. And we also ordered the Whole Fish with Bean Chili & Hand-Pulled Noodles that were hot and spicy which was absolutely delicious! Only downside was the staff needed to be attentive to water refills.

Can't wait to return in the near future and explore more dishes!
author: Tonia T.

description: Don't waste your money!! Used to be exceptional-not good any more. Greasy, salty, and with each dish we ordered, the waitress reminded us it's "spicy". Ugh yeh, that's why it's called chili house right? Went there last nite, spent almost $90 for 3. Was charged $1 for take home containers and a bag. What? What astute business owner wants people to limit how much they order because they'll be charged for take home containers. Is that even legal to charge for containers if you don't let customers know in advance? Definitely NOT returning. Telling everyone not to eat here. Another great restaurant bites the dust!
author: Audrey C.

description:
We just tried Sichuan Home a couple of weeks ago. So we needed to check this place out since people seem to compare the two.. well, they do both serve spicy Szechuan Northern Chinese food.

Sichuan Home got 5 stars from me. Chili House also gets 5 stars. I think they are both pretty awesome. And I am becoming a huge fan of Szechuan cuisine.. it's got to be the spiciness! (I think Chili House is spicier btw, if you like that)

I did like the decor of the restaurant, clean lines and modern, bright and spacious. The menu is huge and they have pictures. They do have description in English but what is "Twice Cooked Pork with Tofu"? That doesn't mean anything! (I had this same dish at Sichuan Home so I was a little familiar with it.. and the picture confirmed it for me).

So we pointed to 5 items LOL:
- Beef pancake (this was OK .. I've had better at House of Pancakes)
- Spicy dumplings (Ohemgee so good!)
- Kung Pao Tofu (I think this is the right one.. very spicy tofu.. the best EVER!! My favorite)
- Sour Bean Fried Rice (also good)
- Twice Cooked Pork with Tofu (with black bean.. this was very yummy)

We are so coming back very soon. It'll be hard for us to decide which one of these Inner Richmond Szechuan amazingness we'll go to! 

Oh and not sure about the crowds because we arrived late around 2 for lunch and not too many people. I think service was really good. A little hard to communicate but I'm very patient. And they were very nice. LOVE IT!!
author: Vol T.

description: This place was incredible! The food was delicious and beautifully presented. I would totally come here again. The food had a lot of flavor and spice. Unbelievably good and awesome! Loved it!!!!!!!
author: Kim C.

description: Love the chili sauce on the tofu, pickled green beans with ground pork was very authentic. You can't go wrong with the beef n tendon slices in chili oil as an appetizer-- wish the service was better, they missed a dish and billed for stuff we didn't order.
author: SJ L.

description: Sichuan sechuan szechuan I don't know.  But this is THE hot spot. The chili spot. Bunch of good stuff with the table side sliced roast duck then the deep fried carcass was the beautiful finisher. But you must order the hot oil fish. Then dunk all the other stuff you ordered into the hot oil after the fish is gone. Then you'll be gone.. in a spicy world of dericious-ness
author: James L.

description:
I don't lust after spicy foods, but it's definitely growing on me. I still don't like the kind of "numbing" spice that Szechuan cuisine is known for, but I do like the other type of spicy (don't know what it's called) that's just flavorful and enhances everything in the dish by giving it all a kick.  

My friend and I got the twice-cooked pork, the bean jello in red chili sauce, the tan tan noodles, and - our one non-spicy, non Szechuan dish - an order of Shanghai dumplings.  

The twice-cooked pork was good but rather salty, so I didn't love it.  I did, however, REALLY enjoy the bean jello and especially the tan tan noodles, which had such a great chewy texture and GREAT kick.  These dishes were all pretty damn spicy, but like I said before, it's the good kind of flavor-enhancing spicy and not the numbing kind.  Even their Shanghai dumplings were really good - that was a pleasant surprise!  Of all those dishes, I'd most highly recommend the tan tan noodles.  But, be warned: spicy!

This place is also much cleaner and much friendlier than most Chinese restaurants.  In terms of service and cleanliness, I'd give them a B+.  This is much better than the rating I'd give for most other Chinese restaurants: F. 

I enjoyed this meal a lot and definitely want to come back soon to try all the other spicy dishes on the menu.  Since I'm not used to eating this amount of spice normally, I paid for this meal dearly with numerous bathroom trips later that evening and into the next day.  This, of course, is my own fault, and I think it can only be corrected by eating more spices more often.  And I believe Chili House will help me do just that.
author: Vivian C.

description: If I could rate this restaurant 0 stars, I would definitely do so. The service was extremely poor, the waiter was awfully rude, and the plates and such were very unsanitary, and the food was no good either, especially the Peking duck. I've personally never eaten such a horrible Peking duck, it had no taste, it was cold, and I could tell the duck was cooked and was there OVERNIGHT!!! Not only did the food take forever to come, but the duck was COLD. There was leftover food on plates and lipstick marks on cups!
author: S Z.

description:
Chili House is on fire!

In a good way :)

Went to check it out, and everything we tried were additively delicious; from the Pancake Stuffed with Chives and Eggs (so fragrant, pipping hot), to the perfect Dan Dan Noodles, to the with-a-kick Spicy Wontons in Chili Oil, and yummy Dry Sauteed String Beans. 

Don't be intimidated if the plate/bowl is just covered with bright red chilis and drenched in chili oil, because the flavor points were right on with each dish. I love that about the food there, compared to say, Spices, where I honestly can't even stomach eating anything because everything would just be masked with hot spice. Burning your esophagus may be fun for some, but I certainly don't consider it enjoyable.

Will definitely return. Bring on the Chilis!
author: Jing D.

description: My family and I got an assortment of things and everything was really good! If you're a fan of spicy this place is great hence the "Chili"
author: Marie C.

description:
Eh... Meeeeh... Blah.. Not worth the money or time to try and eat their food...

It's very mainland china style and has a super acquired taste that is not suitable for most palates..

Although chili enhances dishes and puts a kicks to things, it really shouldn't be the ONLY thing you taste/feel/tortured with while you're trying to eat dinner

Service is sub-par, but of course, as always.. If you're white, you'll get the smiles, ha-rows, and fanks feri much!  

Buddah forbid you come here as a Chinese family, might as well go cook your own dish in the back

Wouldn't come back, id rather chug a bottle of sriricha.. Atleast that's spice with flavor
author: Droolie Y.

description:
I went here this weekend for a friend's birthday. 
All in all, I was impressed.

It's a pretty small place though and it was packed.
Like concert loud in terms of noise as well.

Everything we ordered was delicious although I didnt care much for the fried rice which apparently had spam in it! (What? yeah, no!)

- the chili spicy chicken is delicious, but you get a really really big plate of chili and hardly any pieces of chicken. Still, the chicken is tasty. Almost like fried spicy chicken you can order from Quicklys. 

- hot and sour soup: decent but really sour. not bad though.
- tan tan noodles: yummy and spicy
- ma pa tofu: legit.
- string beans: yummmmy, cooked perfectly. crunchy goodness.

Pretty affordable meal as well despite all the dishes we ordered.
There is a wait but we called ahead to put in a reservation.
I would recommend you do the same. They were very accomodating.
author: Cicely T.

description: We ordered quite a few dishes and shared among 4 of us. All of us are happy with the food we ordered. Other than typical dumplings and beef pancakes, the husbands also loved their eggplants with garlic sauce. We definitely will be back!
author: Jenny C.

description:
Over priced, moderately tasty szechuan food.

Their fu qi fei pian is not great. Neither is their shui zhu yu.

Wouldn't come again! The waitress was really sweet though :)
author: Andy J.

description: Never let the waitstaff pack leftovers for you.  I had a whole plate of duck with meat left, as well as the salt&pepper duck plate - came home, and found the duck w/ meat wasn't in the bag - that ruined my experience.
author: Lyn Y.

description:
A friend told us that this place is owned by the same owner as Z & Y: same great food without the wait. 

I can't confirm if it's the same owner but the menu and pictures definitely look identical. The food is very similar but the wonton soup is better at Z & Y...lighter and more ginger-y. 

Parking is better. But my friend lied. There was a wait. It's just not as long. 

Service is comparable. Slower but slightly nicer. I suggest BYOB (of water).

I think I found my new fave Sichuan restaurant.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I was craving Szechuan food and my mom suggested this new restaurant that just opened recently. We were not disappointed! It's a big restaurant with lots of tables of various sizes. I would doubt that you'd have to wait for a table here. We usually go to Sichuan Home on Geary and 15th Ave but that restaurant is much smaller and so I usually have to wait if I want to get dinner there. So I'm glad that this place is bigger and the food is good too!

We ordered the following:
+ Rice Cakes - it's not spicy but it's DELICIOUS. It has a sort of sweet taste to it, not because there's any sugar but it was probably the lettuce that was cooked with it. I liked it a lot! The rice cakes are chewy and good. I asked for a little bit of hot sauce on the side so I could dip my rice cakes in.
+ Stuffed onion pancake - this was an interesting one because it was stuffed with meat on the inside. I liked it though because it was really hot and crispy. Yum!
+ Red Oil Chili Wontons - No good. I was hoping that it would taste like the red oil chili wontons at Sichuan Home but I guess I'll just have to go back to that place to get them. 

A lot of people were getting the noodle soups so I assume that those are either really good or just really worth it. They were HUGE. You could probably split them between two people for lunch. 

I like this place and will be back soon =)
author: Connie Y.

description: The wait staff could have been more attentive. Literally had get out of our seats a few times to get their attention. The food was very good and spicy. Expect to wait at least 30 minutes for a table on weekends unless you get there around 8 pm.
author: Rigel A.

description:
I just ordered chicken with explosive chili pepper and my friend order silky tofu she opted vegetarian so no beef or any meat and we also ordered bok choy. 
I like the fact that they accept credit cards unlike Spices and I like the fact that the price is cheap and the restaurant is clean. But the flavor is not that great, my chicken was tasteless and only had soooo much chili on it that the I couldn't even barely find the chicken! Maybe there were only 10 small pieces of chicken covered by tons of red chili peppers no wonder it had to be served on a large plate.
I prefer Z & Y in China Town.
author: Ty N.

description: Salt, salt, and then more salt. I don't understand how this can appeal to the general public. My mouth was tingling, especially my tongue and throat from all the salt. Every dish was you guessed it, salty. Maybe it's part of the Szechuan cooking, but diner beware.
author: Fred S.

description:
So apparently this place has been open since October...it still has a grand opening banner out front. Typical Asian tactic.

Anyways, came here for lunch with my friend the other day. Although it took a while for the waitress to notice us, once seated, service was much better. We were served complimentary bowls of hot and sour soup. It was actually pretty good, it had a good balance of pepper and vinegar.

We ordered the Tan Tan Mein and Shanghai Rice Cake (chow nian gao). The rice cakes were the perfect foil to the spicy tan tan mein. I wished I could have tried more of their menu, but based on the two dishes I had, I can say with relative certainty that I will definitely be back soon to try more.
author: Elaine Y.

description: I made a reservation at Chili House for a party of 12 for 7pm on a Saturday night. When I arrived, the entire restaurant was completely chaotic and barely acknowledged my existing reservation. At first, the waitress was going to try to seat my entire party of 12 at a table that only fit 6 people. Obviously this wasn't going to work, so we had to continue to wait. We ended up waiting about 40 minutes to get seated. While the food here is pretty good, the service and the lack of attention to detail is disappointing.
author: Catherine C.

description: Great food! Our waiter recommended several dishes and each was outstanding! The spice is perfect, not too much or too little. Definitely coming back.
author: Jake N.

description:
After a long search for parking. I finally arrived at the restaurant, so parking is not very accessible unless you are patient. When I first stepped foot in the restaurant, to my surprise, it didn't look half bad. My friend and I were greeted almost immediately, but mainly because the restaurant was pretty empty. I was quite satisfied with their customer service, but when the food arrived, that satisfaction quickly shifted. The dishes we ordered were too sweet and often bland, which was quite a disappointment. The food was suppose to be spicy, yet I didn't feel it in the food. My girlfriend found a review about this restaurant in another source and it was rated as the best in San Francisco. However, if I were to review this restaurant, I'd say there are better ones out there and believe me... A lot better. 

2 stars for customer service.
author: Eric C.

description: Happened to come in off the street, and happy to stumble upon a great find. Though the waiters English wasn't great, the service was quick, attentive and friendly. And the food was quite a good value for the money. Be aware, even the non-spicy dishes have a tiny bit of a kick, but in a very good way.
author: Abe L.

description:
I was there on 02/27 when I walk in the waiter had stone cold face then asked me "do you have a reservation?" then I said no then I set down then we ordered food. food are great 
but the service just not good. soon as we got our food he never came around ask us how we doing or anything else , but soon as a couples walked in the same waiter take care of them 
introduce them a brand of beer  gave them a free shot of some kind of sake, so i wants to order more food , i looked at him , he still talk to the couples, then he walked outside smoke cigarette, and returned i don't know if he wash his hand or not, i raised my hand no one response again he walked outside said good buy to the couples. i did not get his name but i am feeling mistreated by my own race, i work for hotel front desk, this waiter does not have a customer skill he is older man, speak good English but with no skill of  customer service
do not go to this restaurant if you are Chinese!!!!
author: Kelley K.

description: Food was okay, the service was poor. The waitress was fine, but there was a rude waiter that totally ruined my eating experience. They should definitely trained their employees to be more attentive and respectful.
author: Weijue W.

description: Great place to eat wish I could give it more stars also very good service I had pork steamed dumplings pancakes with steak and shrimp and some duck.
author: Cooper R.

description: The food was alright. Their soup is fantastic. However, they have very poor service. We waited 30 minutes even when we had made a reservation. We asked for coke and two ice waters, it didn't come. We asked again. It didn't come until the third time. We also asked for another extra batch of tortillas, but it never came. Overall, the food is spicy good, but their service needs to be fixed.
author: Elen Z.

description: Love the cabbage side dish.  Very friendly staff, but place seems to always be crowded.  They do takeout--might be a good way to try them out (though once seated the service is fine.)
author: A B.

description: The duck itself was average generally. But the spicy chicken is the best I have ever tried in sf!! And the beef soup is awesome ~ one of my favorite spicy food restaurant in sf!
author: Nancy H.

description:
Atmosphere: Very busy during lunch and dinner hours. Try to go on an off hour to get the most out of your meal, unless you like the crowd.

Service: Mediocre, very Asian styled. You need to be proactive to get what you want.

Food: I got my parents to switch from their other restaurant of 10 years (the quality had gone down and they switched owners) Which means they're pretty darn good. I love the firecracker chicken, it's mouth numbing. I get it every time I go, and when I think of it, my mouth waters. Do not go here if you can't handle spicy. I had gotten the hot pot once with medium spice and my dad thought the chef absolutely hated me because it was so spicy.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
Everything is so spicy and so good. 

I like the explosive dish with chicken chunks and the salted egg shrimp/corn dish. 

if I was in the area and craving those two dishes.... I will def be back!
author: Chanel L.

description:
Sunk my teeth into gigantic bowl of lamb noodle soup. So hot I had to take the vegetables out to cool off on a plate before eating.  
The lamb was super thin and flavorful. The broth was plentiful and I asked them to pump up the heat, there was an oil slick of chili oil floating on the surface. Every mouthful was lip smacking good. The noodles are the round rice with some chew to it, huge portion. 

I really wanted to have the beef stuffed pancake but couldn't this visit.
author: Lhm M.

description: I called 10 minutes in advance and the lady on the phone said 20 minute wait. I lost my place in line at the other restaurant I was at to try chili house due to short wait. After 50 minutes in line (with no end in sight) I'd had it and left. I feel like they lied to get me to come in and they did this to someone else I just talked to also. Very disingenuous! No one was up front telling guests what was going on - everyone looked confused.
author: Will L.

description: I could've given this place a one star but the reason why I gave this a two stars was because of the Peking duck, it was really good. The other dishes my family and I had were awful, simply put, all the dishes were TASTELESS! I would never go back again.
author: stephanie w.

description:
When I first came here when it was still their "grand opening" I was glad there was a place close by with good Sichuan food.

Came here again last week--food is now just OK but I still like the price very much ($30 sth for 4 dishes + 1 bowl of rice).  Things seemed to have gotten sloppier and carpet's getting dirtier (I never understood why restaurants bothered with carpet).

When I crave spicy Chinese food, I prefer Old Mandarin Islamic Restaurant (higher health score too!)
author: Amanda B.

description: Been here several times mostly for lunch. After eating around the menu a little bit I have settled on a favorite. Spicy fish noodle soup! $7.95 at lunch and $8.95 at other times, it's enough for two meals for me. And it's really really delicious. Although when I look around at what other people are eating, I see they've got me lots of beautiful food. This would be a really good place to come with a group of people so you can try several things. They always also serve A pickled appetizer along with tea when you sit down.
author: Kelly P.

description:
I've been craving Szechuan food for the longest time and I'm so glad I finally got to get it!

Our party of five ordered 6 dishes (including appetizers) and yes we basically finished and were very full.

1. Pancake with beef: yummy appetizer to start off with; NOT spicy!
2. Tan Tan Noodles: basically completely in chili oil; has a bit of a sour taste but very good!
3. **Beef with flaming chili oil**: everyone agreed that this was the MOST SPICY dish we ordered. It tasted different from my favorite Szechuan restaurant in SoCal but always great to try different versions. Numbingly spicy but in a good way! Everyone loved it...comes in a huge bowl and the sauce is so good. You HAVE to put it over your rice...let it soak it up! 
4. Cumin lamb: very flavorful! 
5. Pork with bell peppers (I don't remember the actual name): yummy! totally thought the green bell peppers were spicy jalapeños or chiles but they weren't. 
6. Dry sautéed string beans: first dish that was finished! a good break from the spiciness.

Everything was spicy at a good level. I didn't think it was too much but my friend who is only okay with spicy food kind of died a little and couldn't eat too much...except rice. yeah he ate a lot of rice LOL

The only problem I had was with our waitress. She was not that friendly and I felt unwelcome in the beginning. Granted, we took a while before we were ready to order because it was our first time there and we didn't know what to get, but she never suggested or helped with anything either. But other than that, the food was good and we didn't have to wait long.
author: Kelly T.

description:
Went here before our trek back home to Southern California.  We ordered Chow Mein and Chicken and Mongolian Beef... they all came out at our table at different times, so we didn't eat the meal all at once. 

It was okay, if I were visiting San Francisco again, I'd try another place.
author: Bradley P.

description: Always on point. I get the basics, nothing crazy. Its always amazing. Im a huge fan of the spicy house chow mein, honey walnut prawns, sweet & sour chicken& spicy dumplings. I would absolutely say to check this place out.
author: Michael R.

description: They commended too many dishes. We only finished a half. It was such a waste. The taste is just so so. Price is a little bit too high.
author: Bh W.

description: food is not bad but waitress is totally not friendly！！！ her attitude is too bad and she didn't focus on customer services at all！！very bad experience！
author: Nigare M.

description: Let me start off by saying that I went here with someone who does not eat pork. All of their dumplings had pork in it but they had one kind that had fish. So I ain't get no dumplings! What I did get was the beef rolls, princess chicken, spicy chicken clay pot, and the pouched beef in hot chilli oil. I didn't really enjoy the beef rolls as I have had better in the Ave (Sunset!!!). The princess was standard. The spicy chicken clay pot was my favorite out of all the dishes. Try it! And last but not least, the beef in chilli oil. It was a different type of spicy. It was more mouth numbing and different to my taste buds. It was good, but it can't top the spicy chicken! That spicy chicken tho! Hahaha
author: Eddie B.

description:
5 stars for the Tan-tan noodles! Spicy, flavorful and perfectly done. The rolled beef pancakes were quite good as well, not greasy at all plus the crisp cucumber and hoisin sauce was a good combination to the pancake roll. 

I'm taking one star off my review because they gave me the wrong soup with my to-go order. But nevertheless, it was still good. 

Definitely will be back to try out the other stuff, while waiting for my order I can't keep myself from salivating from all the food that was coming out of the kitchen, The sight and smell of all the chili from other people's orders were simply intoxicating!
author: Gordon O.

description:
Excellent Szechuan food! I wouldn't say this is the spiciest Szechuan place I've ever been to, in fact I think it's a little toned down. But for the average American it's probably still considered spicy.

Non-food-wise:
 --- Parking around this area is generally easy. Paid meters everywhere. 
 --- I usually come slightly off the peak dinner hour and never had to wait. There is ample seating from 2-table seats to traditional large round tables.
 --- Service is speedy and good

They are a little on the pricey side, but I think they use better quality ingredients and produce. At least I feel like all their food is a tad more "refined".

Food-wise:

Couple's Delight (夫妻肺片), $7.95 --- Cold marinated slices of lung and I think tendon. One of the best appetizers you can get. The marinade is spicy with the right blend of soy-sauce-ish salty sweet. Highly recommended.

Wonton with Spicy Peanut Sauce (紅油抄手) $5.95 --- another recommended appetizer. The sauce is what's important (should be spicy & salty with a tad sweetness), and I think they do it very well

Ma Po Tofu w/ Pork (麻婆豆腐）$9.50 --- If there were a textbook example of Ma Po Tofu, this would be it! The balance between chunked soft tofu, minced pork, and chili sauce is excellent.

Home-Made Soy Bean Milk （豆漿）$1.50 --- A surprising delight. It's rare to see Szechuan restaurants carry house-made fresh soy milk. Much better than the store brands. I like to get it warm with no sugar.

Steamed Chinese Cabbage with Garlic (蒜蓉蒸韶菜）$10.95 --- My least favorite dish out of everything I've order here. I don't dislike the cabbage but the broth they pour on it combined some kind of green onion slices they put on it just made it very unappetizing to me. It had some kind of onion-y smell that wasn't the kind of onion-y smell I liked :( On the other hand, my husband thought it was fine, so it's probably a very personal preference.

Xinjiang Style Gill Lamp Chops （新疆烤羊排） $13.95 --- lightly salted and peppered grilled lamb chops.
