By the way, Xinjiang province is very far from Szechuang (I think of the silk road when ppl say Xinjiang) so not sure how this ended up here but it definitely has got that Middle Eastern touch to it. Yummy!


Stir Fried Chicken with Pickled Chili Pepper (小米椒爱上小公雞) $9.95 --- I liked this less. Was like...small chicken pieces fried with some peppers, but it didn't taste very strong or like anything.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
been here many X and the duck is amazing  with the soup, had it 2 X and the dumpling, pot sticker, beef pancake is so so so good.  Ginger noodle duck with rice noodle, basil clam good, tan tan noodle my son loves, boy Choy veg is great.  I need to try other dishes but I usually don't like it too spicy,  but the other guest like it hot. cucumber salad real goo too. 

last nite the place was pack but the dishes were amazing under $100 for 5 of us.   highly recommended coming to this place.  noodle real good and down to earth soup. 

love this place
author: tina l.

description: Went there with a friend last month. We ordered Peking Roast Duck, but it didn't meet my expectation. Then I heard from my friend that the chef from Quanjude in Beijing just left.
author: Laura D.

description: I usually never write any reviews but this place has very shitty customer service!! All the waitresses was doing was sitting, eating and talking with other coworkers!! I had to yell and wait more than 20mins to get their attention!  And not to mention, the soups that me and my friend had was nasty!! My stomach was hurting the following morning!!
author: Tracy Ann C.

description:
This restaurant was recommended to me by a friend. It just wasn't a very exciting meal whatsoever. The service was pretty bad too. We waited several minutes in "I'm ready to order stance," menus closed, stacked, and placed on the edge of the table, eagerly looking up for a waiter even though there were several waitstaff standing around. We also had issues with getting water and our order of rice. They had to be reminded several times to bring these things to our table. This is the kind of place where you have to flag people down for everything. You could even hear the bell being fervently rung from the kitchen, calling a wait person over to bring out a boiling soup that had to be served hot. 

Anyway, the food:

Exploding Chili Chicken: the chicken tastes fine. It's nothing spectacular and has a distinct flavor from all the spices. I kind of think all the chili peppers are a bit of a gimmick because to season a dish there's no way you need that many, but I'm no expert on this. 

Steamed Napa Cabbage: This was really just an okay dish. I wanted a vegetable dish, but I've tried stir fried green beans so many places and felt in the mood for something different. The serving size is insanely large and it essentially was what you would expect.

Tan Tan Noodles: the flavor profile of this was good, but it's a bit freaky how much oil there is.  I know that's just the style of the dish, but freaky nonetheless. The texture of the noodles weren't great. The day after I ate here, I ate at my favorite noodle place, House of Pancakes, in order to remind myself what great noodles should taste like.
author: Victoria J.

description:
Mediocre Chinese restaurant, I was flabbergasted to see that it had 3 1/2 stars.
We ordered the sweet and sour soup which was tofu floating in a pool of vinegar along with a few other strange spices. The beef was drowned in some kind of cheap oil with chili sauce, beyond that everything else was hardly average, most other Chinese restaurants could do the same food for better.
author: Arda O.

description: The restaurant we clean and nice but the food was a little disappointing. We ordered the beef pancake, hot and sour soup, tan tan noodles, and spicy dumplings.  I was surprised that most of the dishes all tasted the similar besides the soup, everything was drowned in their bright red chili oil sauce.  The food wasn't terrible but with all the other good restaurants in the area I probably won't be going back.
author: P N.

description: The food presentation was nice and the vegetable dish and seafood clay pot dish I ordered were both well-received.  However the Dong Po pork, though nicely presented, was tough and dry.  Guess we will have to learn more about which dishes to avoid here...
author: Crystal L.

description: This place must be all about the duck.  We ordered off the menu not having time enough to wait for the duck. The food was so bland that we had to ask for hot pepper sauce to go with it.  The chicken curry has nothing to do with any kind of a curry you've ever had before but more like chicken with white sauce and some vegetables.  It was marked with a red chili pepper signifying a very hot dish which it was not. The  scallion pancakes were not crispy .   Again, the clams in a clay pot  were  so  bland that I had to ask for some Hot Chili Peppers sauce to add some nterest to the dish.  Service was acceptable,  if not welcoming. The restaurant was very busy and we did not get utensils with our dish.   If we ever went back again we would order the duck beforehand and see if that is worth the publicity it has received.
author: Kathryn S.

description:
Originally from Sichuan. I grew up eating spicy food. I have to say that this is THE BEST Sichuan restaurant if you are a fan of numbing spicy flavor of Sichuan cuisine!

They have the most authentic Mapo Tofu! That is a must-order! 

I've been here a couple of times, and everything I order from the menu has wowed me!
author: Teddy S.

description: Mediocre food. Service was mediocre as well. I ordered cold noodle and tofu beef( no spicy) and tunip cake. Let's just say the cold noodle is northern style noodle, which I am not a huge fan of. The reason I went here is because I assumed the noodle would be southern style. Tofu beef is just bland. Turnip cake is weird because I love the turnip inside but hate the sesame outside. Anyway not a great experience but not a terrible experience. Would not come back unless there is a big change.
author: Zhang R.

description:
Braised Crispy Chicken with Jalapenos
chicken piece is too big so it's not crispy enough

I saw the free appetizer pickle dishes by the kitchen (lots of them piling up by the counter but was never brought to out table

shanghai style rice cake is under seasoned and greasy

pumpkin cake with red bean paste flavorless (can not taste the pumpkin)

over all not good!
author: Rina C.

description:
This is a pretty good Chinese spot on a street with about a million restaurants to choose from. I came in on a Wednesday night, and the place was about empty, which was nice, albeit unfortunate for the restaurant. 

We ordered the house noodles, beef pancakes, string beans, and numbing beef. The noodles were garnished with a great sauce, and were the perfect consistency. I also love cucumber, so having that on their was a plus. The beef pancakes were awesome, too. The string beans were fine. Good flavor, but nothing to write home about. Granted, this isn't the fault of the restaurant; string beans don't have a ton of potential. The beef was the only thing we didn't like, but that was more due to how it was presented than to the actual quality of the dish. It simply wasn't what we were expecting. We used the sauce from the beef on the veggies and noodles, however, and that definitely added a kick. 

The service was great, although we were the only ones in the place, so it wasn't a surprise. Food was out almost immediately, which was great. 

I will definitely come back with a better understanding of the menu, as that was pretty much the only thing that kept this from being a five star experience.
author: Zander N.

description: Great Food and Chili Spice!  Just had the chili garlic sesame fish.  Wow!!! The portions are enormous as well!
author: Rob M.

description:
Pretty tasty, pleasantly surprised. Adding to my list of "regulars"!

Had the:
- fish fillet with bean chili
- beef pancakes
- pea-shoots with garlic (veggie)
- "tan-tan" noodles

All really good! :)
author: Cheung L.

description: I'm totally a fan of this place. I recently discovered them through Caviar and ate here like 3 times in two weeks (no Im not ashamed because it was delicious) I have lived in SF for over 7 years now and this is the first Chinese food place that I enjoy. When I order chicken I know Im actually eating chicken which is more than I can say for some other places who send greyish mystery meat...ewww. I especially love the princess chicken and the tan tan noodles. I order these and eat myself into a food coma every damn time...I have no control when it comes to my Chili House addiction.
author: Paige M.

description: My new favorite restaurant in town. Fantastic flavors, great spice that makes you sweat but you still cant stop eating. I go there atleast once a month, and I tried most of their dishes. Did not find any that is not good. Highly recommended.
author: Balu V.

description:
Have been here at least a dozen times, ordered take-out several times, and introduced this restaurant with all kinds of friends. I'm a fan.

Watch out for the excessive amount of garlic and cilantro!

I'll come back!!
author: Alex S.

description: Been there twice and tried all the recommendations, really disappointed. Most of the food there is oily and not spicy at all (as I'm from China)
author: Louie Z.

description: We had a party of 4 and went on a Sunday night, didn't have to wait at all. Love everything, especially the fish in spicy oil. Strongly recommend.
author: Emily Y.

description:
Oh man....

I've ordered SO MANY items off their menu, that I can't even remember exactly what I've ordered.

But trust me when I tell you this: if you like authentic Szechuan food, if you LOVE spicy food, do not miss out this restaurant. You are going to love it here! I know I did!

Will be back many many times to come!
author: C W.

description:
If you talked to me 2 months ago I would've been gushing about this restaurant, now after five visits I'm feeling more of a 4 star rating.

I've been dying for real Chinese food after living in China for nearly 3 years.  SF has no shortage of Chinese restaurants, but they all serve up saccharine Americanized Cantonese food.  (Note: If Mongolian Beef or Beef & Broccoli are on the menu it's not legit) .

When we finally found Chili House we were in heaven.  The atmosphere was just like being back in China and the menu had exactly what I wanted.  Even the smell of the restaurant and the bright fluorescent lights were spot on.

They had my absolute favorite dish of all time which is a pork dish that I don't exactly know the English name, but if you order YanJianRou you can't miss.  The flavor was spot on, but strangely the pork was very soft and doesn't have the sensation of eating meat.  I seriously considered bringing in my own pork and begging/bribing them to  make it for me.

The Beef (or Fish) in Chili Oil is very good, I prefer the fish as the beef had a similar issue as the pork.

Recently we have been getting very poor service.  The lunch specials are reasonably priced, although they are basically just smaller versions of the regular dishes.  We went for lunch and, after hunting down parking, I was getting close to the end of lunch time.  They shut down the whole kitchen at 3PM, not just the lunch specials so they rushed my fiance who was in earlier. They asked at her at least 5 times within 3 minutes to order although we were obviously trying to hurry.

I went here a couple nights ago and the taste of the food was also quite good, although the meat is still super soft and a little strange - not like it would be in the real dish in China.

So... long-ish review, but this is a fantastic place and perhaps the only one in SF with decent Chinese food.  Now if they can just stop being rude (even by Chinese standards) and get their meat right I will be there on the daily.
author: Brian L.

description:
After I ate part of my beef stew wonton noodle soup, I took the rest to go.  When I was emptying the bowl, the entire bottom half of the bowl was absolutely disgustingly grimy.  The worst I have ever seen.

I am a fan of dirty Chinese restaurants, but this was disgusting brown grime you can chip off with your fingers.

If I get sick or go dying soon, someone please see this review and know it was the cause.  Yes... it was that bad.
author: Lausy L.

description:
Still discovering my new neighborhood, and after walking by another restaurant (name shall not be mentioned) with no one in it, my friend and I were on a mission to find one with more people.  Chili House's sign caught my eye and figured we'd give it a shot after seeing it was crowded (there were two large tables visible from the street).

Ordered four dishes:
-hunan beef: I was skeptical about this one when my friend selected it, but the meat was tender and very flavorful.  A nice kick to it as well!
-shanghai rice cakes: Always a favorite of mine and Chili House prepares it well.  Rice cakes did not stick together and they were not oily.  Win!
-steamed cabbage: Unique dish that had just the right amount of flavor.  Tons of sliced green onions on top as well.  Simple, but excellent!
-green beans:  Still slightly crunchy and crisp.  Not soggy--done just right!

Don't expect 3 dishes for $XX, but definitely good portion sizes.  I'll be back to try out some of the spicier dishes--had to tone it down since my friend doesn't eat spicy.
author: Christopher W.

description:
- I was super surprised by this place. Looks and feels like a typical Dim Sum restaurant, with a lot of people and lively feel. 
- Most dishes had a strong spice but did not overwhelm. Go slow to start and then dig in once you're tastebuds have acclimated. 
- My favorite dishes from our order: Tan Tan Noodle, beef pancakes, braised spice chicken
author: Jeff M.

description:
So I was told this was in the "tenderloin" aka the sketchiest neighborhood in san francisco. In a city that the blog "what white people like" is based on, this translates into a regular neighborhood for any other city. Great place for dive food places.
From the outside this place looked like a takeout chinese/all you can eat buffet with e coli special type of place. NOT THE CASE.
The staff was pleasant and accomodated our large group.
The food was all amazing. From the curry to the noodles to the dumplings, hard to remember everything 8 people ordered to share. But I can safely say none of the food was bad or made poorly. The people here are super nice and work hard at pleasing you, something that was greatly appreciated!!!
author: Saad M.

description: I thought the food was delicious! I am really picky about my meat but chicken and beef plates we ordered were great. Not fatty at all. I really enjoyed the atmosphere and will definitely be returning.
author: Paola T.

description:
Yumm! Mmmmmm! Expect these sounds. Favorites: shanghai dumplings, hot noodles, chicken with peanuts and pecan shrimp. If you like these things, you found your spot.

The reservation was nifty on Friday night!
author: Gina P.

description: One of our favorite Chinese restaurants in the city - just a few blocks from our house - the won ton soup melts in your mouth, the Peking duck presentation is always a memory, have not had anything bad - just some better than others
author: Thomas B.

description:
Oh Chili House! Where do I begin? I think you can find some very good dishes in here and the rest are just underwhelming.  Why do I keep coming back? Must the addictive quality of those darn chilies!

I've been here twice and have had the same inconsistent experience twice.  One dish that has been excellent both times is the spicy dumplings.  I've also ordered the fish in hot chill oil and that was underwhelming, just boiled fish in broth with a layer of hot oil and chills on top.  

I've also had the fish filet (looked great in the picture on the menu) but was just meh - it was just a breaded and fried piece of fish that had plenty of seasoning MSG wise but not chili wise (picture showed spices etc. - hey I'm a sucker for show and tell, ok?).  I've also ordered the garlic shrimp and once again it was fried shrimp on a plate full of what looked like breadcrumbs, garlic chips but in truth really looked like a cat's litter box filled with that sawdust litter.  The rest of dinner was spent playing around this "zen" garden while making meowing sounds.  I promise I'll bring that up with my therapist in our next session...

If all fails, this place provides great pre-dinner entertainment with the numerous typos in its menu.

I will come back here again and try out other dishes such as the beef roll (looks so good!) because I think it's one of those restaurants you just gotta know what to order...I hope.
author: Favoloso M.

description: Had a great lunch here and wanted to try their tan tan and the spicy chili chicken dish. Boy was it ever hot! The chili chicken actually numbed my mouth! I never had that happened to me before. Overall the food was great and spicy!
author: Lakeen W.

description: I showed "The free appetizer" yelp app for checking in @ this restaurant but the waiter refused it without saying why.  And then he forgot our order, after reminding him a couple times, the food and drink finally arrived slowly.  The restaurant wasn't even busy.   The service sucked. First time here, and also last time here.
author: David L.

description:
kick-ass Szechuan: chicken with explosive chili is the bomb.  The numbing was perfect.

If you read the bad reviews, you'll see people who Don't Get It(tm) and review the carpet.

The Tan Tan noodles and dumplings were a little soft/soggy for my taste and the flavors didn't "pop".  The pancake w/ beef fell apart and was hard to eat.
author: adam s.

description:
Not for vegetarians. I asked if they could make me vegetarian mixed vegetables and tofu. She said no tofu, but they could do mixed vegetables. I got it to go with rice and paid $12!

As I was waiting, a guy came in with a cardboard box full of dead fish on a cart and was slowly walking through the restaurant, talking to people on the way, it really disgusted me. 

I finally got my food. It was mediocre at best, mostly bok choy and carrots in a bland sauce. Very disappointed. But it was fresh, and it did look like a good place for authentic Chinese cuisine and meat eating. Just not my kind of place. 

The waitress was very polite and friendly too, which earned the 2nd star from me.
author: Venus S.

description: As a Chinese,I'm really looking forward to having good Sichuan food and I had great expectation to this place. However, the experience is really disappointing. Most of the dishes are just different materials with the same sauce and no dish is spicy at all. I never met Maoxuewang with fish beef and mushrooms since I was born in 1991. Just a few pieces of pork blood indicate that this dish is called Maoxuewang. The frog is even worse. This dish is filled with mushrooms but little frog meat. And the frog leg, the most appealing part of frog, cannot be seen at all. The frog itself has a weird taste which I cannot describe but not good at all. The chicken with explosive chili peppers is said to be one of the most famous dish but I cannot tell the difference with the ordinary fried chicken with salt. We still had a few more dishes but none of them worth mentioning. Anyway, the overall service is good so I give this place a two-star comment. But I definitely will not come to the place the second time. I'm so angry that I write a review on Yelp for the first time in my life.
author: Hanning W.

description: Tan tan noodles are to die for. Literally the most unique combinations of flavors in one bite. Also, the spicy dumplings rock. Very quick service and a friendly staff. So thankful I live near this place!!
author: Katie S.

description:
I've definitely experienced better. Don't get me wrong, this place isn't horrendous but you leave feeling really heavy from all the fried food. And on the menu, you read these items not expecting everything to be fried. 

My mom wondered why there wasn't any pepper or condiments on the table... usually, when restaurants do this, their food is heavily flavored so you don't need it. 

We started with the hot and sour soup and quickly found out why there were no condiments on the table. It was heavily peppered, which was fine for me, because I always toss in a ton of pepper anyway. However, this soup was HEAVILY peppered. My sister kept coughing because she was completely overwhelmed by it. 

We ordered lemon chicken, which I really thought would come out like normal lemon chicken but nope... you know orange chicken? well it's like that but with the hint of lemon. It was definitely not what i was expecting at all. Fried. 

We also ordered the explosive chicken, which I've had at Mission Chinese Food. Mission Chinese Food wins hands down. Their chicken was actual chicken wings whereas this restaurant had pieces of chicken and the flavor wasn't better than Mission Chinese. Fried.
 
We got some "Gill Lame Chops with crispy garlic" aka Grilled Lamb Chops with crispy garlic. When they say "grilled" you think grilled, but then tell me why they were lightly coated and lightly fried? Ugh... but this dish was pretty good. I liked it a lot, but you have to like lamb to enjoy it. 

Also go the Ma Po Tofu, Mission Chinese wins. Nothing special about this dish. 

I doubt I'll be back unless I'm craving deeply fried food... which rarely happens. So I guess I won't be back... obviously.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Ordered two appetizers as my dinner, but took 20 mins for the first one to arrive. This felt like a long time, especially when the restaurant was half empty. I figured they don't course the items, as I saw all the other tables get all their dishes first. 

Tan Tan Noodles were ehhhh, average. Maybe a little skimpy on meat and veggies. Just tasted like noodles soaked in spicy seasoned oil. If this is how authentic tan tan noodles are supposed to be, please correct me.

Spicy Dumplings were also average. The meat inside the dumpling was too "compact", like it's been balled up for too long. There was way more than enough chili oil in the bowl to soak the dumplings completely, although I'm not sure why, seems like a waste of chili oil. I'm not going to drink it, nor did it have much flavor to enhance the dumplings.

Maybe these two apps were just misses, so I ordered a third dish, the Twice Cooked Pork, knowing full well I'd be taking home leftovers... because I really wanted to like this place, and wanted to have a reason (a true knockout dish, really) to come back...

The Twice Cooked Pork failed. Honestly, there was too much fat in the dish. Solid fat strips and overall fat content easily easily outnumbered actual pork meat two-to-one. Is authentic TCPork supposed to have finger-size fat pieces with no meat on them? I found quite a few pieces like that. Please correct me if I'm wrong...

The music playlist of choice was strange, consisting of remixed mid-80s techno stuff. The stuff your mom bought on cassette tapes from 1988 Chinatown. Like a sample mix tape of Paula Abdul auditioning with Oingo Boingo. One song had a group of seemingly tiny women singing "na na, na na na na, hey hey heeey, gooodbyeee!" I dunno, it was very unsettling, such an odd choice of music for a Szechuan restaurant. The volume was too low to Shazam it, couldn't figure it out. I sat for 20 mins just listening to it, waiting for my food...
author: Ethan L.

description: I'm changing my rating from a 4 to 5 star. Here's why: Peking Duck. Ever since they added this dish, the place has been insane. They are pretty packed these days, while it's annoying now that I have to wait a long time to get a table here, I'm happy for them as they are very nice people. Their peking duck is as good as any I've ever had and I've had a lot in my lifetime. The chef that makes it and cuts it at the table is the LeBron James of Peking Duck. Watch him masterfully slice that sucker up. He should be on Ellen, he's that good. My party of 4 today came in and thought we over ordered when we ordered duck and 4 other dishes. We killed 90% of the dishes and flat out finished 3 of them. If there's a better place in the city for any style of chinese food in SF, I've yet to find it. This is probably one of two places in SF that could actually survive if you put it in san gabriel valley. Too bad we don't live in the city anymore. Anyway, well done chili house. Well done.
author: M C.

description: Went on a Saturday evening in early 2014. Table of 8. Place seemed extremely understaffed: the waiters had no time for us... didn't even refill our water jugs until an hour and a half later when our party was ready to leave. Told them that we were here to celebrate a birthday... not a single $%1T given. Not sure if the waiters even knew English...
author: TJ P.

description:
One of the best place for spicy food! 

Spicy pig feet is a must order! (if you like pig feet)
if not spicy chicken as always.

the place is too small, but doesn't matter, food is good i don't mind.
author: Stephen S.

description:
Couples Delight and Fish in Chili Oil never seem to fail. Staff seems friendly and very enthusiastic to see non-asian peoples chow down on crazy spicy food. I highly recommend the salted-duck-egg prawns w/corn. A very unusual dish for me, but very tasty! 

There seems to be a distinct difference between this location and the Z&Y. I think it's worth experiencing this distinction yourself. Personally I like the Chicken with Explosive peppers at Z&Y, but prefer the Couples Delight and Fish in Chili Oil at Chili House. 

God, I love Sichuan Food!
author: Chris V.

description:
I expected this place to be colder with a name like Chili House. Tan tan noodles are consistent and good. Chicken with Explosive chilis have a numbing effect, typical of Sichuan food. 

If you live in the area, or you're driving by, it's worth a try.

Leave the jacket in the car.
author: Masato W.

description:
Today was my first time coming here and I loved everything about it. The place is big and the staff here are attentive. 

What's good: 
Hot and sour jelly noodle (not spicy at all) 
Grilled fish (light and tasty) 
Fish soup (my favorite dish) 
Ma Pa tofu (not spicy either, but still delicious) 

So the Chicken with Explosive Chili Pepper was my least favorite. The presentation was beautiful, full of red chili, but it was mostly that.

Other than that, I would come here again with family or a big group so I a bigger variety of dishes.
author: Lisa T.

description: Came in today at noon.  Looooonnnnng wait, besides the waiters are rude!!!  They won't even answer you like how long is the wait.  They just ignore you.  Add to the confusion of waiting is that people just walk in and claimed they have reservations thus making the wait even longer.  This place used to be deserted, no one comes to eat, they do a lot of marketing and now it's of people coming and they have a hard time providing service.  Tried waiting for like 10/15 mins, and people just came in after us and got tables and response is they have reservations and won't even let us know how long to wait.  I walked out, if they  ignore people waiting, I don't expect a good service dining wise.
author: Atoy C.

description:
This place will draw comparisons to its sister restaurant, Z&Y, but it seems like its menu has been expanded upon. There is also a new menu that has noodle soup dishes which I haven't seen at Z&Y; perhaps it's a lunch only option.
 
I had a lamb noodle soup with szechuan spice added and I thought that was really good. The blending of the coriander and szechuan peppercorn with lamb and noodles created an excellent balance of strong, but distinguished flavors.
author: Anthony K.

description:
Pros:  frog in mini flaming pot, house special chow mein

cons: music was blaring as if we were in a club
author: Heidi L.

description:
Worth the trek!

Our crew went to Taiwan Restaurant last week and it's safe to say Chili House is lightyears ahead of the pack. Almost everything on the menu was stunning. The only thing that didn't stand out was the pig's feet on a giant plate covered with chilis. I thought that eating something strange would leave me unphased but someone's warped sense of taste made the dish nearly unedible and nearly ruined the whole meal.

Four stars for all the rest of the dishes and atmosphere!
author: Calvin W.

description:
3 1/2 stars. Portion are big, but food needs to be more spicy.

I like the green onion pancake and the rice cakes here.

The kung pao tofu and salf and pepper fish was good, but no spicyness...AND they call themselves CHILI HOUSE? HM.....
author: Karen H.

description: Worst place ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I went with my bff for a quick bite. We went here because she loves spicy food.  We walk in and no one spoke to us for a while then we are rush off to a side table with menus tossed in our direction. When we ready to order no one came we watched then take orders and serve takes that  came in after us while we waited patiently 15 20 30 minutes go by and no one has taken our order it felt like there were only serving Asian speaking customers. After 40 minutes we stand up to leave and then some blocks the door and says they can take our order now! They were annoyed by our questions never brought us any water or even offer when our food finally did come they did not bring us any flatware!! We asked someone who told us "not my table" then a bus boy put some on the table and there dirty but we can't get anyone's at ten when we finally do and began to eat I noticed crusted rice on the inside and outside of my bowl my friend stood up and began to walk out again she was stopped she complained about my bowl and the lady didn't seem to care until she said she wasn't going to pay the she gave us $2 off out bill of $40  the food wasnt worth rhe wait it was blan and a bit over cooked. this was by far my worst experience ever!!! I would avoid this place at all costs Never Ever go her unless you enjoy terrible service on dirty dishes!!!
author: Chandra M.

description:
Wait a minute. This food seems oddly similar to z and y in Chinatown. Same owners. But no wait, better parking. Had some spicy noodles, won ton, and mixture of stuff in chili oil. Earns 4 stars in my book.

Somebody hit the staples button. That was easy!
author: Q L.

description:
On my weekend getaway, I visited some friends in the Bay Area and decided to stop by this quaint little joint.  It was a pleasant surprise.  We ordered 6 different dishes for the three of us and got more than we expected.  I didn't think the portion sizes were so big.  

We ordered the following dishes:

Hot and Sour Soup
Thai Chili Pepper Pork
Mongolian Chicken
House Special Fried Fish
Thai Crispy Taro Rolls
Green Bean Salad

It was pretty tasty for the few first bites of every dish, but I would have enjoyed it better if I knew that everything we ordered wasn't fried, minus the soup.

Overall Rating: 4/5
Service:  4/5
Taste: 3.5/5
Price: 4/4
author: Matt L.

description: Round II at Chili House and now I have something to write home about. I chose their shui zhu yu-- a legendary Sichuan-style boiled fish dish. This comes in two sizes, dinner and lunch. I opted for the smaler lunch version and it met all expectations. Please: if you are spice averse, stay clear. I love spice, and my first bite still had me in the loo coughing. The dish was served full with tender white fish with loads and loads of traditional dried red chili as well as the famed Sichuan numbing pepper corn. Contrary to popular belief, the Sichuan pepper corn isn't spicy per say, it's numbing, and these did just that. It is a sensation that is all but absent at most "Szechuan" places. In addition, and for some reason beyond me, I also ordered the Yunnan rice cake with pork belly. This too was served spicy, but with chopped moist red chilies. The rice cakes were great, but the pork was too salty. Every meal comes with house soup (even if you order soup as a main) and pickled cabbage. I'd love to come back here with a big group and try about 5- or 7 dishes, including the frogs, which they told me they don't kill there (it's done across the street at the seafood butcher place.) Until then....
author: Brian J.

description:
I recently visited Chili House for a weekend lunch. I was excited to try the Z&Y sister restaurant closer to my house (and without a wait!).

The dining room is a similar size to the Z&Y in Chinatown and the menu offers the same sichuan dishes with additions. They do not have their beer & wine license yet but another table was enjoying wine and beer so I think they are operating as BYOB at the moment.

We had the explosive chicken, beef pancake, and cucumber and jalapeno salad.  Everything was as spicy as we had hoped and the beef pancake had a sweetness that offset our other spicy dishes. Food quality was what we expected  from visiting Z&Y. I look forward to visiting again and trying more of the dishes I enjoyed at Z&Y.

Service was a bit slow for a restaurant that was not even close to capacity but I am sure that will get better once they get a swing of things.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
Very small portion for its price. Two adults spent $60 for lunch without ordering expensive fish. 

It claims to be authentic Sichuan food, but the taste is far from that claim. 

Will not recommend, not if you are from mainland china.
author: Michael S.

description: I would have given it a four star based on the taste of the food, if I didn't have a diarrhea the next morning.
author: Stella R.

description:
I saw this place mentioned on Tablehopper as having just opened, so I figured I'd give it a try. I went with a couple of friends, one of whom had been through China and knew a thing or two about Sichuan cuisine.

We are all comfortable with blood and guts, so I was a little surprised by the waitress' attitude. After ordering, she confirmed with my friend that the "laowai" would eat the food, and when we asked for small bowls of rice, she told my friend there was no point because the laowai would just dump it on their plates anyway. (I understand enough Mandarin to follow my friend's conversation).

Waitress' attitude notwithstanding, the food was fantastic:

Couple's Delight - There were a few thick chunks of tendon that were hard to chew through, but the taste was fantastic. We all loved it - much better than at Z&Y or SPiCES. 4/5

Chicken With Explosive Chili Pepper - I have had this at a lot of Sichuan spots and it never quite meets my expectations. This one had just the right amount of spice and numbing Sichuan peppercorns to hit that perfect "ma la" balance. 4/5

House Special Fresh Filet Boiled in House Spicy Sauce - It's a Sichuan specialty that I would have loved a bit more if the dish had any kick. The pieces of fish held together really well, but the flavours fell a little flat. 3/5

Mao Xue Wang - This was a bit of everything; congealed blood, pork intestine, fish, beef, rice sticks, and more. Just a hodgepodge. Tasted fantastic. 4/5

Cumin Lamb - We figured we'd get something a bit less spicy, for some balance, and this certainly wasn't spicy. In fact, it was a bit sweet, which was somewhat disconcerting. The lamb was delicious despite the sweetness - tender, fatty, with a nice kick of cumin. 3.5/5

Overall, I'd give the place a 3.75/5. I'm more impressed with Chili House than I ever was with Z&Y, and I definitely want to go back.
author: Harley C.

description:
If you like spicy Chinese food, this is the place for you.   They burning hot chili oil beef, which reminds me of my home town.

They have other dishes too that are not so hot, but they really live up to their name with the chili oil.    I took my friends there and  they like spicy food but not as spicy as I do, and they really enjoyed the chicken dishes especially.

I also have some vegetarian friends and unfortunately they only had a few vegetarian dishes, but they had green onion pancakes as well as tofu without meat, but not much else for them.

I really enjoy the meat dishes myself and will take more friends to eat there.   Parking however is very tight.
author: Yang Q.

description: Bland and small portions not worth the money rather go to Sichuan Home on Geary Blvd.
author: Calvin C.

description: The staff here was incredibly rude. They served several tables of Chinese customers before us even though we were seated before them. We had to jump up and grab someone in order to try to place our order. Pretty sure our waiter coughed towards our food without covering his mouth either. Completely unprofessional and would never come back.
author: Natasha F.

description: Best looking insipid Chinese food I have ever eaten.  Imagine shaved strips of bitter melon glistening on a bed of ice covered in honey.  Beautiful but bitterless melon.  Tapioca balls stuffed with black sesame paste floating in semi opaque syrup tasting like dish water.  How do you destroy string beans with chili paste?  Start with poorly sourced, stringy beans.  Why did the Beijing Duck cross Clement Street:  It did not want to risk comparison with the superior take out fowl hanging in windows that surround this restaurant.  The menu is conceptually interesting; its execution is overall bland or raw, unsubtle, amateur.  I felt sorry for the attentive host and servers, who were all fine.
author: jeff c.

description: I used to frequent Chili House. But my last trip was my last. Their new chef seems to have completely changed every element of every dish, and it mostly just tastes very homogeneous, bland and lacks texture with the exception of maybe one or two dishes. With the unveiling of their new menu and its high prices for almost all dishes, I don't think this place is worth going back to.
author: Jake M.

description: Not bad. Inexpensive lunch ($8 each without tip or tax). We had the spicy water fish (fish in spicy oil) and the deep fried Taco Bell burrito fish (fish in chili bean)... Don't get me wrong, I like Taco Bell bean burritos and the fish wasn't actually bad, it was just interesting and unexpected. Flavor wasn't as robust as Z&Y, but it was a nice meal overall and the hot and sour soup to start was pretty good. Could have used some fire sauce...
author: Victoria K.

description: Luvve the Couples Delight, House Cold Noodles, Twice Cooked Pork, and the spicy fish dishes!!
author: Sheue L.

description: Chili house used to be one of my favorite Sichuan restaurants in the city. Not anymore after they replaced their chef and raised their price. The new chef is not even comparable to the old one, everything tastes bland. I'm not dumb enough to pay $16 for a dish that tastes like nothing. Will not be coming back!
author: Julia Q.

description: This place just opened up a bit ago so my friend and I decided to try it out. The flavor profiles are a definite change from all the other restaurants in the Inner Richmond. The flavors were spicy, clean, and super delicious. Friendly staff although we hit a language barrier regarding some questions with them, no biggie though. My favorite dishes were the spicy cucumber appetizer and the cold cut plates. I also tried a few other dishes and they were all very good. One dish I might avoid is the hot and sour soup; it's good but not amazing. All in all, love the food, friendly staff, and having another cuisine option in the Inner Richmond!
author: Rosanna N.

description:
ive always been a fan of the spicy numbing feel that i get from szechuan food. the menu here looks exactly like the one from Z&Y restaurant in chinatown where i am a fan of their food.

not sure if we just came on an off day, but aside from the couple's delight, the other things we got were pretty bad...

spicy wontons are my favorite szechuan dish to order but the night i went, the meat tasted really bad. and bad meat flavor plus all those chilis does not make it any better.

we also got the combination hot pot where all the food is already in the soup. there was a lot of food in it but it got very tiring to eat after awhile because it was just one flavor throughout. the fish also didn't taste very fresh. sadly the only thing that was good from that hot pot was the spam.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Love this place. Great lunch specials.  The service is good and the food comes out fast.  The only set back is that sometimes it comes out to fast and while you may not be completely finished with soup or appetizer.  

I definately would recommend this place to all my friends.
author: Kenneth G.

description: I have been to this place three times and it has been reliably MEDIOCRE. Their laziji was made with boneless chicken nuggets, not the usual bone-in variety. Fail - it lost on flavor and texture big-time! Shuizhu fish dishes were meh. And once again, if you are catering to a mostly Chinese clientele who craves spiciness, just make it S.P.I.C.Y.? Simple enough?
author: YM L.

description:
This review has more to do with the crappy waiter than the food.  We were being seated and he immediately asks us if we want appetizers. Sure, but can't we have a minute to at least look at the menu??!! Rolls his eyes and leaves. Another waitress comes by and takes our appetizer order--steamed pork dumplings and couples delight. Few minutes later the first waiter comes back and asks if we want appetizers....seriously?!  I told him another waiter took our appetizer order so he asks if we are going to order anything else. I start with a dish for my toddler boys, broccoli beef because they can't handle the heat. His response? "Really?? You come to a Szechuan restaurant and order broccoli beef?"  Excuse me?  I didn't ask for a commentary on my selection and why have it on the menu if you dislike it so much? I don't need to explain myself or justify my order to you! Also, we were excited about eating here and wanted to try many dishes, however, he kept stopping us and saying we ordered enough food. Are you rationing the food??? If I order too much food, isn't that my problem and a boon for you?

The interaction made our experience unpleasant and made the food less appealing.  Almost felt like being combative when he asked how the food was.....the food is not spicy....you call this a Szechuan restaurant? But bit my tongue.  Needless to say, hesitant to return. Fortunately the city is filled with other options that match good food with good service.
author: Dave T.

description: This was one of the worst meals I've had in years. We ordered the tan tan noodles and they were awful. Mushy noodles with oil that had no flavor. Orange chicken that was soggy and way too sweat. Tea smoked duck that was like duck jerky it was so dry and tough. We told the waitress we thought the food was terrible and she just shrugged. I will never go back here.
author: Shauna P.

description:
Whoa, such an underrated place.  I had never heard of it before, it's not on any of SF's important foodie lists but it was great.  My boyfriend's little, old Chinese grandpa picked it because he said he just "got a good feeling about it"

Very standard Chinese Food Restaurant decor. Standard service.  I'm going to list the things we tried from best to worst

GET:
1. House cold noodles -get them if you like peanut sauce and thick, fresh noodles

2. Cumin Lamb- DELICIOUS, not too spicy (and I'm a wimp) tender lamb, rich broth

3. Dry sauteed string beans- perfectly fried so they were crispy but still juicy on the inside without being greasy

4. Beef-pancake- YUM! flaky dough rolled up with beef and veggies, like a chinese stromboli. 

5. Scallion pancake- oh man this was DELICIOUS but sooo greasy.  order if you feel like indulging


SKIP:
6. Shanghai rice cake- I'm told Shanghai is famous for subtle flavor so be prepared this dish is "subtle" I would call it a bit bland but that just me

7. Chive dumplings -plain. not bad just entirely un-noteworthy
author: Meg M.

description:
Definitely takes after Z&Y. Moderately spicy, but nothing amazing. The portions are large, so make sure you account for your party and don't get too much food. Some dishes, you should probably ask for rice. 

Some issues I had were the over use of peppercorns in their cooking, making it taste somewhat bitter making a few dishes almost inedible to me.
author: Sara M.

description: Yummy spicy food and great service.  Got the scallion pancakes, spicy wonton, couples delight, and hot and sour soup.  Their soup portions are huge.  Was also able to order a hot pot on several occasions (the combo and fish ones are really good and large sized).  Tried to order the hot pot at Z&y (sister restaurant) on several occasions and was told they don't serve them there even though they were on the menu there as well.
author: Kathy P.

description:
The serve is so bad!!!!!!!!!!!! No smiles!!!!!!!!!!!And one of the order that called "樟茶鸭"is very bad!!!!!!
Even if this,we wrote $2.5 tips on the ticket,then,the server force us "you must pay $5 
at least".
I won't  go there again!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Feekek J.

description: Their sichuan food is pretty good. I have ordered the fish and chicken, both of them are delicious, it's a fabulous lunch.
author: Guanpeng G.

description: This is one of the best Sichuan restaurant I've been to in SF bay area. Authentic Sichuan food at a reasonable price. Definitely stop by if in SF.
author: Minami H.

description:
I really like Chinese food and have had really good luck with it in San Francisco.  So, I was looking forward to getting some good food.  Unfortunately this place was a bust.  

We were a group of five and we ordered a variety of dishes.  We thought the food ranged from inedible to forgettable.  The hot and sour soup had way too much vinegar.  The Hong Kong style noodles were bland.  The braised sea bass was gross.  The soup dumplings were pretty inedible.

Too bad we wasted a good food opportunity during our short visit :(
author: Ege Y.

description: If you like spicy Chinese this is the place for you.  Tan Tan noodles really warmed the palate,  Everything was quite flavorful.  Best wonton soup I have had in the neighborhood (still no where near as good as Tai Chi on Polk but good) They do ask how spicy you want it so you can ease in if you want.  Give this place a try if you are in the neighborhood.
author: Jerry W.

description:
Frickin awesome! Our new Chinese place for the spicy eater!! We had the pepper chicken, the dan dan noodles, fried tofu, killer potstickers and numbing beef. The tofu was totally superior and a great foil for all the spice. I know tofu and used to make it professionally.
The pepper chicken was generous and hunting for chicken was an excellent activity. There was enough for three people, one of whom is 13 so he eats double. 
The numbing beef was delicious. Couldn't stop eating it.
Very nice service, fun atmosphere, and takes reservations.
We will definitely return and bring friends!!!!
We're good!
author: Edward C.

description: This place is so good!!! If you are a fan of spicy food, then you should try this  restaurant! The complimentary pickled cabbage was delicious, and it heightened my expectations. I tried the chicken and cream of corn soup, spicy dumplings, spicy fried fish, and chow mein. The chow mein was the only average dish I had, but it was standard compared to other places. But other than that, all of the food was tasty! The spice level was very balanced and didn't overpower the dishes.
author: Rachel H.

description: Luck would have it that they're next door to the 4 star-rated Good Luck Dim Sum, practically the same address.  The vibe and mastery show them trying harder in face of a stiff competition.  The Mongolian beef was just juicy and fresh.  The fish fillet with bean chili was pure delight.  Their lunch special is an added bonus for affordability.
author: Ben C.

description:
Pretty good! Dong bo pork is a must

The bitter melon salad was small for the price but definitely  refreshing from the mountains of chili! 

Good service. Accommodated our party of 11 on a whim including baby strollers and all.

Very affordable and clean.

A+ !

I'll be back..
author: Tiffany T.

description: I will just say this: I'm not a huge fan of spicy food (I'm Russian--we're not used to spicy stuff! I was dragged here by my spicy food-loving friends), but I loved everything! We got Sesame Chicken (just in case I couldn't handle the heat), Tan Tan Noodles, Fish Filet with White Sauce, and some Won ton Soup (can't recall what it was called). Even though I had to drink a ton of tea, it tasted so good that I had to keep going. I'm sure I'll be back!
author: Anna T.

description: This place only gets 3 1/2 stars on yelp but the food was actually much better than that. The weight in the restaurant just for takeout was about 40 minutes and that was kind of annoying, but we watch lots of dishes come out of the kitchen and they looked really really good including the peking duck. We tried the Westlake minced beef soup and it was really tasty. We also got some kind of house special chow mein noodles and I was pretty impressed. I would love to go back there and try the Peking duck. Definitely not an inexpensive place.
author: Doug C.

description: It was so hot I loved it. I felt like I was exhausted after the meal. The spice depleted me of energy. The food was fantastic. The service- not so much. I needed water. I even brought a quart- it wasn't enough. I ordered beer. No one came back to ask if I needed more- oh yes I did. Their food is so hot and so good but bring a gallon of milk or water with you because otherwise you will burn.
author: Me M.

description: The pancakes were very oily and I've never felt more disrespected at a restaurant in my life.  Unfortunately they probably pay yelp to remove their bad reviews.
author: Leslie D.

description: I was coming off of work and my girlfriend and I called up another couple to eat with us. We decided we wanted to try a new place and my friend decided to come to Chili House. We ordered some pancake thing, mapo tofu, a corn dish with shrimp, and some chili noodle dish. All the food was spicy after eating a couple a bites. I'm not used to eating spicy food but this place definitely packs alot of heat in their food. My girlfriend and I enjoyed the shrimp dish because it was the only one not spicy but it felt spicy from all the other foods we ate. The place gets packed during the dinner rush too. The service was friendly and prompt.
author: Jason L.

description: They now have a lunch menu where you can get a smaller portion of flaming fish oil for half the price of the normal dinner price. This is really cool because normally places will offer pretty uninteresting/americanized meals on the lunch menu. The cold sesame noodles are pretty good too- they have szechuan peppercorns in the sauce so the flavor has extra depth and complexity.
author: E. M.

description: A place I frequent, as this is probably one of the best Sichuanese restaurant in the city. The fish dish with noodle is pretty nice.
author: Tian W.

description: Here's what you need to know about Chili House:  the food is really good.  It's Sichuan.  It's authentic.  It makes your mouth happy.  Just go there.  Service is friendly, decor is perfectly fine, energy is positive, prices are reasonable (especially for SF).  We went there looking for a replacement for a place in San Leandro that closed a while back and we were very pleasantly surprised.  Get the sliced fish in hot chili oil, and the spicy wonton appetizer, and the Explosive Chicken.  Just order everything that has the color red in it.
author: Adam H.

description:
We really enjoyed this place--the Fish Filet in spicy house sauce was recommended by our gracious server, and it was delicious and worth the high price. The Wontons in Spicy Peanut Sauce were also delicious. Our mistake was ordering other "standard" dishes--which were fine, but all we needed was one order of the fish, some rice, and the won tons--we would have been happy and full!

We will definitely be back.
author: Laura S.

description:
We ordered Dry Sautéed String Beans, Salty Pepper w/Prawns and Grilled Whole Fish.  We also asked for less spicy for all dishes.

String Beans were very good, just enough of Garlic and string beans were perfectly cooked.  Slightly hot spice gave it a nice kick.

Salty Pepper Prawn is a deep fry dish w/ flour which was different from what I expected.  However, the taste of this dish was quite good. It was not greasy and flour was nice and crunchy.  Hot spice was just right for us.

Grill Whole Fish was not grilled as the menu said.  It was deep fry, the same way as the Salty Pepper Prawn.  I asked the waitress why it was not grilled and she told me that is how they prepare for this dish.  We asked to replace it to Braised Whole Fish.  She checked with the kitchen and changed it for us.  She had a very nice attitude and great service.  

Braised Whole Fish was surprisingly good.  The meat was very tender; the fish was good size, not too big / small.  The souse was very tasty.  They fry the fish before braising so it was also a little crunchy around edges.  By the time we finished it had nothing left other then bones.

Our comments for this place, food is wonderful and service is great.  We will be back.
author: Yelppy L.

description: Please don't always automatically relayed to the customer who give you the lower stars! If you really want to improve your service and making the restaurant better, you need to learn how to be nice to the customer, no matter eating in your restaurant or call you guys to order to go! I have called your restaurant and want to order something few days ago, but when I ask some questions, the lady hang up the phone and I called back, the same sound from the lady and she says she's the manager! ! ! How could you be rude for the customer? Do you think you open a restaurant only for sell the food and the other things no matter????? Where's the f*cking customer service????? It makes me so mad. I think the owner should consider change the person who don't know how to manage the restaurant!
author: Veronica G.

description: Really enjoyed the pea tips, pork dumplings, chicken with basil, and Mongolian beef.  Will be back.
author: Yella W.

description: Authentic Sichuan.  Try the Shuizhu Niurou (水煮牛肉).
author: Michael D.

description: 90% of the meal is chili covered so if you can't handle the heat, get out of Chili House. It was a cold winter day and I wanted something that would warm me up. Ordered the tan tan noodles, beef pancakes, and chil beef tendons. All were delicious and very traditional. Noodles came with a broth doused with chili oil and numbing spicy. Made me sweat more than a long jog. Beef pancakes were very hearty and the tendons were cooked until Al Dente, thinly sliced and slathered in chili oil. By the time i finished eating, I was spiced up and went through napkins like sweat towels at the gym.
author: Ed L.

description: Came on a Saturday afternoon and the place was not busy so we had the attention of all servers available :) We ordered appetizer cold chicken with wine , dumplings and a big bowl of beef noodle soup . I thought everything was great especially the soup which was flavorful , well-balanced and fresh. Definitely will come back and will try other dishes in their menu.
author: Jed D.

description: Just opened for four (4) days, Chili House promises to be a destination spot for all who enjoy Sichuan and Northern Chinese cuisine. This is the sister restaurant of the popular Z&Y Restaurant in San Francisco's Chinatown. As such, the menu is currently the same. Then again, Chili House offers Northern Chinese deem sum, such as beef pancakes and buns. The food is solid, authentic, and delectable. Now, there a great place in the Richmond District for this numbing spicy food. Highly recommended.
author: aL Z.

description: This place is hit or miss for me. Sometimes its extremely spicy and I start sweating bullets, and other times its moderate enough that I can  withstand it with just water and tea. Everything is quite good, I love the beef in flaming chili oil as well as the tan tan men. The Mapo Tofu is honestly a bit spicy for me, but when I'm feeling extra confident, I'll eat it knowing the consequences I'll face on the toilet later on.
author: Cody M.

description:
Lately, there's been a small invasion of Szechwan/Hunan places in The Richmond.  As someone who has been deprived of good Chinese take-out, I welcome our new spicy neighbors.  One of these is Chili House, on Inner Clement.  The dining area is clean and remodeled with "interesting" choices for music.  The service is a bit slow, but the food (at least for what I ordered) was worth the wait.  

First visit: Mabo Tofu and Rice to go.  Ordered extra spicy.  It had the burn and the numbing peppers that numbed my tongue.  The tofu was firm so you could it up with chopsticks easily.  Awesome, especially compared to my last visit to Spices (which seems to have gone downhill).  

Second visit: Kung Pao chicken over rice for lunch.  Bits of chicken were bite sized and the portion was nap inducing (generous).  Ordered spicy and felt the burn come on half way through.  Dish was good.  Ordered an canned iced tea (the kind in the red can).  $2.50!! Check the menu for beverage prices. 

So they can do the basics.  Good.  Next visit means a proper multi-dish dinner.  Exploding chicken perhaps?
author: Rodney L.

description: Ohh my, with a abundance of Chinese, Thai local haunts abound, this place takes tops honors. Every dish, from a appetizer to a main dish was outstanding. When I order pork & leeks I get pork & leeks. Not fillers like a Volkswagen sized bell pepper or a waTer chestnut that I'm pushing aside, or a piece of cooked celery that places will "add to the dish" casual yet not downtrodden. A great local find
author: Mark C.

description:
A nice big menu of great Sichuan food options. This is where I take all my out-of-town guests. Food that is sinus-clearingly spicy, but full of rich and excellent flavor as well. The portions are large and I can never quite order the right amount for my party without ending up with leftovers, but that is the best problem in the world to have. 

I particularly love the "fish filet in flaming chili oil" and the cold spicy noodles.
author: Jacob M.

description: Absolutely love Chili House. XLB, Green beans, tan tan noodles and meat pancake -- all delicious and gracious service!
author: Angelique V.

description:
If you are really truly looking for authentic Szechuan cuisine then this is the place. This is not your average Take out Chinese place so expect to open your mind and go here to try new things and strange amazing flavors. Although you can get your standard fried rice and walnut prawns there are so many more unique dishes you need to try. And FYI if you are a spice fanatic like myself a lot of my recommendations are SPICY so watch out. They dont mess around. You can always ask for more chili sauce if youre feeling daring.
Although very odd the Cold Beef Tendon appetizer is an experience. I have no idea what the flavors or textures are and this is not a dish for everyone but once I tried it years ago I was sold.
Of course you have to get the Mapo Tofu and the beef pancake roll appetizer. I dont know all the exact names so hopefully im close.
The number one thing you must get is The Explosive Fried Chicken! Comes in a giant platter of hot peppers and it is awesome (dont be convinced to eat several of the peppers like I was...you will regret it)
The hot pots are pretty popular as I saw them on several tables around us and the fried fish is good as well.
Go with an open mind or should i say palette and you wont regret it
author: Lilia D.

description: I live in the inner Richmond so I thought I would give this place a try. I wanted rice noodles in a broth with chicken. I ordered Yunnan style. I have no clue what that is...no description in the menu. I was told it had chicken and fish so I said ok. I ordered it to go. I got home and the noodles smelled like human feces. They were in a separate container than the broth. The meat container had bizarre looking meat. Spam! I do not like mystery meat....the chicken was scary and I do not know what was up with the fish..I went back to get real chicken. They promised that there was no MSG but I got it home and there was MSG! Horrible. Suffice to say, I won't go back.
author: Jewli J.

description: Pretty easy to make a reservation for four on Saturday night. Dumplings and green beans were quite good.
author: Huey K.

description: Been to Chili House twice, and the food was decent the first time and an explosion of oil and grease the second. Service was slow, food was overwhelmingly oily... not a pleasant dining experience. Will not be back.
author: Kate B.

description: Fish pot, dan dan noodles, liang fen, red sauce wontons, and other delicious goodies. Everything (good) here is either spicy or goes with something spicy. You should come with a bunch of friends and family style. Beware the VERY long wait. Try to make a reservation and remind them if you have been waiting a while - they may have forgotten.
author: Jenny J.

description: Really bad food, really bad service. When I walked in to try it out, I ended up standing there with no acknowledgement. I wrote my name on the list they have lying out there and proceeded to wait. A couple walked in behind me waiting for me to be seated so they could be seated. The waiter finally came over and instead of seating me, he seated them?! I decided to look past that and I was finally seated. On to the food. Some of the worst Chinese food I've ever had in my life. I ordered the Hunan Beef. Literally couldn't ensure that I was actually eating beef and everything was drenched in excessive amounts of oil. Also while I was dining there, someone sitting next to me found a rock in their food. The waiter refused to acknowledge and/or fix the situation.
author: Jeff W.

description: This place was okay for us.  A lot of MSG and meat tenderizer powder.  With that being said, it is authentic Sichuan style spicy chinese food with Chinese restaurant style service (minimal but fast service) This restaurant would not survive 3 months in China.  Go to Mission Chinese or Sichuan home instead.
author: Wunan L.

description:
I feel that I had to update my review for this one.  I wrote a review 3 years ago and gave a 3 star, complaining about the going down quality.  

I happened to talk to the owner about 1 year ago and gave her my honest feedback, I do feel this restaurant is improving, the quality of the dishes goes up, the services is getting better, they also introduce some Chinese northern style DimSum.  One thing remained for improving is to reduce the salt and grease of the dishes.
author: Lillia B.

description:
Good - If you are craving spicy food.

Cons:
-OVERLY BUSY - UNORGANIZED WAITLIST/SEATING SYSTEM:
When I went there last weekend, the lady that greeted me told me they dont take names and the table will be ready in 5 mins. Went to the restroom and came back, saw 3 parties waiting. I tried to tell the server I was here first but he said, oh, we just started a clipboard for waitlist, you can be 4th on the waitlist.

-ANGRY SERVER, SOME DUDE:
There's a super nice guy with glasses and there is another dude that looks like he hates you, his life, and his job. If dude #2 doesn't like his job, he should find a new career.

-FOOD PREP:
I ordered a few popular dishes and the taste was lacking. It was very busy. I'm guessing they didn't prepare/marinate enough food to accommodate business volume. Everything tasted almost right, but not quite there.

I PACKED MOST OF THE FOOD HOPING THEY WILL TASTE BETTER AFTER MARINATING OVERNIGHT.AND YUP, IT SURE DID! 


YUMMY THE DAY AFTER!
author: Fu D.

description: The deep fried eggplant sucks.  The help bickering in Cantonese while I ate was not my idea of atmosphere.  Three different waitresses.  No brown rice.  Yuck.
author: Steven Z.

description: We Tried the recommended dishes. Honestly, they aren't that good. 3 stars only compares to the Sichuan home on Geary st.
author: Johnny Y.

description: Great spicy food with depth of flavor.  The dishes can be a little rich for me to eat often, but I really enjoy it.  Great tan tan noodles.  Good portions.
author: Courtney C.

description: Only tried once. But overpriced and mediocre. Chicked curry was bland and really tasteless.  Spicey dumplings were ok.  Spicey green beans didnt seem fresh. 55 $ for 2 seemed way overpriced
author: Terry K.

description: Everything is red. I was drag out into the cold to head here for dinner, I was hesitant at first due to laziness. But I'm glad I went. Good is good, not amazing but it gets the job done. Portion was good for the price. Nothing stood out in particular. I did like their beff tendon, beef wrap, fried fish, and eggplant( they did a different take then normal). We orders the chicken n the fish soup n 2 soy milk. 70 something for 3  with left over... Not bad.
author: jasmin t.

description: mediocre food with mediocre service. But the dining was clean and nice. Otherwise, i'd go for 'Spices!' Which is like 20 steps away.
author: Honey G.

description: Lousy service.  Don't want to get into details, but to make a long story short, they need to be more attentive... TREAT EVERYONE EQUAL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  MAYBE THEY THOUGHT I WAS APPLYING FOR A DISHWASHING JOB???? I SOMETIMES GET CONFUSFED FOR SIMILAR POSITIONS:). Anyways.. screw this place.  Im sure the food is good.  Went to place down the street, got seated immediately, got my order in. Was asked from time to time how everything was.
author: Demanding T.

description: good szechuan place, not much for dim sum.
author: Wayne C.

description: the spicy fish pot was pretty good! im glad my friend brought me to this place i will def be back again. the spicy isnt super spicy but the place was still very good!
author: Bill H.

description: I have been to China many many times for business. One of the things I look forward to when I go there is the food and experience of eating the different varieties of dishes. This restaurant has very friendly staff and most of all good dishes.
author: Taz M.

description:
So One of my friend said that the quality of food in this place is equal to Z & Y. Another friend said it is different. From what I know the food at Z & Y, had their ingredients coming from this kitchen, and both were owned by the same family. 
Anyway, So far, in my opinion,  both have the same quality, except this one is less crowded, thus more convenient!
author: Kristin W.

description:
It used to be a task to find any Szechuan restaurant in the city, and all of a sudden 3 sprang up in a 8 block radius in Richmond.  

We tried a few of the Yelper recommended dishes.  Only Green Onion Pancake made an impression to us.  Dan Dan noodles were spicy for sure, but texture leaves much room for improvement.  Kung Pao tofu was edible, and simple stir fry veggies have a layer of cornstarch paste that's less appetizing.

It's a step up from Spices!  But not the house for me.
author: daphne w.

description: The food is bland, gross, and over priced. I never thought I would ever dislike a pot sticker and they made me believe it was possible. Never again.
author: Natalie J.

description: Among the best Szechuan food in SF; a city dominated by Cantonese cuisine. The Chicken with Explosive Chili Pepper is as good as  dishes I enjoyed back in China.
author: mack m.

description: After reading the reviews on Yelp I was excited to eat at Chili House. The wait staff was ok - not the friendliest, I've had better and I'm afraid to say that I was under whelmed by the food. My husband wanted one non spicy dish, we ordered mushu pork (it was ok) then we have the deep fried spicy fish (ok) spicy tan tan noodles (ok ~ my complaint is that it was REALLY greasy) and the spicy chicken. The chicken was deep fried, but was lost with all the red peppers. I think we had ten small pieces of chicken and tons of red peppers. What a waste of money on that one. I don't think I'll come back again, there are way too many places to eat in the city.
author: Tina P.

description: We actually planned to go to Spices II but ended up parking a few blocks up Clement St, randomly saw this place and decided to give it a try. There was no wait on a Friday night. We tried some of our typical benchmark sichuan dishes: fuqifeipian, dandan noodles, and chongqing laziji (spicy chicken). The fuqifeipian wasn't bad, but definitely not our favorite -- it was a little too sweet.  The dandan noodles were good but we found the sauce to be a little soupy and again a bit too sweet and not enough sesame paste/nutty flavor. The laziji was disastrous -- boneless chicken that tasted like it had been frozen for weeks and it just didn't have the right taste to it. One thing I was pleasantly surprised by however, was their very liberal use of sichuan peppercorns (mala ftw!). We still prefer Spices (both locations) to Chili House but would go back in a pinch. The best is still Sichuan Fusion in Richmond if you're up for the drive.
author: Wayne H.

description: I read here on Yelp about this place and that it's a sister restaurant to Z&Y on Jackson Street in Chinatown (which has become quite popular and busy even on weeknights).  I came to check it out.  Indeed, the menu appears to be the same.  Just as during visits to Z&Y, I went for the tan tan noodle and it was excellent.  Of the few places I ordered that, they definitely have the best one.  Just be prepared for your teeth and tongue to maybe have a rough feeling right after you finish. :)
author: H K.

description:
ate here yesterday with two friends.  Everything we had was delicious:

1) ko shui ji (that's saliva chicken)....tender and with a deliciously spicy sauce
2) fish stew with pickled vegetables - this was AMAZING.  one of my favorite dishes in general, but the version here was filly and tasty with lots of fish fillets, tofu, mushrooms, and a few vermicelli.  the pickles they used were delicous.
3) string beans - pretty good!
4) scallion pancake - i'm not a fan of these in general, but the version they had grew on me over time.

I just had the left over fish soup for lunch and I'm already trying to think about how I can go back to get more!
author: Yin L.

description:
Came on Christmas Eve with the family.  We were seated towards the front which was very cold. The restaurant did provide a small heater for the area but we were freezing the entire time.  The food was super hot and spicy but absolutely delicious.  
House Special Fresh Filet Boiled in House Spicy Sauce - the  fish was flavorful but the broth was hot like lava.
Chicken with Explosive Chili Pepper - the chicken bits were denser here than at Z&Y (sister restaurant).
Eggplant with Garlic Sauce - the deep fried eggplant is so good and really makes the dish.  It's not too spicy so it was a good break from the above.
We had non-spicy food eaters so we also got the chow mein and fried noodles.  They were ok; no complaints as we knew they weren't sichuan dishes.   I just added a spoonful of the fish broth to the noddles and it made the dish very good.
author: Gwen C.

description: We came in last night and ordered 8 dishes and 2 bowls of soup but the most dishes had no flavor, and salty. We claimed to a waitress, the way it is, can't do nothing about it, she said. All my friends were disappointed, we paid $375.00 for the dinner.
author: Trung N.

description: After the downhill decline of Z&Y, we are left with very few options in SF for good Sichuan food.  Chili House has potential.  The waitress from the now closed Panda Country Inn works here and remembered us.  The food for the most part was decent.  It was only there 3rd day open on busy Clement street.  Service was quite slow the night we were there as the room is so large and the wait staff did not have their service coordinated.  Working hard but hardly smart.  I would try this place in another month.
author: Laurence H.

description:
This is definitely an authentic Chinese joint in two ways. First, the food is spot on Szechuanese. Second, the service sucks.

Now before you get up in arms about the racist comment I just made, allow me to clarify. Service here is good if you are accustomed to shouting across the table at a passing waiter. This is the Chinese model for customer service, where common courtesy is dispensed with for the sake of getting to the point. There is nothing inherently wrong with this, it's just a cultural norm. 

Also, I'm Chinese, so it's ok if I say things like that. .

 If, on the other hand, you like to wave down servers when they are close to your table, you're going to have a bad time. You can gesticulate, you can politely chirp "Excuse me" repeatedly, the waitstaff here will not notice. They are all furiously studying something on their shoes as they weave around the restaurant emptyhanded.

A waitress here, she seems to be the manager as well, is humorless and impatient with the elderly. Now I know that is a very specific criticism, but I happen to be very particular about how service personnel treat my 90 year old grandfather. This woman missed the mark by far. Old people are hard of hearing, so repeat yourself without appearing exasperated. Old people talk slowly, so don't fidget like you are in a hurry, even if you are. 

My grandfather spent some years in Szechuan and says the food is very authentic. They make their own chili oil and serve handmade noodles. We'll likely be back but with lowered expectations for service so we don't have an aneurysm over dinner.
author: Polly F.

description: delicious, its hard to find places like this :) wish it wasn't all the way in richmond!
author: Gloria Z.

description: I'm only giving this place four stars because i'm being selfish hehe. I HATE lines.. the always gets packed with chinese people around dinner time... and man oh man... good company and good food... call for long long conversations. the food is SO mouth watering. I LOVE spicy food and very flavorful asian dishes, and this place has exactly that. Spicy, bold and sodium-filled goodness. Prepare to be bloated and fat for the next couple days as you drink all the water you can to flush it out. but, SO worth it.. mmmh!
author: Mish L.

description: love this place!  despite the fact that there is a huge chinese population in san francisco, there are very few good authentic chinese places. with that said, if you like authentic chinese food (and especially spicy/sichuan style chinese food) - this place is probably the best in the city. some of the dishes are on the greasier side, but they are all very very tasty. the place is pretty spacious and clean, great for groups. the service is usually pretty good as well (at least for an asian restaurant).
author: Lisa H.

description: If you eat at restaurants on Clement Street before 11th Ave. you know they can be a bit on the iffy side, esp. in all around cleanliness.  Chili House is fresh and new, it feels airy and spacious.  The rectangular tables are black granite or something similar, a quality touch.  The waitstaff is as good as it can be.  Today the music was Celine Dion, yes, odd but a nice change.  The food I had was perfectly prepared.  Their woks must be smokin' hot, and if you like it Peppery HOT, you will be very satisfied.  I will return, again and again. They don't cater to tourist trade and the food is authentic, as far as I can tell.  Go for lunch, the prices are more than fair and the food is excellent.
author: Rona M.

description: This is definitely in my top places to get Chinese food list. If you can't handle spicy food though don't come here. Food is so spicy but soo good! We got the explosive chili chicken, garlic string beans, and a tofu dish I can't remember the name of but I loved. They also give you complimentary peanuts and tea. Pack your tums and go get some deliciously spicy good food here.
author: Ashley R.

description:
I can safely say that this place and R&G are my favorite places for Chinese food in SF.  For some people the dishes might be too spicy, but for me it's mmmm delicious.

We first went when they just opened, and every time since then we have not been disappointed.  Some of our favorites are:

- mapo tofu (we order this every single time)
- couple's delight
- sliced pork w/ garlic sauce
- water cooked fish or beef
- beef pancake
- spicy wontons

Of course, not every dish is a winner.  Items like the Dong Po Pork, tan-tan and cold noodles, Whole Fish, XLB, and others were nothing special.  That being said, there's a whole lot more on the menu that we'll be going back to try.

Hot tip:  the herbal tea drink is 1000x more delicious than usual when your tongue is burning and you feel like you're going to die.
author: Felix W.

description: I came here with my friends last week...I like the spicy food...but the parking is terrible.We waited about 30 minutes...I like    the spicy fish soup...and you shouldn't miss the cold noodles...It's amazing.The best chinese food in SF...
author: Yun W.

description: We got fried rice, spicy crispy chicken, soup, and noodles. The food was good, service was ok. If you are craving spices and chinese food, then yes go here !
author: Parveen G.

description: I only tried one thing on the menu, so this review is only based on a review of their hot and sour soup. Their hot and sour soup is, by far, the worst I have ever had in my life. I was sick with a cold, so I was craving some hot and sour soup, which usually makes me feel better. I was in the neighborhood, so I decided to give them a try. I got one order of hot and sour soup to go. The soup was sick and extremely gelatinous. Although it had heat and spice, it was largely flavorless. What flavor that was there, was not good. I was tempted to just put it all down the garbage disposal, but I forced myself to have some, hoping that any kind of hot soup would make me feel better. The next day, I added a lot of vegetable stock to their soup, along with some soy sauce and seasonings. It made it a little more palatable, but still not great soup. I would never go back to this place again, based on my hot and sour soup experience. They may very well have other dishes that are delicious, but I don't feel like giving them a second chance.
author: Suzanne E.

description:
Very good food and an even better menu.  I would like to have tried many of the more unusual dishes.  Prices are fair and will not break the bank.  
For the folks here who complained about the service; did you want good food or a servant?   
I'll go back.
author: Len N.

description: Finally a good Szechuan restaurant in the bay.
author: Koalie W.

description: YUM YUM YUM! If you are a fan of spicy food, this is your restaurant. The crab is a must eat! I only have good things to say about this restaurant.
author: Curry F.

description:
The prices are very affordable (especially if you go in for lunch!) and the food is great. The hot and sour soup never disappoints. The only thing I would say, which is probably true of most (non-gourmet) chinese food, is that it's not as good the next day, especially the meat dishes. 
Customer service was also very friendly. I would have given this place 5 stars but I didn't because i wouldnt call it "as good as it gets". But it's very close to it :]
author: Alina S.

description:
