Went there for the first time with my wife. It was really good. We had the beef pancake, egg rolls, combo chow mein and Kung Pao Chicken. The meals were all superb. This was the way Kung Pao Chicken should be cooked - one of the best I ever had...
There were a lot of unique (to me) dishes...a lot of them are spicy - some plates had food on top of a bed of chili peppers, some items were drowned in those chili peppers too..it was really interesting and intimidating as well..Some of the photos of dishes in their menu looked like something out of a bad dream with all sorts of oddities blended with shades of red, shades of chili peppers...
Some of the things on the menu were straight out of bizarre foods...
Andrew Zimmern - come get some ! 
Definitely a szechuan (sp) restaurant with over 50% of the items being spicy containing those chili peppers which I usually refer to them as Satan's Penis. 
I thought the service was good , friendly staff. I saw their sign said Grand Opening and personally speaking, I think they will do really well. I do want to go back there again because it was really good. And explore some of their other things on the menu..
Be sure to bring plenty of kleenex when you go. Recommended to those who love spicy foods, or if you,re under the weather , get some really hot soup ..those cold germs will run for their lives.  
They do need to include brown rice on the menu, and maybe a Chow Fun in addition to their chow mein.
author: David S.

description: Great addition to Clement street. I've had the hunan beef, the green onion pancakes, the pot stickers, and the wonton soup. Everything I've had there is delicious. I should mention the wonton soup. I've never tasted finer broth in that soup, and the wontons are also very good. Service is great.
author: James P.

description:
I wanted to love this place so badly.

I am a huge Sichuan fan, and have celebrated and lamented the comings and eventual passings of all Sichuan restaurants in the Richmond. When I saw that a new Chinese place had opened on Clement, I was Actively Not Caring About Another Chinese Restaurant on Clement Street. Then I looked at the pictures in the windows of staple Sichuan dishes and was more like Please Let This Be Real A Sichuan Place on Clement.

We finally had the chance to try it on a Friday evening (takeout).

We have three benchmark dishes generally ordered our first time to a Sichuan restaurant - it allows for easy comparison: Chonquing chicken (not called that on their menu, but I forget what name they used), Mapo Dofu and Dry-Fried Green Beans.

Chonquing Chicken was 3/5
Mapo Dofu was 3/5
Green Beans were 4/5 - not as crispy as I would have like but the sauce was fantastic

Everything came together to leave a fairly underwhelmed feeling. Nothing was bad, but it just didn't have any life either.

Result: much better than most Chinese in this neighborhood and in the city as a whole. Not a standout by Sichuan standards.

---

Whoever took my phone order was light years ahead of the level of service gotten from most Chinese places, though!
author: r g.

description: Super good food that is nearly authentic chinese.  The surroundings are clean, but not fancy.  Prices are very reasonable.  We will make it a normal stop.
author: v n.

description:
I was shopping at New May Wah when I looked across the street and saw a new restaurant, Chili. It had huge pictures of food in the window so I went over for a closer inspection. I found a menu on the door and thought "I am going to have to try each and every one of these plates of food, starting with Mo Po which no one has ever been able to make hot enough for my taste. 

When we first sat down we were served a 'teaser' and I did not recognize what vegetable it was. Potato was the answer. I had always wondered what the Chinese would do with a potato and now I know. How in the world they get it cut so thin is something I want to know the answer to. Lightly steamed and while still crispy a light sauce that truly excites the taste buds, served room temperature. We had another dish that I can not find on the menu chicken marinated in something wonderful covered with a pepper and oil sauce. I have never eaten anything like it and Bruce says we are definetly returning here again. We ordered a sup gum chow mein and another vegetable dish and some steamed rice and tea. Nice sized portions yet very low prices in a clean dinning room with attentive waitpersons. The service was as excellent as was the food. 

The only thing I don't like is they close at 10pm and it can be difficult to get there before then if my meeting runs late. I really want to try their dim sum. I know I will be returning here again and again. Highly recommended
author: Alan H.

description: Loved this place!  We got Tan tan noodles, crispy chicken with jalapeños, boiled fish in chili oil, bitter melon with honey.  I was sweating like crazy but was definitely worth it.
author: Daisy W.

description: The cold noodles and the eggplant with garlic are PERFECT dishes. We ask for extra-spicy and it hits the spot.
author: Rahul A.

description: I don't know where all the media buzz come from. The food is average the most. There was nothing extraordinary. I ordered the flaming oil fish dish.
author: Sheila S.

description: the best sichun food in bay area!!!! I love Z&Y, so i came here since i heard they are so how related. it didnt disappoint us. highly recommended!!! just a little far from my place.
author: Sishi L.

description: The food is good but their previously very high health score has slipped recently to an 88.
author: R. P.

description: Omg! I am still craving the Diced meat with Sour Bean dish!!! So good, so addictive. My sister from New York insisted on swinging by the restaurant before heading back to Marin to pick up this yumminess. I added spicy dumplings and we were in heaven!! Made some rice at home and that ws a great welcome to the Bay Area dinner!
author: Belle C.
